TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned respectfully submit that Social Housing is a major social safety net, crucial for all Australians.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to maintain a commitment to the buying and building of new housing properties. The new Commonwealth State Housing Agreement must provide the States with monies to buy and build more Public and Community Housing. Dismantling the safety net of Social Housing will mean homelessness, overcrowding and the scrapping of public housing redevelopment plans, all of which will impact on the most disadvantaged groups in the Australian society.
Your petitioners support an increase in assistance to low income earners in the private rental market, but not at the expense of Public and Community Housing.
Your petitioners thus urge the Senate to reject current plans in the area of public and community housing.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows: That the East Timorese asylum‐seekers, who have fled terror in their country and who have sought refugee status in Australia, are being unfairly rejected on the basis of dubious ascription of Portuguese nationality. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Prime Minister and his Minister for Immigration:

1. Acknowledge the burden on charitable organisations and basic human need and permit the continuation of Asylum Seekers Assistance for all East Timorese refugee applicants until a decision by the Federal Court is made.
2. Reinstate the right of an interview in all East Timorese refugee determinations.
3. Grant special humanitarian consideration for East Timorese refugee applicants.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

2 August 1996
Senator the Hon Richard Alston
Minister for Communications and the Arts
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Richard
I refer to:
1. National Gallery Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1996 No. 92
2. Australian National Maritime Museum Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1996 No. 93.

There does not appear to have been an amendment made to r.4(2) of the principal National Gallery Regulations since 1984, yet the legislation affecting those who would normally be given exemptions from entry charges has undergone substantial change since then. These include the new Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the new Social Security Act 1991 and amendments of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 now covered by the present new exemption. Until the present amendments the principal Regulations referred to long repealed provisions of the Social Security Act 1947 and the Repatriation Act 1920.

The Committee would appreciate your advice on why it has taken so long to update the Regulations. For instance, amendment of the principal Australian National Maritime Museum Regulations in 1991 by Statutory Rules 1991 No. 348 would have been a precedent for updating. That amendment refers to both the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

The Regulations confer a benefit. The Committee would appreciate your advice, however, on whether any person could have been deprived of a benefit by the apparent failure to update. Were the previously existing provisions of the Regulations ignored in practice? Were people exempted from paying the charge in breach of the Regulations?

The Explanatory Statement for Statutory Rules 1996 No. 93 does not advise of the reasons for the omission of references to Part 2.9 and Part 2.10 from r.2A(2)(b)(i) of the principal Regulations, or an indication of how long ago this updating should have occurred.

New r.4(2)(c)(iii) of Statutory Rules 1996 No. 92 does not italicise the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, in contrast to Commonwealth drafting practice as expressed, for instance, in r.2A(2)(b)(iii) of Statutory Rules 1996 No. 93.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
6 November 1996
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Bill

Thank you for your letter of 2 August 1996 concerning the amendments to the National Gallery Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No. 92 and the Australian National Maritime Museum Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No. 93.

As the Committee points out the National Gallery Regulations have not been amended since 1984. This was an oversight exacerbated by the changes in Administrative Arrangement Orders for the Arts side of the portfolio during that time.

The Committee has expressed concern that people might have been deprived of a benefit by failure to update the National Gallery Regulations. Subregulation 4(7) of the National Gallery Regulations and subregulation 2A(5) of the Australian National Museum Regulations confer a discretionary power to admit people without payment of entry fees. The National Gallery of Australia and the Australian National Maritime Museum have advised that it is their practice to admit, without payment, people receiving pensions, benefits or allowances. Thus I understand that no one is likely to have been disadvantaged by the failure to update the National Gallery Regulations or the technical drafting defects in the Australian National Maritime Museum Regulations. Nor has it been necessary for these bodies to breach the Regulations in order to allow free entry by persons in receipt of relevant pensions, benefits or allowances.

In amending the Australian National Maritime Museum Regulations, the Office of Legislative Drafting (OLD) took the opportunity to delete what appeared to be obsolete references to Parts 2.9 and 2.10 of the Social Security Act 1991 (Social Security Act). However, OLD has now advised the reference to Part 2.9 was omitted in error. OLD has also advised that the non‐italicisation of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 in Statutory Rules No. 92 was a drafting oversight.

I understand that the above technical defects in the Australian National Maritime Museum Regulations will be corrected the next time that the Regulations are amended. I also understand that the Department of Communications and the Arts will be exploring with OLD whether relevant exemptions in both sets of Regulations can be drafted in a more general way to avoid the need to update them on each occasion there is an amendment to relevant Commonwealth legislation.
I hope this clarifies the matter to your satisfaction.
Yours sincerely
RICHARD ALSTON
Minister for Communications and the Arts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the reference of the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I am of the view that this is a wrong reference. I am not talking about the substance of the bill or the merits of the issue that the bill refers to. As the Chair of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee and Deputy Chair of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, I am concerned at the workload of the committee. The taking on of this reference will result, in my opinion, in an exponential increase in the workload of the committee that we will not be able to carry through. We will not be able properly to do the job on the references that are in front of the committee now, or indeed reference itself, with its very tight reporting date, bearing in mind that the holiday season will intervene during the currency of the inquiry.

The secretariat of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Standing Committee last year received an award of acknowledgment from the Department of the Senate for the heavy workload that they undertook during the previous 12 months and during the life of the previous parliament. I commend all the members of the secretariat for the enormous amount of work that they did: 15‐ to 18‐hour days were not unknown to them. I made a vow that when I became chair of the committee, I would not repeat the situation that developed last year. But, unfortunately, if the Senate determines that this reference goes ahead now in this way, that workload would have to be repeated in order to accommodate the workload that we would have on our plate.

For the edification of honourable senators let me explain just what we are doing. In the legislation committee, we have a reference on the optimal role and function of the Administrative Review Council. We have a reference on the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill 1996. We have a reference on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3) 1996. That is just for the legislation committee. If we add the euthanasia bill to that, we would probably get to it in January.

BREAK.PARA: On the references committee, we are concluding a reference on the rights and obligations of the media. We have two separate references on the payment of a minister's legal costs. We have another reference on the need to protect Australian citizens against discrimination on vilification on the grounds of their sexuality and transgender identity. We are concluding that reference and we will be going through a chairman's draft very shortly. Submissions for the inquiry into the Australian legal aid system conclude in a matter of weeks and we will shortly be starting a program on that reference with some dates already allocated in January for public hearings.

I am very firmly of the view that the Legal and Constitutional Committee is not the committee that this bill ought to be referred to. I think in the first instance that perhaps a committee dealing with matters of health and palliative care ought to be the committee that would look at it. There are legal and constitutional matters connected and concerned with the bill and which the bill impacts upon. So for that reason it might be worthwhile for the Senate to give consideration to the formation of a select committee to look at all the matters that the bill deals with or impinges upon.

I am sure that the Senate could ensure that all interested members and all interests in the bill could be accommodated in the formulation and composition of the committee. I am not so sure that that can be accommodated by referring it to a standing committee or to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. There are, as the Senate would know, six members of the committee, three who come from the government, two from the opposition and one nomination from the Democrats. There is provision for participating members, so every member of the Senate could—if they wanted to—participate in the hearings.

But at the conclusion of it all, if the committee was of a view to put forward recommendations, how would you handle it? I cannot see, when all the major parties have determined this matter by conscience vote, how the committee at the conclusion of the inquiry could make recommendations on a conscience vote. I think what we need is some time out during the course of the day to discuss this matter on an informal basis. I have found in my experience in this place that most of the better decisions have been made on this informal basis. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak on this matter but as Senator McKiernan has mentioned the role of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee I feel compelled to put to the Senate some aspects of the matter. In relation to the workload of the committee it is true that the committee has two bills before it but hearing dates are in place for those two bills and the reporting dates are set at 2 and 3 December this year. I see no reason why those targets cannot be met. The reference to the Administrative Review Council is not urgent—the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) has said that—and it could be given a lower priority. So that takes care of those three matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to references, the sexuality reference is at the stage where a chairman's draft is under consideration and, over the break, committee members no doubt will have an opportunity to look at the draft. No more hearings are listed so that reference is in hand. It does not, I submit, pose a great problem to the committee. Of the other two references that Senator McKiernan mentioned, one relating to the media and the other to payment of a minister's costs, the payment of a minister's costs has had one previous report in relation thereto and the remainder of that reference is of no great moment as far as work is concerned. In relation to the media there have been prior hearings held and a report delivered. Again, I put it to the Senate that that reference does not attract any great degree of urgency.

I would agree that the legal aid reference is an important reference. Two hearing dates have been set in January for that and the reporting date, I believe, is not until April next year so there is adequate time for the committee to address that. So I believe the references are all in hand. I do agree with Senator McKiernan that the committee has a heavy workload—it always has had. I recall that in 1993 the committee had just over a week to report on the Native Title Bill and it covered five hearing days in that time—and did a very good job.

In summary, the logistics are sufficiently in hand to address this matter. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee is a standing committee which allows participating members to participate in these sorts of references. I think that is an excellent process. It would allow any senators interested in partaking in the inquiry to do so. This committee is a standing committee which is set to look at legal and constitutional issues. If you look at the selection of bills report you will see that the reference touches on legal matters, the Northern Territory legislation, the Commonwealth legislation and the constitutional aspects of that. I submit it is the appropriate committee for this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Ellison. Like Senator Ellison, I did not intend to speak in this debate but because it is being debated I will speak and foreshadow that I wish to move an amendment to the motion on the report. I agree with Senator Ellison that the Legal and Constitutional Committee is the appropriate committee. I make it clear that I am not opposed to the reference of the bill to the committee. The thing that concerns me—and I think that honourable senators on reflection will agree with this—is that this bill, which is a tad more controversial than most bills, has not been given sufficient consideration in terms of this reference.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there should be a more appropriate discussion between all parties in the Senate who have an interest—Senator Harradine, the Greens, the Democrats and everyone else—in this bill which will be subject to a very rare procedure in this parliament; a free vote, a conscience vote by everyone. I think a far more appropriate way of dealing with the matter would be to defer just for a short time consideration of what should be done with the selection of this bill. I am not suggesting that the whole report be deferred with the other bills, just this bill.

Senator Ellison rightly said that there are many aspects of this bill. It is not simply a question of euthanasia. For me, as a Territorian and as a Territorian who was privileged to spend 10 years as a member in the Northern Territory parliament before I came down here, I have to express my anger—and I do hope that honourable senators will understand this, because of that background—with the arrogance of some of our southern colleagues. One in particular little twerp from Tasmania jumped up yesterday and had the effrontery—and it was not you, Senator Harradine; I know, Senator Harradine that you will understand that I could have taken this comment—

TALK.START.PARA: —Angel's image.

—Tasmania being the most politically over‐represented place on the face of the earth, I could have taken this criticism from someone from New South Wales or Western Australia. Yesterday reference was made in here to the parliament in which I served. But it was a bit much to hear that reference by a senator from a state with barely double the population of the Northern Territory and six times the representation here in the Senate. I heard Senator Abetz say in here yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly only exists by virtue of the federal parliament's goodwill. What the parliament gives, it can also take away.

Adding that to the appalling statement by Mr Andrews when he led the debate introducing this bill we are now discussing into the House of Representatives when he said, `Territories have no rights, only obligations', I agree with Senator Ellison that this bill does have aspects that go beyond the all‐important question of euthanasia.

I say again because I think Senator Harradine was out of the chamber when I initially said this: I am not opposed to the reference to a committee; nor am I opposed to the reference to this committee because it is the appropriate committee. But a little more discussion over the next 24 hours would solve the problem.
I intend to move, Mr Acting Deputy President—and the clerks in their usual professional fashion can clean up the words—an amendment to this effect:
That consideration of this bill—
that is the euthanasia bill only, and this is an amendment to your report, Senator Panizza—
be made an order of the day after the conclusion of the debate on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Senator Harradine, if that is not considered appropriate, then I would ask for some helpful suggestions from senators with great experience, like yourself, to at least bring it back next week. So that an opportunity can be given—
—I was told two hours just a while ago.
—Yes, well, whatever—later today then. To progress debate—and I am pleased that I am a member of a chamber when debate can still effect things—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add "except the recommendation relating to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, and consideration of that recommendation be an order of the day for a later hour of the day.
I do so rather than determine this issue now.

As someone who has an intense interest in this matter, I have not had sufficient opportunity to talk to my colleagues about this reference. Before a final decision is made in here, I would like the opportunity to participate in how this bill should be dealt with which I have not had so far. So I would move that amendment for a later hour today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: is Senator Collins's amendment tantamount to an adjournment motion?
—I am happy with that.
—Senator Harradine, my advice is that it merely means a deferral of that one recommendation, so it is not an adjournment motion. The debate can continue on the motion and the amendment.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, this is one of the most important and fundamental questions to be dealt with by this parliament this year. I appreciate that the government has an important program to be dealt with by the parliament this year consistent with all of the issues the government announced both following the election and arising from the budget process. Nevertheless, all parties and members of this Senate accept that the essential issue of dealing with euthanasia is, properly, a conscience matter for full and appropriate debate and consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware that in recent weeks the House of Representatives has agonised over the euthanasia bill. But, to a large degree, the debate has been rushed in the House of Representatives. Following an initial short debate in the other chamber, the bill is now being dealt with by the Main Committee. The Senate is now being asked how it would like to process additional and further consideration of this important, non‐party political and major social legislation.

As Senator Bob Collins very rightly acknowledged, this issue has major import not only for the Northern Territory which both he and I represent but also for the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island. I share Senator Collins's apprehension about the views of other members of parliament who have sought to denigrate the rights of Australian citizens who live in those three territories by patronisingly telling us territory residents that we ought not to be considered on the same basis as every other Australian citizen, that we ought cop it sweet and accept imposed rules and views because the Commonwealth has a legislative and constitutional obligation with regard to territories.

This bill goes to the core of the individual rights of Australian citizens no matter where they live. I appreciate the diversity of views and opinions on the core issue of euthanasia, which we will have to debate and which we should, very properly, consider in a committee process. Like Senator Collins, I can appreciate that the process of dealing with this in the legal and constitutional committee will mean appropriate consideration. I have been assured by the committee chairman, Senator Ellison, that the committee will travel and visit as required the territories to get the views and opinions of people.

Whilst a reporting date of February will be an onerous task, it will also be important to recognise that the committee will then look at the constitutional, moral and ethical issues of euthanasia on which people like Senator Harradine, Senator Boswell or Senator McGauran would have different perspectives to that of my own and a number of other people.

On the issue relating to territory and state rights, I find it incomprehensible that any chamber of parliament should not appropriately recognise other parliaments. That was very adequately demonstrated here in this Senate by the presentation of a remonstrance only several days ago by the parliament of the Northern Territory and by a letter of concern from the parliament of Norfolk Island.

So it is important that the Senate give consideration to an appropriate and proper committee reference and representation because of those constitutional issue to which we in the Senate have an absolute fundamental obligation. The House of Representatives did not take up that challenge or that opportunity. They walked away from their responsibility in that area. This is an important issue. I want to see the social adjustment issues of euthanasia properly canvassed by the committee. I do want to see the constitutional issues taken into account. I want to see the issues relating particularly to Aboriginal indigenous people of Australia properly canvassed and recognised, and that can only properly be done by the committee in this instance. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to have business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 and 2 taken together. In doing so, I indicate to the Senate that I will be asking for the question on parts of notice of motion No. 1 to be put separately.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 and 2 be taken together.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1—That regulations 4, 10, 11, 13.3, 13.5 to 13.9, 14 to 37, 47 to 49, 51, 53 to 55, 74, 77.16, 77.19, 78, 85, 119 and 144 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 211 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.
No. 2—That the Immigration (Education) Charge Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 213 and made under the Immigration (Education) Charge Act 1992 , be disallowed.

Much has been said recently about the issue of migration. This has been triggered by one maverick from Queensland, the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). She has lit a bushfire and contributed nothing positively to a very critical debate. As days goes by, we see that she has contributed very little because she has no capacity to contribute much. On all grounds of her contribution she has been wrong.

When we look at migration and Australia's history of migration, we realise that the immigration program that consecutive governments in this country have presided over has been our greatest single achievement as a nation. Our record is one that we should not shy from. Over 50 years of planned migration, we have brought five million people to this country from 200 or so different ethnic backgrounds. It has been successful. People have come here without the English language or skills. We have found that, very soon after their arrival, they make a fair fist of their new lives here. Already we can talk about one million small businesses in Australia started by non-English speaking migrants.

In terms of societal harmony, internationally we are recognised as being unparalleled in the way that Australians from all walks of life come together, live together and get on with each other. What we have seen in recent days is the bushfire of racism lit by Pauline Hanson having debilitating effects on a society which, for over 15 years, we have been very keen to nurture in a very positive way. Migrants have not only brought an infusion of energy to this country but they have changed this country forever. They have changed how we see ourselves and how others see us.

When ignorant critics run the line that multiculturalism is a negative in our society, we should always note that Australia has from the start had a multicultural component to it. We have always been a multicultural nation. Be it the diverse communities, languages and cultures of Aboriginal Australians or the first settlers, we were always destined to have to rely on population growth. Because of our size, we were always destined to be a country of migration and diverse migration sources. For instance, our constitution entrenches respect for diversity and, you could say, multiculturalism. Freedom of religion together with the equality of treatment of people are two important planks in our constitution that ensure that, when people have their religion respected, their cultural heritage is respected.

We have always been, in composition, culturally diverse and we have always had entrenched in our system of constitutional law respect for cultural diversity. It is part of our fair go ethos. That is a critical thing to say at this point. You can have all the laws you want, but it is that fair go ethos, a fair go for other people, that has been quite critical to the way Australians treat each other.

We should also note the economics of migration. At a time when people are saying that migrants take jobs, we should look at the fact that historically, when we have been in recessions and economic downturns, we have relied on migrants to stimulate growth. We have also seen over recent years, for instance, at a time when there has been high unemployment, that those regions that have had population growth are the ones that have had least unemployment.

When we are recognised as being the most successful migrant country in the world and we compare ourselves with countries like the USA and Canada, I think we should ask ourselves why we have had that degree of success. That leads directly to the discussion of some of the motions we are moving today and some of the regulations that the opposition is seeking to bowl over. We have been most successful because we have had a very deliberate policy of inclusion. We have built on the dedication of migrants to set up a new life and we provide for them a springboard to do so.

Inclusion means quick and easy access to citizenship and the security that citizenship provides to people. Security gives them a platform to start new lives, far from the fear of persecution—persecution from which at least half a million Australians have directly fled. Citizenship, and reaction to it, is symbolic of a two‐way commitment. For us, continuation of a policy of ready access in a non‐discriminatory way to citizenship is quite critical.

Our inclusive approach also embodies inclusiveness in a social sense. Family migration has been critical to the success of migration in this country. People need infrastructure and support—emotional, physical and capital—when they migrate. Nothing can be more critical to them than having their family around them to support them. Family migration, particularly spousal migration, has been a critical part of our migration policy, to the extent that there has been a bipartisan approach to recognise the sanctity of family and spousal migration.

We are concerned that in the regulations that are before us today the government has ditched one of the critical platforms of migration policy over the years—that is, a policy that recognises the right for husband and wife, for spouses, to be together.The moves here are moves that we will object to. They are moves that are contrary to the Sex Discrimination Act and to international covenants. More importantly, they are contrary to the formation of successful migration through respect for the base family—the nuclear family, for instance, in this case.

We recognise that the role of communities is central to support structures. We also recognise that the government has a role to play in terms of its social justice agenda. We recognise that economic policy, not immigration policy, causes ghettoes. Australians have been prepared over years, over decades, to put an investment into people, to put an investment into our migrants. We recognise that, by putting in that investment at a difficult time, Australia as a nation will benefit. The history of migration in this country shows that we have always benefited from that investment.

Inclusiveness also means that we do not act in a racially discriminatory way. We should all feel that we have an equal part of the action in our society. The debate that Pauline Hanson has triggered has basically done what she has set out to claim we should not have in our society—she has divided it.

I think one of the real problems we have had in respect of this is that there has been a failure of leadership. Any leader worth his or her salt in this society should have realised seven or eight weeks ago that if he did not, as other leaders have done in the past, stamp on the views, argue against them and rebut them solidly, he or she would have had to respond seven or eight weeks down the track, they would have to respond in a position of weakness and a lot of damage would have been done in the meantime. I think it is to the eternal fault of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, as a leader, that he has not been prepared to do this in the past.

As I say, inclusiveness means being treated equally. One of the real concerns we have with these regulations is in the family reunion area. Family reunion, as I said, is critical to migration. There has to be a sense that people can equally sponsor their families. How can you justify a situation where, if these regulations are not knocked off today, some families with an English speaking background can have their parents, grandparents, brothers and sisters allowed into this country, sharing houses with them, while, across the road, next‐door or in the same street, people from a non‐English speaking background would be denied the opportunity to have their families live with them? It is iniquitous, it is discriminatory and it is racially discriminatory.

It is a reintroduction of the old English language test, the old dictation test. Through the mechanisms that this government is pursuing by adding the factor of English language points to the concessional family category, you are denying many people from a non‐English speaking background the opportunity to come to Australia.

The impact of introducing English language points for the concessional family category will be deep and it will be recognised within Australian society and outside Australia. For instance, the projections I have seen, which are quite reliable and which the department has made available to us through the estimates process, indicate that because of this regulation the number of people from a non‐English speaking background coming in under the concessional family category will decrease dramatically. Whereas at the moment the figure is 63 per cent, it will go down to just over 30 per cent. Migration from places like Beijing and Shanghai in the concessional family category will be halved; from Ho Chi Minh City, it will be halved; from Beirut, one in five in the concessional family category who came in the past will not be able to come in the future. From Athens—and here we are talking particularly of people from other parts of Europe coming through Athens—50 per cent of non‐English speaking migrants in the concessional category who otherwise would qualify and have qualified in the past will not be able to come. The number from Belgrade will be cut by two‐thirds in terms of the concessional family category.

With this particular regulation the government is introducing discrimination into our migration program. When we look at the figures—and we will be tracking these figures very closely, as we have already in the estimates process—it can be found that John Howard said in 1988 that he wanted to moderate the flow of Asian migration. And the introduction of the English language in the concessional family category does that. Eight years later he has found a way, not just against Asian migration but against non‐English speaking migration from all parts of the world. That is our critical objection to this aspect of the regulations.

I might also say that in just a few short months this government have made a complete botch of the migration program. Not only have they eroded the spousal part of family migration, which is a critical aspect of migration, but they have also brought in discrimination between families. They have made the program almost impossible to manage. This is now being realised throughout the community and, can I say in regard to the discriminatory aspect, throughout the region.

On migration, those opposite have responded to base populism in our community; they have kicked this stalking‐horse around the community for electoral advantage with an eye to the polls. But the reality is that a critical part of the Australian migration program is now unworkable because of this response to base populism. Any government worth their salt should not respond in this way. They should factor in the views of the community, as we always do in our consultations on the migration program. At the same time the government should have a program that is manageable, but this minister has failed in that respect.

Let us put these regulations in context. We have allowed much of what the government has proposed by way of regulation but, where there has been a breach of policy commitment or where there has been no disclosure before the election, then we seek the right to overturn the regulations that reflect those breaches of commitment and that dishonesty through deliberately withholding issues from the public before the election. For instance, we have accepted the extension of the six‐month waiting period for new arrivals to two years which the coalition announced before the election. With issues which were not covered by their policy before the election, obviously we seek to reject them.

We have accepted increased sureties under the assurance of support provision, but we object to the government double dipping by excluding people from benefits in the first two years while at the same time trying to require assurance of support against the likelihood of drawing on social security benefits from which they are excluded. We have accepted the government's authority in the decision to control the size of the program and the composition of the program, except where it conflicts with basic human rights such as family reunions in particular.

In respect of family reunions, can I remind the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) here, and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), the minister responsible, that it is an amazing development in Australian migration policy for him to seek to have the power to cap the number of spouse visas granted in any one year. I remind Mr Ruddock of what he had to say about capping spousal visas in 1989 when amendments were introduced to make it perfectly plain and to remove the possibility of doubt that these visa classes would not be capped. Mr Ruddock said:

I regard it as absolutely unconscionable for a government to say half way through the year, `We have enough spouses in now, we are going to close off that category and no more people in that category can come to Australia—no more husbands and wives, no more dependent children, or aged parents'. I am glad that the Minister has made the decision to exclude those groups.
We will try to hold Mr Ruddock to that as well.

We have accepted the decision to raise substantially visa application fees, although there are sound reasons for criticising these measures. We have accepted the introduction of a two‐year probationary visa for offshore spouse applications, and we support this being applied to offshore de facto spouse applicants. We have accepted the introduction of 20 additional points for English language skills for the skill independent category. It has now been decided not to proceed with the disallowance of regulations 13.5 to 13.9.

But we are concerned about a number of critical issues. We are concerned about the regulation that seeks to amend the balance of family test requiring a parent to be sponsored by a majority of the children of that parent in Australia. We believe that the existing requirement of at least 50 per cent provides sufficiently rigorous control. Any further tightening may appear to be minimal, but it makes it impossible for families who have two children but only one child in Australia to sponsor parents. It is insensitive to cultural obligations. Let us keep in mind that quite often, if not always in these cases, they do not impact financially upon the Australian taxpayer as there are in place preclusions from social security and non‐refundable health charges payable in advance in Australia.

In respect of regulations 10 and 11, we are concerned and we object to including in the schedule of assurances of support a widows allowance. The widows allowance quite often would be claimed because of a situation—obviously not anticipated before the person came to this country—where a person becomes a widow.

As to regulation 13.3, the New Zealand provisions, this regulation deletes the families of New Zealand citizens from schedule 1. The effect of this will be that New Zealand citizens migrating to Australia will not be able to sponsor members of the immediate family if such members themselves are not New Zealand citizens. To accept such an amendment would be inconsistent with our opposition to the general principle that only Australian citizens can sponsor a spouse, dependent child or parent and so on. As a consequence we oppose regulation 13.3 together with regulations 20, 47 and 55. We do not believe there needs to be a precondition of citizenship before one can nominate for migration such a close family member, whether from New Zealand or any other part of the world.

Regulations 14 to 19 seek to introduce the requirement of citizenship to sponsor preferential family. This provision is a breach of a pre‐election commitment. Quite often, Senator Short made it very clear that this sort of requirement would not be brought in. Let us face it: one of the major reasons for this provision is to target Chinese migration—the parents and families of those who manage to qualify under the 1 November decision of the previous government. It is those people who will suffer the most because of this particular provision. We do not believe that this provision should be pursued because of the impact it will have.

We believe that it would be wrong to attach citizenship with such basic rights. We have always taken the approach that in Australia citizenship should be a willing choice; it should not be forced on people. This regulation forces people to make a commitment to this country whereas, in the past, the concept of willing choice has been most successful.

The government is looking at establishing a council on citizenship. On occasions, the government has expressed the view that eligibility for citizenship should be extended from the current two years and that factors, such as a high level of functional English, should be among the criteria for eligibility. We believe that such developments would be an unhealthy deviation from our approach to the creation of our society over recent years.

There are further problems on the horizon if any parliament is prepared to accept regulations 14 to 19. Those regulations are a breach of an election commitment. They are discriminatory in their application. More fundamentally, it would be wrong to attach citizenship with such basic rights, such as permanent resident status which, in the past, has entitled a person to a lifetime stay in Australia and to sponsorship. We do not think we should take things to the extent the government is proposing with these regulations.

Let us keep in mind that, to do so, would impose undue hardship on many people—people who have made a commitment to this country but who, for one reason or another, do not want to lose the rights of another country. In the absence of a clean approach to dual citizenship, they would be in fear of losing rights of inheritance and the like if they were forced to take up citizenship here. If this particular provision were to go ahead, those people would be denied the capacity to reunite with spouses or dependent children for an intolerable amount of time. For a range of grounds, we oppose this provision.

Another aspect of regulations 14 to 19 is that they make it compulsory to demand an assurance of support whereas, in the past, it has been discretionary and non‐compulsory. Already, people are having problems with that provision and those regulations. Already families are being separated. One particular case, which has come to my attention in recent days, is that of a Tasmanian woman who married a US citizen on 25 June this year and is now seeking to bring her husband to Australia to begin family life.

Under these new regulations, that woman is required to provide an assurance of support for her husband, something never before demanded with respect to husbands and wives of Australian citizens. This woman is a qualified teacher but, because she is pregnant, her child being due next March, she is not acceptable to this government, she is not acceptable to this department, for the purpose of giving an assurance of support. She is not in a position to sponsor her husband because her income flow and other factors deny her eligibility to give an assurance of support.

This woman's only other close relative, her mother, also is not able to sign an assurance of support. She is retired but, although she is prepared to pledge equity in her home, she is not in a position to meet the government's requirements for a person giving an assurance of support. These are the sorts of cases that will come up time and time again, not in their fives or tens or hundreds but in their thousands, if this government's proposals to deny people the capacity to sponsor their spouses go ahead.

This is the sort of divided society that the government is creating, a society where people cannot bring in their spouses, where Australian citizens cannot bring in their spouses. As I said, this is one instance but, if the government's provisions were to go ahead, making it more rigorous and more difficult for people to sponsor spouses, we will be hearing of similar cases through our media night after night.

PARA.BREAK: The government says that we need to do this because there has been a blow‐out in the number of spouses coming to Australia and rorting the system. But when asked about this by us—not once but a number of times—in the estimates committee process, all that the officials representing the minister for immi gration could point to by way of evidence were 108 cases out of a 40,000 intake over two years. Fair dinkum, that is a pretty low number—low to the extent that the previous government was actually looking at ways of facilitating entry.

SPEECH.PARA: If the government can point to only 108 cases being pursued out of an intake of 40,000 over two years in order to justify this inept, incompetent policy, they have to look at it again. They have to revisit this policy because it is not just words on paper, it is people's lives that they are affecting here. They are going right to the heart of family migration via an incompetent and inept policy, a policy that demands of people that they be separated despite the fact that a partner is an Australian citizen. It makes it impossible for them, as is the case with this Tasmanian woman, to unite with their spouses.

That woman is in real danger of having this child while her husband is out of the country. Why? Because the government's silly, inept and ill thought out policies will deny her access to her husband. These are the sorts of objections we have heard—real life objections—to the government's proposals and regulations. That is why we say that the Senate has a responsibility to look very keenly at them and to look at the incompetence of the minister in pursing policies like it.

This is one reason why, in the past, we have had spousal migration and sponsorship dependent on permanent residence and not on citizenship. I say to the government: go back, you are going the wrong way; think it through again and come back with a new set of proposals. What we have heard of today with this Tasmanian woman we will see often in the future unless the government reconsiders this stupid policy.

Regulations 48, 49, 51, 53 and 54 introduce citizenship requirements, compulsory assurance of support for onshore children, onshore aged parents, onshore families and onshore spouses, extended eligibility for temporary visas, and so on. What is the logic in it? What are they trying to achieve?

BREAK.PARA: Are you trying to keep kids separated from their parents? Are you trying to artificially keep parents separated from their adult children? I am sure the department has been driven to this by a policy from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), a policy driven by pollsters and a policy which demands of him to beat the migrant can as much as he can. What is the impact of it? You are going to separate families.

This is a government that was elected on the basis of family policy, and this is a government that will die in migration policy because the impact of that policy will be to keep families separate. This policy, as I said earlier, will deny this Tasmanian woman the presence of her husband at the birth of her child. That is just one example of the direct implication of your policies and your regulations.

We could go on. We can look at regulations 21 to 36. There have already been massive inroads to the humanitarian program. It has already been cut. There has been some fanciful argument about cuts from what it was expected to be, and so on. But the reality is that there are 3,000 less humanitarian cases coming in this year than there were last year. So, what do you want to do? You now want to include in the humanitarian program families that are sponsored by refugees and special humanitarian visa holders. It is another way of cutting our commitment to international humanitarian situations and crises.

PARA.BREAK: Let us go to the issue of English language points. There is so much to talk about in terms of these regulations. I talked earlier about the impact of the English language on the concessional category—the English language requirement and points for English language capacity. What you will do there is not just keep non-English speaking people out, but you will lower the standard for those with English language. Your program numbers are closely the same. By denying those of non-English background access to the program, there will be more places available for those of English background. So, if you are of English background, you will get in with little more than secondary school educa tion. If you are not of English background, you are going to need a lot more than that.

BREAK.PARA: I will tell you something: the history of migration here and the history of commerce in the world is that you do not need to know English to make a buck. You do not need to know English to be a successful business person. If you go through the whole raft of successful Australian business entrepreneurs, so many of them came here without English. But you will be discriminating against those people in the future.

Regulation 144—I am skipping a few because we are running out of time—is particularly offensive. It seeks to make citizenship requirement and balance of family test retrospective to 3 July 1996. It is retrospective. It does so in a contrived and twisted route, hoping to get around section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act, which provides that these regulations cannot be retrospective. Disallowance will ensure that this retrospectivity cannot occur.

I will finish on this particular point: nothing has been more critical to migration than government support; and nothing is more critical in terms of government support than English language. When you look at DEETYA and the immigration department together, this government is spending less in this budget on English language services than the previous government did—though it came in with the commitment to spend more. You have ripped the guts out of English language programs in DEETYA and, as a consequence, migrants are not going to get the critical service they need in terms of English language services.

At the same time, you want to raise English language charges. You are going to rip a lot more money out of them—from $2,200 concessional charge this year—for which 90 per cent of users of the programs are eligible—to $4,400 on 1 October, and $5,500 on 1 January 1997, if you get your legislation through in respect of that. Let us be realistic about this. If you are dinkum about creating a harmonious society, you should not make it more difficult for people to access English language programs, and you should not be ripping from them, at a time when they are pretty low on resources, the resources they need for those programs.

I fear that the directions taken by this government on migration are going to be quite destructive to the sort of society we have built together over the last 50 years. Malcolm Fraser would not have embarked down this road. That is the final charge you can lay against this minister and this Prime Minister—that Malcolm Fraser would not have touched this with a 10-foot barge pole. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate unduly on this matter, but it is a very important matter. It is particularly important in the context of the much wider disgraceful debate that is happening in certain sections of our community—a debate that started prior to the election and, unfortunately, was fuelled by some comments by various candidates for political office during the election. It is a debate that, unfortunately, has continued since the election with the election of some members to the parliament of Australia and comments that they have made since they have been elected.

SPEECH.PARA: The community is debating immigration in Australia. I do not have a problem with that. In fact, in all of my time as a member of parliament, I have encouraged debate about immigration and what happens to migrants when they come to this country. I make those comments for the very simple reason that there will be people in the parliament who will welcome the changes that are foreshadowed with these regulations being brought in by the government. They will indeed be applauding them because of the impact that the regulations will have on various migrants who arrive here.

I want to make the point very strongly that the opposition is not standing in the way of all of the changes that the government is proposing in the area of immigration. For example, they have proposed an extension of the six-month waiting period for certain benefits which new arrivals receive. We are not opposing those matters which they gave notice of prior to the election, when they said in their policy statements, `We are going to institute these measures if we are elected.' We are not opposing these measures. Those measures were subject to scrutiny by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee earlier in the year in a report that I believe was tabled in August, and which has sat there since then. Indeed, the bill has sat on the Notice Paper; it has not been brought on for debate.

We are not opposing certain measures that were contained in that bill. But the government saw its opportunity to expand upon the two-year waiting period, without any form of consultation with the community, and we have indicated our opposition to those additional measures.

By our opposition to the measures and regulations that Senator Bolkus has alluded to, we are clearly stating that we support families. Not only are we getting up and mouthing the words, `We support families,' but we are turning those words into actions by speaking against the regulations and voting for the disallowance of those regulations that attack migrants in our community.

I do not want to delay the Senate unduly, but I want to emphasise the last point Senator Bolkus raised in his excellent contribution to this debate which related to the education charge. The concessional rate which applied under the previous government was based on a charge of $2,005, for which 90 per cent of users of the program were eligible. The regulation, as foreshadowed by the government, would withdraw that concessional rate. As of 1 October, the rate rose to $4,405. If the amendments to the Immigration (Education) Charge Act go through, from 1 January 1997, which is not long away now, that fee will rise to $5,500, which is an increase from $2,205 to $5,500. That is quite an extraordinary increase by any measure.

Taking that with the coalition's attempt to remove all support for new arrivals for the first two years after they come to this country seems fundamentally misguided. The community has told the government that it is misguided. If we are to have a migration program—and I certainly support that—it is important to make sure that people are able to successfully make the transition from their previous home to their new home in this country. To do that, some people will need access to education programs—programs to assist with English language skills and programs to assist them enter the labour market.

Any short‐term savings that are made in this area are likely to create a long-term problem if the result is that new arrivals find themselves unable to make a successful transition and therefore become long-term losers who are alienated from mainstream society and are welfare dependent. That does not seem like the recipe for a sensible approach. These regulation amendments would result in the diminution of settlement support. It would further disadvantage people from non-English speaking posts from having the opportunity to enter the work force and to participate in this society generally.

This is inconsistent with the coalition's pre‐election promises to improve access to English language programs. The coalition described them as the glue that holds Australia together. Senator Short, who is in the chamber, would well recall those words. I recall Senator Short being on stage in north Perth during the election campaign and enunciating that they are the glue that holds Australia together.

Everybody knows that you won the election and we lost it. You went into the election campaign with commitments that are not now being fulfilled with these regulations which were enunciated in the budget. Those commitments are not being fulfilled. You stand condemned because you have not sought to fulfil those commitments. I was going to say some kind words about Senator Vanstone, but I do not think that we will re‐open that argument again. I commend to the Senate the motion moved by Senator Bolkus and call on all honourable senators to stand up for families and vote according when the division is called.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is somewhat unprecedented and misguided. It is the first time that a government's migration policy arrangements, since they were put into legislative form, have been the subject of sustained and constant attack by an opposition. It is worth mentioning at the commencement of the debate that Senator Bolkus has indicated that the opposition accepts the overall immigration target that the new government has established and yet refuses to allow the government to implement measures to actually achieve that target. In other words, he wants to have the best of both worlds.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an impossible task to say to a government, `Yes we agree that your modest reduction in the immigration intake is reasonable and yes we agree that your target of 74,000 is not unreasonable, but no we will not let you implement measures to achieve that target nor do we have any proposals as to how you should achieve that target.' In my view, that is incompetence in the extreme. If you say that 74,000 is a reasonable target—and I think there is agreement on that—and you want to block these measures and stop an elected government implementing a program, the net result of which you agree with, what do you want done? Where are your proposals to achieve a target of 74,000?

Before moving to some remarks that I would like the Democrats to pay some attention to, I would like to make two remarks relating to Ms Hanson. Senator Bolkus chose to yet again give Ms Hanson the prominence that, in my view, she does not deserve. It is a frequent tactic of the opposition to despise her views but nonetheless keep raising them and keep giving her opportunities to get coverage. He neglected to mention something that I think should be mentioned—that is, that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when Leader of the Opposition ensured that Ms Hanson was disendorsed as a Liberal candidate.

That is a serious move to make during an election campaign. When you have got an endorsed candidate you cannot put another one in; you are stuck with that person. There is no clearer a statement by a leader than to say, `That person is not standing under our banner. We would rather lose the seat than have that person in our party.' So let's not come in here and pretend that the Prime Minister endorses Ms Hanson. I do not believe such a thing has ever happened in the Labor Party—I have not bothered to check the history—but it certainly stands out as a most unusual event during a campaign.

We did not know whether we were going to win the election. Everybody here knows this. We hoped we were going to win, but in 1993 we thought we were going to win and did not. In 1996 we were very cautious. We had no idea that we would win by the huge majority that we did. Sure, a week or so before the election we thought we were going to win but, as I said, we had thought that before. There was no certainty about the numbers. In those circumstances—not these circumstances now, where we have a very significant majority—where it was not sure, the then Leader of the Opposition said, `That person is not standing under our banner, out. We would rather lose that seat than have someone with those views purporting to be a Liberal.' I do not think you can make a clearer statement as leader of an opposition. Yet still, members opposite come back and invite the Prime Minister to constantly address Ms Hanson's misguided remarks seriatim, so that every time she says something she gets on the front page of the newspapers. That is what happens when a Prime Minister responds to you—you get on the front page.

This has been a misguided approach by the Labor Party. I do not believe that Ms Hanson's views represent the Labor Party's views, and I certainly know they do not represent my party's views. If you want to keep giving her publicity, keep asking the Prime Minister to respond to her. If you want to use her politically, you keep doing it. I think that needs to be put on the record.

PARA.BREAK: Overnight I delved down to the depths of my goodwill to try to find something positive that I could say to Senator Bolkus with respect to this whole matter of these regulations. I had not actually found anything to say until he spoke and raised the matter of Ms Hanson. I do not mind saying that I think it was Senator Bolkus, as the former minister in this area and I think now the shadow minister, who was asked a view of Ms Hanson and who said, `I think she'd be better sticking to fish and chips.' A certain degree of warmth came over me towards Senator Bolkus on that occasion, and I freely admit it has not re turned since. Nonetheless, I thought at the time that that was pretty well spot-on.

SPEECH.PARA: Having dealt with that matter, let me come back to the point about the migration program. As I understand it, the Labor opposition agrees with this target but is simply saying to the government, `We're not going to let you implement it. We are going to say no to this box and dice. You are out of the ballpark, you cannot have it.' The consequences of that are to stay with the program as is.

We are seeking a modest reduction in the migration program, from about 83,000 to about 74,000. What we are seeking to do is restore the balance between the skilled and family reunion categories. We understand that Labor is not going to support us. But we do hope that the Democrats and the two Green parties—as I now understand we are to refer to the Greens—and Senator Harradine consider this seriously.

I will address the Democrat's policies for a moment. If the Democrats were not to support this, if they were to prevent the government from delivering a program of 74,000, it would seem to be inconsistent with their own immigration policy which, as I understand it, is a policy of net zero migration. I further understand that this policy has been the subject of three separate ballots of the membership and has roughly 80 per cent support. The Democrat's Internet home page indicates that until a sustainable population can be achieved, a low level of immigration should be continued. It goes on to say:
. . . with the annual number of immigrants (including refugees) not exceeding the number of permanent departures of the previous year. Refugees should be given the highest priority in immigration.
The National President of the Australian Democrats, Tony Fountain, in a letter to the editor just recently, said:
The policy of the Australian Democrats on immigration is, in essence, that our numbers coming into the country should equal in any one year those of the people leaving.

To fulfil this policy it would mean a program of just below 30,000. The government is seeking to implement a program of 74,000, and the Democrat's policy would lead one to a program of a mere 30,000. So it is difficult to see how the Democrats could endorse a policy that would lead you to an immigration intake of 30,000, yet prevent a government shifting from 83,000 down to 74,000. It is very hard to see how that could be realistically justified.

It is at the moment unrealistic to try to shift to anything like the Democrat's policy. To deliver a program of 30,000, you need to give, they say, a priority to refugee entrants. We have 6,000 refugee entrants, 14,000 for humanitarian and refugee entrants. There are 12,000 New Zealanders seeking permanent residence in Australia, which is unregulated entry, which leaves a balance of only 12,000 for the rest of the program.

Last year there were some 33,500 spouses and fiances in the program. Without the measures this government has proposed, these numbers will not be contained. So without even the spousal measures, the Democrats are going to exceed their own policy commitment by roughly 20,000. Under the Democrats policy, not even all the spouses and fiances could be accommodated, because they want to give a preference to the refugee and humanitarian intake. That is an important point for the Democrats to consider.

Under the Democrats proposal, assuming last year's level of demand, each year 12,500 spouses and fiances would not be able to enter Australia. Within a mere five-year period, there would be a queue of 107,500 spouses and fiances waiting to be reunited with their partners. For a program of 30,000, it would be necessary to abolish the categories of dependent and adopted children, parents, brothers and sisters, last remaining relatives, special need relatives and all the skilled categories, including business migrants.

I have tried to indicate to the Democrats why we do not think we could realistically move to your policy as it now stands. We do ask the Democrats to reconsider your policy—that is, no more in than leave. That would ask you to endorse a policy of about 30,000. We are asking to shift from 83,000 to 74,000. We ask you to bear that in mind.

I come back to an earlier point I made. The opposition says that this is a reasonable target to move to, but it refuses to allow us to implement that target and does not come up with an alternative implementation plan to achieve it. The irony is that the measures the opposition is seeking to remove are required because of its own mismanagement of the migration program. The further irony is that Senator Bolkus is the one who, as minister, presided over the mismanagement of the program.

What has the new government inherited? We have inherited the legacy of a migration program which is in what state? The migration program has become dominated by the family stream, and we believe community support for that domination has been lost—not community support for the migration program but community support for the domination of it by the family stream. That is what has been lost.

The family stream was allowed to grow by 27 per cent during 1995-96. The effect of that was that it made up almost 70 per cent of the program, with a growth of 32 per cent in the number of spouse visas granted and a growth of 74 per cent in the number of parent visas granted. This growth was allowed to occur at the expense of the skilled stream of the program. This was not adding on a family section and maintaining the skilled section—it was at the expense of the skilled section.

Following the election in March, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, had very extensive consultations with a wide range of groups, including state and territory governments, business and industry groups, unions, environmental bodies, welfare organisations, church groups and representatives of Australia's migrant communities. On 3 July this year, the government announced that its program would include about 74,000 places. That is what we wanted, and we understand that there is agreement on the total. We wanted a skilled stream of 28,000, preferential family of 36,700, concessional family of 8,000 and special eligibility of 1,300. This program, therefore, is close to the average program level of the last four years, which is 72,550.

Just before I leave the question of the make-up of the program, I return to some remarks Senator Bolkus made. He sought to imply, without having the stomach to say it directly, that somehow the government was shifting to a racially based immigration intake because of certain changes we have sought to make to the English requirements. That is what he was seeking to say, but he could not bring himself to come straight to it.

First of all, we believe that the figures Senator Bolkus used with respect to those matters—the requirements for English, making a contribution, et cetera—are overstated. What Senator Bolkus did not say—and this is why they ask you to tell the truth and the whole truth when you go to court—was that the previous government recognised the need for migrants to have English language skills as a key to accessing employment. The Labor Party recognised that. If it is discriminatory to seek to introduce this English factors measure, how is it that the Labor government was prepared to introduce it for independent and business skilled migrants? Why is it good enough for some people and not good enough for others? That is the fickleness, the two-facedness and the shallowness of the debate we have heard this morning from Senator Bolkus.

Nonetheless, let me move on. How did we develop this migration program? We saw the need to restore the balance between family and skilled streams in the context of maintaining the non-discriminatory selection criteria. High and sustained levels of unemployment in the preferential family category had to be taken into account. There is evidence that English language skills are a key factor impacting on employment prospects and the overall settlement success of migrants. We had to take into account the costs associated with the rising number of parents within the program that need to be contained. And it was essential that changes be made to the selection criteria within the family stream to reduce the component of the program to an acceptable size. Under Labor in previous years, the family component zoomed up at the expense of the skills program. What we are doing is seeking to redress that balance.

The measures contained in these statutory rules which are designed to achieve this include the provision to allow refugees and humanitarian entrants to be reunited with their immediate family in Australia under the humanitarian program with attendant benefits and access to settlement services. Under the former government, many of these people had to be able to satisfy the criteria for selection within the general migration program without the advantages of being included within the humanitarian program. A further irony in this area is that the measures are substantially similar to the measures announced by Senator Bolkus in January this year.

There is a requirement that, generally, sponsors in the preferential family category be Australian citizens. In the current situation, where this demand driven category has grown to an unacceptable size and to constitute an unacceptable proportion of the program, it is reasonable to reduce this demand through recognition that the right to sponsor family members to become part of Australian society be acknowledged as a privilege only available to those who have made a public commitment to Australia by becoming an Australian citizen. To ensure a tighter balance of family tests for parents wishing to join their children within Australia, a clear majority of their children must be living in Australia. This change recognises the need to reduce the number of persons entering Australia who have the potential to become a burden on the Australian taxpayer.

There will be full cost recovery for English language tuition charges payable by certain migrants. This measure removes concessional rates that applied to certain applicants and removes exemption in respect of some onshore residence classes to bring them into line with the equivalent offshore classes. Before the election, we indicated that we would be applying full cost recovery principles in the adult English language program. This change recognises the need for migrants to take greater responsibility for the cost of their post‐arrival services, such as the provision of English tuition.Refugee, humanitarian and preferential family visa holders remain exempt from this charge.

PARA.BREAK: There are measures to ensure that sponsors in the preferential family category appropri ately abide by their commitments to support these programs. It is not unreasonable to ask people to abide by their commitments. The changes require sponsors in the preferential class to pay a bond which acts as a surety in respect of social security benefits, such as a special benefit. Requiring sponsors to provide an undertaking without the payment of a bond has not been successful in getting sponsors to meet their responsibilities, with the result that the Australian taxpayer has had to shoulder them. Similarly, preferential family applicants in respect of whom a bond is payable will also have to pay the health services charge, which operates in tandem with the assurance of support arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the inclusion of an English language factor in the points test for concessional family applicants. Senator Bolkus sought to make so much of that without mentioning his own government's recognition of the English language and the benefits or greater opportunities for migrants that it creates. This was foreshadowed in the government's election platform. The concessional family category is predominantly a skilled entry category designed to supplement the Australian labour market with relatively skilled migrants. That is what concessional family applicants are all about.

Points for the English language will be a relatively small portion of the total. Points will continue to be awarded for education skills and family connections. English language ability has been a factor in the selection of concessional family migrants for many years through the list of occupations requiring English. But putting English in the points tests allows it to be considered along with a range of other factors that are relevant to successful settlement.

There is the removal of a loophole which has allowed almost any non‐citizen temporarily within Australia to apply for a migrant visa offshore and to remain in Australia as the holder of a bridging visa, often with work rights and access to Medicare, until the migrant application is finally decided. This has been a loophole. A growing number of such migrant applications are being lodged by persons within Australia. If the number continues to grow at the current rate, control of the migration program may well be compromised. These people enter Australia on a temporary visa, the expectation being that if they decide to migrate permanently to Australia they will pursue their application offshore.

There is the introduction of a two‐year probationary visa for spouses and interdependency applicants offshore, in line with the current practice onshore. This is in response to the government's and the community's concern at instances of the use of the offshore spouse provisions for non‐bona fide relationships. Contrived marriages and especially organised marriage rackets remain a major concern to the integrity of the program. This measure, coupled with increased assessment of the bona fides of offshore applicants, will go a long way to restoring the community's confidence in the way this category is being used.

Also included in the Migration Regulations (Amendment) are a number of other less important changes and technical amendments. Other measures to facilitate better management of the program are contained in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996. That bill includes provision for there to be much more flexible powers when it comes to limiting the number of visas that can be granted in the program year in a particular visa class or classes.

The government requires the full range of measures I have spoken about if Australia is to achieve its goals of a balanced migration program and one which has public confidence. I repeat: the public has lost confidence in a migration program where the skills aspect has been allowed to diminish and where the family stream has taken over. The public has not lost confidence in a migration program but in one with that emphasis. That public confidence needs to be restored and it can be by returning to a more balanced program.

Following the announcement of the program in July, it is already evident from the application rates in certain categories that the government's plans to deliver a better migration program are being understood. Application rates in the preferential family category during the first quarter of this year are down by 14 per cent on the number of applicants last year. Should the disallowance motion moved by Senator Bolkus be passed, it will have the effect of doing away with all the initiatives I have mentioned in detail.

I have been advised that the view of the opposition is, nonetheless, that they do not disagree with the measure to introduce a probationary visa for spouse and interdependency classes offshore. However, in seeking to disallow the Australian citizenship sponsorship requirement, the regulations relating to the two‐year probationary visa have also been included because of the way the regulations have been drafted. It is my understanding that if this most unfortunate disallowance motion does succeed, the opposition will cooperate in assisting the government to immediately restore the regulations relating to the two‐year probationary visa. The government has adopted appropriate measures in order to achieve a very sensible balance between the family and skilled migration streams within the 1996‐97 program. The opposition has indicated that it agrees with the overall size of the program. The Democrats policy would have the program halved beyond what we suggest—more than halved, actually—as I understand it.

This disallowance motion seeks to destroy the measures designed to achieve the size of that program. So, yes, we agree with the size of the program but, no, we do not agree with how you are going to do it—and, no, we have no other proposals. This government is committed to the program it announced on 3 July 1996, both in size and in balance.
