Disallowance of the regulations would require the government to control the program through other measures. The only substantial measures currently available are the present inflexible capping powers in the Migration Act 1958. We are seeking more flexible powers in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), but the opposition has already foreshadowed that they may oppose those measures. I reiterate that Labor caused this problem. It let the balance in the program get out of control. This government is trying to fix it and what the previous government that made the mess is trying to do is sabotage a very sensible solution with a migration program of about 74,000 and the proper skills balance restored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the disallowance motion that has been moved by Senator Bolkus regarding the migration regulation statutory rules 211 and 213. I am glad that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has been reading our policies and surfing the Net, though I give a word of caution: the last time the minister surfed the Net on the Democrat home page she had to apologise to us—but I see no inconsistency between Democrat policy and what we are doing today. The minister has referred to the policy—our policy is quite clear. We do support—we do not oppose—a reduction in the number of migrants coming to Australia. The minister quoted our policy which states about migration levels:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . shall not exceed that number that will allow the population of Australia to be stabilised at a level which is consistent with an indefinitely sustainable environment. Until a sustainable population is achieved, a low level of immigration will be continued with the annual number of immigrants set so as not to exceed the number of permanent departures of the previous year. Refugees should be given the highest priority in immigration.

On that point, for a start, we are quite obviously and fundamentally at odds with the government's program which seems to be geared towards economically rationalised immigrants. Senator Vanstone referred to Senator Bolkus and urged that he tell the whole truth and not just little bits, so I continue. Our policy also states:

We also believe that the processing of applicants and the selection of new migrants will be non‐discriminatory, that high quality post arrival educational and orientation services should be provided and recognition of qualifications, linked with the right of reciprocity for Australian qualifications and based upon careful assessment of course content, curricula and requirements and professional trade experience will be provided.

So this debate today is not simply about numbers—in fact it is not about numbers; it is about means. It is about ensuring that our migration policy is of a non‐discriminatory nature. That is a very clear part of the Australian Democrats policy. There is nothing at all in the Australian Democrats policy statement which states that any measure at all is permissible to reduce our migrant intake, particularly not discrimination. I do note with interest the comments of the now Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, back in 1989 when I believe he was the shadow immigration minister. During the second reading debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill, back in 1989, he stated:

I am pleased to be able to participate in a debate where, as a result of what is called a bipartisan approach we hae been able largely to agree on important legislation and important amendments to improve that legislation. I think it is important that people understand what is meant by `bipartisan'. First it does not mean that the Government hands down on tablets its view and can immediately assume that in all respects it will be accepted by the loyal opposition.
On 1 June 1989 he also stated:

I regard it as absolutely unconscionable for a government to say half way through the year, `We have enough spouses in now, we are going to close off the category and no more people in that category can come to Australia—no more husbands and wives, no more dependent children or aged parents. I am glad that the Minister has made the decision to exclude those groups. We have saved the Government great agony had it persisted in that area. It certainly is a matter that would have attracted a great deal of adverse criticism.

Those comments were made by the then shadow minister, Philip Ruddock, now the minister. It seems to me that he is quite blatantly contradicting a viewpoint that he held while he was in opposition. How times have changed! What does the attainment of office seem to do to people around here?

For us, the governing principle is that while the Australian Democrats support the prerogative of the government to set the numbers for the levels of immigration, we do not support policies which implement those levels through discriminatory means. We will always reserve our right to monitor the way the government intends to implement its policies. We should never divorce ourselves from the impact that immigration policies have on the lives of people. We have heard examples of real life stories—Senator Bolkus referred to them today here in this chamber. It is about means today, not about numbers.

It is important and worth noting that the Democrats have also supported many immigration measures put forward by this government and other governments, particularly those measures stipulated in statutory rules 112 and 213. Among others, we also have accepted a two‐year probationary visa for offshore spouse, de facto and interdependency applications. So we are not intentionally opposing all immigration measures put forward by this government.

I turn now to some of the specific objections of the Australian Democrats to some of the regulations that are up for disallowance. In regard to the balance of the family test and its expansion, the Democrats do not support that. We find it quite an offensive and oppressive measure. The imposition of the test that says children can only sponsor their parents if more than 50 per cent of those parents' children are Australian citizens we consider unnecessarily harsh. We also consider it an important citizenship issue, and I will turn to other citizenship issues and questions later.

But to a large extent, if implemented, this regulation will have an arbitrary effect. Can honourable senators imagine what it would be like for a family of five to assure that three of their children were Australian citizens before they were eligible to sponsor? Surely the governing principle here is that the assurances of support are adequate to safeguard Australian taxpayers from becoming a financial liability to our society in which they have not made a significant contribution. Surely these assurances of support are adequate protection. By any stretch of the imagination, the current levels of assurances of support, coupled with the recent increases, are more than adequate to meet those concerns. That is the Australian Democrats' position.

In regard to Australian citizens and the issue of Australian citizens versus permanent residents, a number of regulations, namely, regulations 13.3, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 37, 47, 48, 49, 51, 53, 54, 55, 74, 77.16, 77.19, 78, 85 and 119 are all amended to make only Australian citizens eligible for certain classes of visa and/or sponsorship. In negotiations with the government, the Democrats have made clear our concerns about this provision. We have made clear that we have concerns that these matters, potentially, are in breach of the Race Discrimination Act 1975. Honourable senators will appreciate that in the recent political climate, it is essential that not only are our immigration policies non‐discriminatory, but that there is a reasonable perception of that non‐discriminatory principle. In this regard and in light of Australia's less than proud history in this respect—and Senator Bolkus referred to the rather infamous and inappropriate White Australia Policy—there is a strict onus upon all Australian governments to ensure that beyond a doubt, our immigration policy is non‐discriminatory. The government have fallen way short in this regard.
Let me clarify what I mean by `non‐discriminatory' because there exists an apparent ambiguity around this place as to what this actually means. By non‐discriminatory, I mean:

That any enactment involving a distinction, exclusion, restriction or preference based on race, colour, descent or national or ethnic origin which has the purpose or effect of nullifying or impairing recognition, enjoyment or exercise, on an equal footing, of any human right or fundamental freedom in the political, economic, social, cultural or any other field of public life is discriminatory.
Furthermore:

If, by reason of, or of a provision of, a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, persons of a particular race, colour or national or ethnic origin do not enjoy a right that is enjoyed by persons of another race, colour or national or ethnic origin, or enjoy a right to a more limited extent than persons of another race, colour or national or ethnic origin, then notwithstanding anything in that law, persons of the first mentioned race, colour or national or ethnic origin shall, by force of this section, enjoy that right to the same extent as persons of that other race, colour or national or ethnic origin.

Of course, they are not my words but the words of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which we, governed by the rule of law, are bound to take as the authority of what constitutes racial discrimination.

BREAK.PARA: Clearly section 10 of the act makes it clear that national or ethnic origin are part of the attributes which constitute racial discrimination. What these regulations do is in part construct a distinction based upon national or ethnic origin in the provisions as to whom can sponsor other people to migrate to Australia. To distinguish between a citizen and a permanent resident in this way can be argued is in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act.
Returning to the words of Minister Ruddock, on 30 October in the House of Representatives, he said:

I am not pleased to participate in this debate today. It is the second occasion on which I have been involved in a motion to affirm our non‐discriminatory approach to the selection of migrants in Australia, all visitors, temporary residents and others who happen to be legally in Australia with equal rights and respect regardless of their race, creed or country of origin.
Furthermore, the joint statement that was issued on that same day on racial tolerance in the House of Representatives stated:
That this House—
point 2—
reaffirms its commitment to maintaining an immigration policy wholly non‐discriminatory on grounds of race, colour, creed or origin.

All senators as well as all members, I presume, would stand by that principle and endorse it very strongly. But in view of these regulations and section 10 of the Racial Discrimination Act, it seems we a distinction between the words of the minister and the words of this government and its action in a policy form.

I am glad that Minister Vanstone referred to the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) because, indeed, in that particular piece of legislation we see provisions designed to exempt from the Migration Act the protective provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act. How on earth can a policy, regulation or enactment be non‐discriminatory when clearly it comes into direct conflict with anti‐discrimination legislation? Clearly, it cannot. This seems to be an attempt again by this government to implement racial discrimination in Australia's immigration policy but this time through the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) and in a sexist manner, mind you.

If ever there was a time when the old adage `the ends do not justify the means' was relevant, it certainly is in this debate. It is an indictment on this government that it has taken extraordinary lengths—no matter how belated—to denounce discrimination in immigration only to propose legislation and bring regulations into being which are discriminatory. The Democrats do not and will not support such a measure.

In regard to the introduction of points for English language—20 points in the concessional family category—to which Senator Bolkus previously referred, as I also mentioned previously, the White Australia Policy is a particularly sinister part of Australia's history. In his article `From "White Australia" to part of Asia: Recent Shifts in Australian Immigration Policy Towards the Region', James Jupp makes the following observations:

Between the 1880s and 1960s, Australia deliberately insulated itself from its geographical region by adopting the White Australia Policy. Officially known as the restrictive immigration policy, under the Commonwealth Immigration Restriction Act 1901 (incidentally, one of the first acts passed by the National Parliament), the effective exclusion of non‐European immigrants formed part of a wider ideology based on fashionable theories of racial superiority. These had the greatest currency in the English‐speaking and Germanic cultures and were often supported by sophisticated "scientific" theories as much as by popular prejudice.
He continues:
The mechanism for implementing the policy included a dictation test . . . It was normally given to the applicant in a language not understood by them and was not a test of literacy.

Clearly, the imposition of a 20‐points test—that is, to the level of a native speaker—is going to have a disproportionable effect upon those people from a non‐English speaking background. Ultimately, the balance between non-English speaking backgrounds and English speaking backgrounds would significantly alter.

While it may not be the intention of the minister—I do not suggest it is—to re‐create the effects of the White Australia Policy, clearly this would go a certain way towards that effect and therefore cannot be supported in the concessional family category. While it is true that additional points are already allocated to migrants in the skilled category, there has always been a recognition that the concessional family category should be exempt from such points testing.

I thought that Senator McKiernan appropriately addressed the issue of the education charge, one that the Democrats have consistently opposed. So there are no claims there by the government or the minister that we have changed our position in any way.

In conclusion, the Democrats are disappointed by the regulations before us today and by the apparent lack of comprehension on the part of the government as to the implementing of a non‐discriminatory policy, instead of just talking about it. Clearly, this is an area where the Democrats will be required to play a more vigilant and supervisory role, and it is not one that we intend to resile from.

The minister may continue to throw back at us the words in our policy and words that she may have read on our home page on the Net but I reiterate that there is no inconsistency. We are on record as not opposing a reduction in numbers but we also maintain that fundamental part of our policy to which we are committed: that any changes in migration policy or any reduction in numbers must be done in a way that is non‐discriminatory. The Democrats repudiate racism; we denounce racism; but we also celebrate multiculturalism in this country. That is also a pertinent feature of our immigration policy. The Democrats will be supporting the disallowance before the chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —The address we have heard from Senator Stott Despoja is quite interesting because, as Senator Vanstone quite correctly pointed out, the Democrats have a policy which says in essence that the number of people allowed to enter this country in the course of any given year shall not exceed the number of people leaving the country in the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the number of people leaving the country each year is about 30,000, so the maximum number of people who should be allowed to enter the country under the Democrats policy is about 30,000. They have already said that they believe the humanitarian category should have priority. The humanitarian program was running at about 14,000 places. So that means that there is a maximum available under the Democrats' policies for all categories of about 16,000 places a year.

Assuming that we leave New Zealand out of it altogether, 16,000 people would mean that we would have to run an immigration program in relation to spouse entry that would be 12,000 places a year more stringent than what we are proposing under these regulations. We would have to completely eliminate the skills category and other categories. We would have to completely eliminate, for example, the preferential family reunion. We would be able to take only 16,000 spouses. There would be 12,000 spouses every year who would miss out. Nobody's brother, sister, uncle, aunt or parents would get into the country. That is the consequence of the Democrat policy.

Yet here we are making a modest move from 83,000 migrants a year to 74,000 migrants a year, and the Democrats are saying, `No. We are not going to allow you to put these regulations through the parliament because we think they are discriminatory.' Well, how discriminatory would you have to be to cut the immigration program from 83,000 people back to 30,000 people? You would have to be substantially more discriminatory than anything that could possibly be discriminatory in these regulations.

But of course this is the Democrats, so rationality and reason do not play a big part in it. It is a little bit like `Natasha through the Looking Glass'. That is really what this is about. I was expecting the Queen of Hearts to come running down the aisle of the chamber at any moment because, if you had the Democrat immigration policy, the Queen of Hearts would have to come in here shouting, `Off with their heads!', because none of these people would be allowed in.

BREAK.PARA: The argument we heard from the Democrats is that somehow these measures are racially discriminatory because in the concessional family migration program we have a points test in part on the English language. I agree with everything that my friend on the other side of the chamber has said about the evils of the White Australia Policy. However, what Senator Stott Despoja did not understand, and obviously never will, is that the White Australia Policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're running from it.

—They are running from the logic of the argument. A prerequisite of entry under the White Australia Policy was that a person pass a dictation test. This policy states that people will get points for functional English, but it is still perfectly possible to enter this country under the concessional family reunion scheme. I am glad to see that Senator Stott Despoja is back. I acknowledge her presence in the chamber. It is always nice to have her here. It would be even nicer if the Democrats learnt something whilst they were here.

BREAK.PARA: It was a prerequisite under the White Australia Policy that a person had to pass the test. Under this policy, if you do not pass the test, you can still make it in. But concessional family reunion, which accounts for about 8,000 or 9,000 people per year, is basically an economic entry; it is a skill entry. It is not the program that applies to people who are parents or spouses. Those categories relate to a preferential family reunion. So it is incorrect to say that this discriminates against spouses or parents, because they are not in the concessional category. The concessional category is based on skills. The points that apply in the concessional category rank people in terms of their skills.

However, the concessional category is a concession. It says that we will give people an advantage because they have a near relative who is sponsoring their entry into this country. If this category were abolished, these people would not make it under the independent points test. We are doing people a favour. At the end of the day, it is still a points tested migration category.

The other category, which is the preferential category, does not have any points attached to it. It does not have a points test system. That category remains. What the Democrats say is, unfortunately, inaccurate. The concessional family reunion, because of the points test, is and always has been a skills based category. It is appropriate to apply a points test that does not disqualify people to recognise English language ability.

It is also, if I dare say it, a little patronising of the Democrats to say that this discriminates against people from South-East Asia. I happened to go through university with some people from Singapore who spoke better English than the English students who were in the university with me. They spoke much better English. It is patronising to suggest that people who come from South-East Asia cannot speak English.

TALK.START.PARA: —How was it writ?

—Senator Forshaw, it is a good thing that you were born in this country; that is all can I say, my friend. I want to make it very clear that this is a non-discriminatory policy. It does not discriminate on the basis of race.

BREAK.PARA: One argument we heard from Senator Bolkus on the other side of the chamber was that somehow this discriminated against people from mainland China who came here under the 1 November decision. That is incorrect. If anything, I would have thought the majority of family tests for preferential family reunion sponsorship rights advantaged people from mainland China, because the one-child policy has been in operation in mainland China for 30 years. That means that most of the people who are here under the 1 November decision are the only child in the family. In fact, Senator Bolkus is wrong; it is easier for many of these people to bring in their parents than migrants who have come from Greece, Ireland or the United Kingdom. That argument is wrong. It is disingenuous of Senator Bolkus to suggest that there was some evil, nefarious plot in the immigration policy to racially discriminate against these people.

I happen to chair the coalition's back bench committee on this. I can assure honourable senators that I was assiduous, as was Senator Short when he was the shadow minister, in going through every measure to ensure that it did not discriminate on the basis of race. In this program, we are discriminating on the basis of what people have to offer to this country and what they will take from it. That should be the basis of the migration program.

We are saying about the concessional family reunion that we believe people who have English language skills are more likely to get a job. It is a fact that people who come in under the concessional family reunion program with low levels of English literacy have a much lower chance of getting a job and are much more likely to be dependent upon welfare. We are concerned about that for two reasons. The first relates to the fact that the taxpayer has to fork out money. The second relates to the fact that we do not believe it is fair to encourage people to come to this country when they have a very low chance of getting a job. It limits their right to fully participate in this nation's public life. That is why we believe these changes in relation to the English language are necessary.

I want to talk about the spouse program. It is a fact that this program was in control until the 1995-96 year. In the 1995-96 year, the number of spouse applicants shot up dramatically. There was no control put over who was getting entry under the spouse program. With spouses, fiancees, de factos and interdependent relationships, it was almost open slather. Many of these marriages were sham marriages. On the limited investigations that were done during the 1995-96 financial year, 1,500 sham marriages were found in the intake, and that is just on the limited resources that were then available to the department to investigate it. The rule in the department was not to bother.

Rather than being anti-family, our requirements for spouse entry are pro‐family. They are pro the legitimate marriages and anti the sham marriages. How can a person stand before an altar and take a vow of marriage before God just to get entry into this country. That is what has happened. In striking out the sham marriages and putting in requirements to show the bona fides of the marriage, we are upholding family values. Nothing can erode the sanctity of marriage faster than its being used as a sham to circumvent the immigration requirements of this country.

I find that, as a Christian, quite frankly, utterly, morally and religiously reprehensible. I find that a slight against my Christian values. That is why we are doing it that way, and we believe it is perfectly fair. I will give honourable senators a case study of how the system will work. I had a constituent approach me. He is well known to me. He said, `I was best man at a wedding in the United Kingdom. It was an Australian marrying an English girl. They put an application in for spouse entry. They're concerned about whether they're going to get in.' I said, `If it's a bona fide marriage, I feel reasonably confident you'll meet the requirements. But when the spouse comes here, obviously, they have to stay married for two years.' I said, `What evidence do you have of the bona fides of the marriage?' He said, `Look, I flew over to London, a number of other people who were relatives flew over to London for the wedding. They had been engaged for some substantial period of time. They had been living together for some substantial period of time.'

I said, `In light of all that, I don't think you're going to have any problem because it is a bona fide marriage.' I had no hesitation in writing to the post and saying, `I happen to know some of the people who went to the wedding. They travelled all the way from Australia to the United Kingdom. These people have been together for a substantial period of time. I would like you to take my word that I believe this is a bona fide marriage.' That is all that is necessary.

But if you happen to get married to somebody in Las Vegas, in one of those drive‐in marriage parlours, it is not unreasonable that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs might happen to be a little bit concerned as to whether the marriage will last, even before we get to whether it is bona fide. We might happen to be concerned as to whether it will last.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not made in heaven!

—Not made in heaven, Senator Kemp, that is absolutely correct. Of course, we have seen a number of high profile people—for example, Mr Michael Jackson—undergo those marriages, and look at the consequences. All we are saying is that we are discriminating in favour of bona fide, legitimate relationships. But the program is still very, very generous.

BREAK.PARA: There has been some suggestion from those on the other side that we should knock out some of the other parts of the regulations. For example, the motion moved by Senator Bolkus would prevent the government from recovering the full cost of English language courses from people who are essentially economic migrants. This does not apply to the family reunion categories, it does not apply to the humanitarian categories, but it will be applying to other categories where people come here on the basis of skills or because they are business migrants. If they undergo an English language course, and these people are coming here to get a financial benefit from being a resident of Australia, it is not unreasonable that we expect them to contribute a proportion of the cost. That is a perfectly reasonable proposition.

These people, we believe, because of the great opportunities and advantages offered by this country, will be substantially better off in economic terms after a couple of years. It is not unreasonable to expect them to pay the cost of the English language course if they are obliged to undertake an English language course. In fact, the very existence of English language courses for migrants shows that with the points test for English this system does not automatically eliminate people who do not have high levels of English language proficiency, because if the system did what Senator Bolkus said it would do, we would not be running English language courses in the first place. So yet another perfectly reasonable proposal put forward by the government has been knocked back.

The opposition seeks also to prevent the government from recouping benefits received by migrants within the first two years that they are in this country. We have said that people who are arriving as migrants from now on cannot expect to receive social security. We have said that where people are sponsored there should be a bond. The opposition wants us to stop any opportunity to recover from that bond where the people who have been brought in and sponsored receive social security benefits.

What is the point of putting up the bond? What is the point of asking people to be sponsors? Anybody can put their hand up and say, `I'm going to sponsor Joe Bloggs to come into this country. Yes, I will make sure he meets all his requirements. Yes, I understand he can't get welfare.' Of course, Joe Bloggs comes in, he does not bother to do anything, Joe Bloggs finds himself down on his heels. We do the humanitarian thing and give him some money, but the sponsor does not have any obligation at all, under what the opposition is proposing, to ensure that the sponsor actually meets their obligations. That, we believe, is wrong. It is wrong for this country, it is also morally wrong, because these people give a promise and it is not unreasonable to expect that that promise should be backed up with some form of surety. In fact, the opposition have even said in some of their statements that they accept that. Unfortunately, here they are in the Senate chamber, they have said they accept it and now they want to knock out the regulation.

You can see, Mr Acting Deputy President, that what we have here are some fairly shallow arguments from those on the other side. One of the things that really gets me is that they say they are concerned about family reunion. Senator Bolkus talked about family reunion. What we are proposing in these regulations is that people who are here under the humanitarian program can be allowed to bring in their immediate families. That regulation would be knocked out by the motion that Senator Bolkus has moved today. That regulation would be knocked out if Senator Bolkus's motion gets up.

I think the knock‐out blow should not be delivered to the regulations, should not be delivered to the integrity of the migration program; I believe the knock‐out blow should be delivered to this motion. I believe the Senate should knock this motion out and allow the government to continue a migration program that is reasonable, balanced and basically reflects what the migration program was in 1994‐95, before it blew out in the 1995‐96 financial year. That is all we are seeking to do.

But if we do not have it, it stands to the shame of those opposite that we have been prevented from doing so. The Democrats say they believe that net migration should be zero. They would only allow 30,000 people into the country. We are saying we are going to take it down from 83,000 to 74,000. They are saying, `No, we're not going to let you do it because we think that would be discriminatory.' People on the other side are making all sorts of outrageous claims, none of which stand up to scrutiny. This is being done for the basest of political motives, and that is why it should be rejected by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator O'Chee has summed up the argument by the government on these regulations pretty succinctly by saying that we are discriminating on the basis of what people have to offer this country and what they will take from it. It is pretty much a utilitarian, economic, fundamentalist viewpoint. It says, in effect, that the door is open but not if it is a matter of the heart, not if it is a matter of humanitarianism, not if it is a matter of concern for the plight a person might be in when she or he wants to come to this country. It says that we are going to judge the matter on the basis of what we can get out of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the disallowance of these regulations because I think an immigration policy has got to be more than that. Such a policy has got to be based on—not just take account of—humanitarian ideals. This great country of ours is based, I believe, on humanitarian ideals and concern for a fair go for everyone, not just on what we can get out of them. I also heard Senator O'Chee say that it is patronising to suggest that people from South‐East Asia cannot speak English. What an extraordinary statement! That comment was made apparently on the basis of the case of some friends from Singapore that he knew at university. That does not suggest that he has travelled very widely because the reality is that most people in South‐East Asia do not speak English.

BREAK.PARA: We have to take into account that it is a reality that most people in the world do not speak English and that we need to open our eyes to the fact that most people wanting to come to this country from South‐East Asia, for whatever reason, will not be able to speak English—certainly at a level which is better than the average English‐speaking student in a university in Australia, as Senator O'Chee would maintain. He also said, at the outset, that the Democrats' policy was one of nobody's parents, nobody's sister and nobody's brother getting into the country. But what he is saying is that somebody's parents, somebody's sister and somebody's brother are not going to get into the country—who previously would have—if these regulations were to be disallowed.

The problem is: how are you going to select that somebody? Which somebody's sister, which somebody's parents or which somebody's brother will be blocked from coming here because of the regulations the government has before the Senate? That is another reason why we should consider very carefully allowing those regulations to go past this place.

I am not going to recount the arguments put by Senator Bolkus and the other speakers who are supporting the disallowance of the regulations, except to say that they will have my vote. It is perhaps summed up by the Ethnic Communities' Council of New South Wales. I quote briefly from a letter written by Angela Chan, the chairperson of that council which represents over a thousand, affiliated, ethnic organisations and members:
The ECC of NSW believes that many of the proposed changes will have a discriminatory effect including:
The requirement of citizenship to sponsor immediate family, including spouses.
What they mean there is that if you are a permanent resident, you are not going to be able to sponsor immediate family; you will need to be a citizen. That is a change from the past. Next:
The changes in the pass marks required for the Concessional family category, giving considerable advantage to people of English‐speaking background.

That is a levying of increased discrimination against those people who do not have an English‐speaking background. As Senator Bolkus so succinctly put it, it means that, if you are on one side of the street where the family speaks English, you will be able to get family members through the requirements and into the country on the basis of family reunion; whereas if you are across the other side of the street in Australia where the family does not have family members speaking fluent English, or English as a first language, those people will not be able to. That is where this difference will be levied. It is discriminatory, not only against people wanting to come into the country but also against families already living in this country. It is discriminatory against Australian citizens and Australian permanent residents. Next:
The huge increase in fees for visa applications and English Language Tuition.
The requirement of parents to have a majority of their children in Australia before being able to migrate.

Previously, the `majority' terminology was not required but now, if you have only two children, both must be in Australia. It is not good enough to have one child in Australia or, to put it conversely as Senator Stott Despoja did, if you are a child in Australia and you want to have your parents given the opportunity to come into this country and you have a sibling somewhere else in the world, you will need to get that sister or brother to come here before you have a chance of being able to get your parents to join you. That is a change against such people coming to live in Australia.
The council says the new regulations will also be discriminatory because they are:
Requiring assurances of support be provided for spouses and other family reunion categories.
And because of:
The real reduction in the Humanitarian intake.
Ms Chan continues:

These changes will affect many in the community, particularly families. Many of these regulation changes were not foreshadowed in the election campaign and therefore we fail to be convinced by the Government's argument that they have a mandate to be making these changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones? Which ones were not foreshadowed?
—I have just enumerated the list, Senator Short, and you ought to be well enough aware of your own policy to know which ones.
—You ought to be able to tell us which ones, yourself. So you support all of them.

—You can get to your feet in a moment and defend these yourself on the basis of the policy you put to the electorate. If you want to argue with the Ethnic Communities' Council of NSW, take up the issue with them. Mr Acting Deputy President, I support the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to participate in this debate on Senator Bolkus's motion to disallow the migration regulations because it is a very important matter. It boils down to whether we agree with the proposition that the government of this nation has the right and the ability to determine who can enter Australia. If the disallowance motion were to be successful today, it would be a death blow to the ability of the elected government of the day to determine Australia's migration program.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout our history, the major parties—the coalition parties and the Labor Party—were absolutely at one on the fundamental proposition that the government of the day had, as one of its basic rights and responsibilities, the determination of who can enter this country within the bounds of, as we have had for a long time now, a totally non‐discriminatory policy. The policy of successive governments has been non‐discriminatory in respect of race, ethnicity, nationality, colour, creed or religion.

In my opening remarks I want to stress very strongly that the Howard government is completely committed to a totally non‐discriminatory policy, as the coalition parties have been since, as I am very proud to say, the coalition government of Harold Holt in 1966 abolished the White Australia Policy, which was discriminatory and abhorrent. But since those days, for the last 30 years, virtually without exception—there have been some hiccoughs from time to time, particularly so far as the Labor Party is concerned—all major parties in Australia have followed a totally non‐discriminatory approach.

But that approach must be seen within the context of the government of the day being able to determine the size and composition of its migration program from between the different categories of family reunion, skilled migration, humanitarian refugee intake, and the like. I do not know of anyone, with the possible exception of some of the speakers today—Senator Bob Brown in particular—who would differ from that view.

The disallowance motion that we are discussing is unprecedented because, as I understand it, it is the first time that a government's migration policy arrangements, since being put into legislative form, have been the subject of a sustained and constant attack by an opposition. As I said, if this motion were successful, it would be the first time in Australian history that an elected government has not been allowed to do its required job of managing the Australian migration program.

I strongly put to those supporting the disallowance motion—particularly to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, very honourable senators who have at the core of their approach to the parliamentary system the understanding that the elected government of the day must be able to govern—that this disallowance motion, if it were to be passed, would negate the fundamental rights and responsibilities of an elected government in a parliamentary democracy.

The great irony of all this is that the opposition is seeking to remove measures which we have introduced because of the previous Labor government's mismanagement of the migration program. The prime architect of that mismanagement was none other than Senator Bolkus, who has the hypocrisy to come into the chamber today and move this disallowance motion. Senator Bolkus speaks very much with a forked tongue in this debate.

On the one hand, the opposition claims that it agrees with the overall size of the program for 1996‐97, yet the disallowance motion seeks to destroy the very measures required to achieve that size of program. I would have thought that there was general agreement amongst members of this parliament and in the wider community that the migration program is out of control. And it is out of control because of Senator Bolkus's gross mismanagement.

The critical concern I have—as a person who throughout my whole life has continued to support a strong immigration program as a fundamental requirement of the sort of Australia that I want to see develop in the future—is that the mismanagement of the program and the previous government's allowing it to get out of balance has destroyed community confidence in migration in a way that is extremely damaging. No government will be able to pursue a vibrant, progressive, strong migration policy in the future if it does not have community support for that program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Communities have had the same view about migration, Jim, for 100 years. Have a look at the public record and the polls.
—That is not true.
—It is absolutely true.

—That is not true. Let me just make a couple of points about that because community confidence has been destroyed in the migration program through the mismanagement of the previous government. It is that very important factor that has allowed the flames of intolerance and division to be fanned by persons like the member of Oxley, Ms Hanson. I agree with the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, in her remarks earlier today, that it is about time we ceased talking about Ms Hanson.
—Well, stop talking about her then.

—Just a moment. You have had your go. It just helps maintain the publicity she receives. I do not want to prolong that publicity, but I do want to use this debate to put on the public record some of my views on this situation. I will do it very briefly. Unlike your view, Senator Collins, it is my view that, during most of my lifetime, a high level of immigration was accepted as almost an article of faith. That view has been questioned increasingly in more recent years. The impact of migration on the economy, and particularly employment and unemployment levels, has attracted increased consideration. It is important and desirable that there be a lively debate on these matters and, particularly, on our immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of migration on population distribution, resource usage, international relations, the environment and the nature of our society also has come to be increasingly debated and requires careful debate. Those necessary and desirable debates, though, must be based on facts, on sophisticated analysis, on the Australia we have today and on a realistic assessment of our future, rather than on any nostalgic view perhaps of an Australia of the past.

It is the duty of each and every one of us, individually and collectively, to continue to work towards still greater tolerance and harmony, and cultural and economic vibrancy, in Australia. It is our duty to be ever vigilant against those in our ranks whose words or actions cause division within our society and who, through ignorance or for whatever other motives, conscious or unconscious, fan the flames of bigotry or hatred, whether these be on racial or any other grounds.

It is for that reason that the contribution of people like the member for Oxley, Ms Hanson, is to me both repugnant and dangerous. Her approach is based on ignorance. It is remarkably simplistic. It is based on incorrect facts and unsubstantiated assertions. It is confused and inconsistent. Ms Hanson appears unwilling to accept that future migrants could provide net benefits to Australia. She damns with faint praise the enormous benefits that migrants have brought to Australia throughout our history, especially over the past 50 years of virtually uninterrupted large-scale migration from all corners of the globe. Hers is a negative, destructive approach which simply does not reflect the Australia of today.

I come back to the point that the views of people like that have been encouraged by the undermining of confidence in the migration program that we have had under the previous government. That is precisely what the government is attempting to do in its—

TALK.START.PARA: —Undermining by the Prime Minister, who said that she accurately reflected people's views. That might have had something to do with it, Senator Short.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, could you perhaps stop this constant flibbertigibbet over the other side from interjecting.
—Constant insertion of the truth.
—Order, Senator Collins!

—The program that the government is seeking to implement is a balanced program both in size and composition. To those who say that it is a major attempt to slash or to ignore the virtues of family reunion, I would simply have to say that the figures do not support that. It is true that there will be a reduction in family reunion this year compared with last year. But last year saw a very large increase in family reunion and a major decrease—and that has been occurring over years—in the proportion of people in other categories.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to a point that was made by several speakers in relation to the 1989 comment of Philip Ruddock, the now Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and then shadow minister, that to cap the number of spouses would be—I think he used the word—`unconscionable'. There are two or three very important things that need to be said about that.

The first point I want to make is that Labor itself proposed to cap the number of spouses in 1989. Now they have changed their mind and they are saying that there should not be any capping. Now there is, of course, even more need to properly manage the program. Capping in this area is one important—and as fair as can be determined—way of doing so.

The second point I would make in relation to Philip Ruddock's comments in 1989, compared with the situation today, is that there has been an enormous change in the balance of the migration program between that time and now. For example, in 1988-89, 46,000 out of a total migration intake of 124,000 constituted family reunion. That was something of the order of a third. In the year just concluded, 1995-96, out of a total intake of 82,000, 48,000 were family reunion. That is almost 60 per cent—not far short of two-thirds—almost a doubling of the proportion. So the situation is very different indeed now from then.

Thirdly, of course, there is now substantial evidence of fraud in the program. I am amazed and I regret to see that Senator Bolkus today virtually ignored the significance of that. That fraud is a matter of great concern to a huge range of Australians, including potential immigrants to Australia who want to come in for fair, proper and honest reasons.

They are some of the things I wanted to give the lie to in terms of this debate today. Senator McKiernan made the point that when I was the shadow minister for immigration I said during election period and prior to that that English is the glue that binds the nation together. I do not resile from that statement and nor does the government.

Two points have been made today about the English requirement. The first relates to the increase in fees for English language training. I stress that it is only an increase in fees for those who already make a contribution. We are increasing the degree of cost recovery in those categories where people already make a contribution towards the cost of their training. The opposition would have us believe that everyone is going to be slugged a fortune to learn English. The fact is that refugee, humanitarian and preferential family visa holders will remain exempt from this charge. There will be no charge to learn English for preferential family newcomers or refugee or humanitarian entrants. They are the ones whose needs are the greatest and they are the ones who will continue to be totally protected. There will be no charge for their English language tuition.

The other point made by Senator McKiernan and others is that the government is going to put a points score for English in the concessional family category. The maximum will be 20 out of a total possible score of 150. A person who is well skilled and has no English at all will still be able to enter Australia in that concessional family category.

The way this issue has been presented—and this happened time and again during the election; this is an election undertaking that we are now introducing; it is not new because we announced it before the election and there were great debates about it around the country and I participated in virtually all of them—is that if you have not got any English you will not get in through the concessional family category. That is simply untrue.

The other point that is ignored is that if a person who does not speak English but is fluent in two other languages applies under the concessional family category they get bonus points. They will get five bonus points. That might help them get over the points hurdle for entry into Australia. I want to dispel completely the absolute untruth that has been peddled for months that, so far as the concessional family category is concerned, if you cannot speak English, in the future you will not get into Australia. That is not true.

Migrants now are not accepted for a range of occupations on the occupational listing, which was introduced by the previous government and has been in existence for years, unless they are proficient in English. It is absolutely mandatory that they are proficient in English before they will be allowed into the country to undertake occupations in certain of the categories. For Labor to be saying that the new government is introducing something which is fundamentally different from anything that ever existed in the past is simply untrue.

One can make similar points about most of the other issues that have been raised today. I think those issues have been covered very fully and amply by the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Vanstone, and my colleague Senator O'Chee. I do not want go into all of those again.

I want to pick up the point about assurances of support and the bonding requirements that are part of the regulations. Assurances of support have existed in the migration policies of successive governments. I am not sure, but I think the current assurances of support arrangements were probably introduced by the previous Labor government and they had our support. The simple fact is that they have not been working and they need strengthening. That is what the regulations, which the opposition seeks to disallow, include in part.

The question of Australian citizens versus Australian residents, so far as sponsorship is concerned, is an important issue. It is a new point. It constitutes a departure from previous practice whereby Australian residents, whether they were citizens or not, have been able to sponsor people in the family category. People can have different views on that. I would have thought that most Australians would say that this is a time when there is a need for a rational approach and as fair and objective an approach to both the size and the category composition of our migration program as possible. We hear a lot of crocodile tears from the opposition and others about the impact of migration on employment and unemployment levels. That has not been proven. I think that requires further careful debate and consideration.

You cannot make the point that migration increases unemployment and, at the same time, say that we cannot have some decent, proper, and as fair and objective as possible, rationing system. I think most Australians would say that an Australian citizen should have preference over an Australian non‐citizen in being able to sponsor persons to come to live in this country. People have different views on that, but the simple fact is that, if you are not to use that sort of screening or rationing mechanism, you will have to use other mechanisms which may well be much less fair to all concerned. The final point of detail that I wanted to pick up was to refute the assertion that in some respects the regulations are retrospective. That simply is not correct. Senator Bolkus, in a press release issued on 29 October, stated that `in attempting to make some of the changes retrospective, the government has made legally flawed regulations'. On behalf of the government, I say to Senator Bolkus that that is not so. The amendments to the regulations are fully prospective in nature, in that the regulation amendments apply only to decisions made after the commencement of the regulations on 1 October 1996. Any argument that the regulations are retrospective is simply wrong as a matter of law. Legislation operates retrospectively only if it provides that rights and obligations are changed with effect prior to the commencement of the legislation.

Although the amendments may affect some applications on hand at the date of commencement of the regulations on 1 October 1996, they do not affect the rights or obligations of those applicants prior to this date. I understand that that matter has been the subject of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, which has confirmed fully the legality of these regulation amendments.

I conclude by making a plea to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston to look very carefully at this disallowance motion moved by Senator Bolkus on behalf of the opposition. If this disallowance motion is passed, what the Senate is really saying is that the elected government of this country does not have the right or the responsibility to determine the level and content of its immigration program. That is something that really is unprecedented in the history of this nation, and I believe that would be seen as a matter of very great concern by each and every Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important matter indeed that has come before the parliament. I acknowledge what Senator Short said; that is, that over a period of years there has been a bipartisan approach to the question, and that by and large migration regulations have received that bipartisan support. Mind you—and I remind the Senate of this—that was not so in respect of Mig 2 and Mig 4, which were those put forward by the then minister, Senator Bolkus. They had a run around the legal and constitutional committee. I thought I would mention that, because it is not the first time that regulations have been challenged. But Senator Short is correct: largely, these matters have been matters of bipartisan support and have gone through this place without having been disallowed.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to advert to something that Senator O'Chee said about the issue of sham marriages for the purpose of persons trying to get into this country. Of course, we all condemn that. We all would want to tighten the situation that enables that to occur. I have made it perfectly clear to the government that I support that. As I understand it, the opposition has no objection to the introduction of the provisional two‐year visa. But the trouble is, as is often the case with these regulations, that that desirable objective is so intertwined with other provisions—in this case, the provisions relating to citizenship and the provisions relating to Australian residents—that it cannot be extracted. But I give the government my assurance that I would support it strongly in bringing that matter forward if it can be done in such a way that it is clear and not mixed up and inextricably interwoven with other provisions which clearly are not acceptable.

I do appreciate very much the time that has been given to us by the department and its officers and by the minister on this matter. I have been well advised on this matter. I have been given all of the information, and I have considered it very thoroughly. There have been, as the officers know, hours and hours spent on this matter.

The government says quite openly that the regulations seek to limit the right of persons who are lawfully and permanently resident within the Commonwealth to have live with them their spouses, their children and their parents. The government has made it clear that its intention is to reduce the migrant intake, and this is a measure which it sees as being an equitable way of achieving that objective.

I point out to the Senate, as I think has already been done, although I have not heard it, that it is the family area that is going to take the brunt of the reduction. I do note what Senator Short said. Yes, there was an increase in family intakes last year—in fact, there has been a reasonably substantial increase over the last three years—but I will come to that in a moment. In this particular instance, it means that the preferential family category will drop from 50,500 in 1995-96 to the planned level of 36,700. That is a 14,000 drop.

TALK.START.PARA: —That takes it back only to the year before last, Senator Harradine.

—I acknowledge what you said about that, Senator Short. I admit that, of all the people in this chamber, you would probably be the one who has had a very detailed knowledge of these matters over a long period of time.

BREAK.PARA: Let me just say that the intake for the other category—the total skilled program—is going up by roughly 5,000. So the brunt of this proposal is falling on the family category. It is my strong held view, as I have expressed time and time again, that anyone lawfully resident in this country has the right to have their family with them.

The bonds of marriage and family are the foundations of any civilised society. In saying this, I acknowledge, too, that that view is generally held right throughout this parliament and particularly by the last speaker, Senator Short. I feel that to do what this measure is going to do—that is, to keep husbands and wives and parents and children separated—is not appropriate. It is certainly not appropriate for a civilised country which acknowledges that marriage and family are the basic foundation of a civil society. When we look at less fortunate countries and tyrannies, what always moves us to compassion is seeing the break up of families and the separation of people from those whom they love.

I also wish to make a comment about the history of this. Quick and Garran, in their classic The Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth, pointed out on pages 954 and 959 that the founding fathers of this federation expressly denied the Commonwealth power to legislate over citizenship. They feared that to give the Commonwealth power over citizenship was to give it power to make somebody a non-citizen. Only three categories of persons are recognised in the constitution—subjects of the Queen, people of the Commonwealth and people of the state. The High Court has made certain interpretations since then, and we all know that. But the basic principle which should guide us, I believe, is liberality.

Persons who are lawfully in this country and who are subjected to the same taxes and same obligations as the rest of us should be treated no less favourably when it comes to such fundamental questions as the right to have their families reside with them. Senator Short did say there are various views about that matter. Of course there are various views about it—there are something like 900,000 voters on the electoral role who are non-citizens. Take the British migrants for a start; those people who have not bothered taking out citizenship. Senator McKiernan, are you a non-citizen?

TALK.START.PARA: —I wouldn't be here if I were a non-citizen.
—No, you would not. This is quite a serious matter and, of course, there are different views on it. For a start, 900,000 different views from that angle.
—Some of them are Irish as well.

—Yes, some of them are Irish as well. I have a number of cases that relate to this, and I am not going to delay the Senate by raising them all. One specific example from South Australia is a classic. The application of regulation 1.05—the balance of family test—will mean that the people in this example who wanted to get their parents out from the United Kingdom will be unable to do so. The parents were going to make an application two years ago, but the wife of their son contracted cancer and ultimately died this year. When they went to get an application to come out here, they were told, `Well, it's no good now because of the effect of the new regulation.' That new regulation says:

BREAK.PARA: A parent satisfies the balance of family test if:
(b) the number of children of the parent who are lawfully and permanently resident in Australia or are holders of special category visas usually residents in Australia is:
(ii) greater than the greatest number of children of the parent who are resident . . . overseas.

That is ludicrous. For crying out loud! At the moment, it is 50 per cent. They have said `greater than 50 per cent'. I suppose that favours parents with one, three, five or seven children and does not favour those with two, four, six or eight. In any event, you could have a family of six children, with three in Australia, one in the United Kingdom, one in the United States and one in Europe, and you cannot bring the parents out even though all the grandchildren are here—as in this case—because they have not got more than 50 per cent of their children resident in Australia. That is ludicrous. I thought perhaps we could dolly up some taxation‐type amendment that would deem a notional children percentage here or there so as to get these people in.

I have been given the wind‐up. I will not go into the details. The government says it wants to increase the intake of skilled migrants and lower family intake to justify the immigration program to the Australian people. I say very simply—and I make no bones about it—that there ought to be more migrants. I do not think that there should be a cut in the migration program.

I believe migrants are being unfairly made the scapegoats for unemployment in this country. I think governments have to have a look at this question of unemployment, as I have said time and time again, and the previous government too is at fault. You really do have to know what unemployment is. Simply stated, unemployment arises because there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available at the same time as there is downsizing—a euphemism—and cutting of jobs because of technological change and so on. Under those circumstances, you really have to have a look at the participation rate and giving a true freedom of choice to those persons who are in paid work who have better reasons to be out of it so that they can engage in more socially constructive alternatives. I hope the government will ultimately see that.

Finally, I want to say that if we want to engender support for migration to this country, surely the best way to do this is within the family reunion area. It stands to reason. I think the balance that is being proposed by these regulations, which is against family reunions, is not the best way of going about that even though, as Senator Short emphasised, there was that substantial increase last year and the year before.

I will be opposing these regulations. I had intended to try and isolate two of the regulations but I feel that that would be not appropriate and, in one case, impossible. I am supporting the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend my motion No. 1 by deleting reference to regulations 13.5 to 13.9, so that those regulations are not disallowed by the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Delete the words `13.5 to 13.9'.

There is much I could say but I think it is important to get this decided upon before lunchtime, if we can. I agree with Senator Harradine. The previous government was able to achieve migration at the levels that this government claims this program is at without the sorts of draconian, incompetent measures that the government is pursuing through these regulations. The government argues that we had let the program get out of control, while at the same time maintaining that they are sticking to the figures of the previous years.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to indicate that the opposition will be supporting the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. It is always a pleasant contribution to make when I can say that all the measures contained within the bill will be supported by the opposition, which is something that I must say is not a comment I can make on other social security legislation that is before the parliament at this stage.

PARA.BREAK: The opposition, for its part, has facilitated the passage of this non‐controversial legisla tion, and I make the point to the Senate that the opposition supports the four key elements of the bill because in the main this bill is about correcting technical errors and oversights.

SPEECH.PARA: There are four key elements that I will touch on in my brief second reading contribution. Firstly, the bill exempts payments from the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust for people with medically acquired HIV or AIDS; it exempts them from the assets test. I note that these payments are already exempt from the income test.

The bill continues the effect of savings provisions which allow women to be automatically transferred from mature age partner allowance to wife pension when their partner, who was granted mature age allowance before 1 July 1996, is automatically transferred from mature age allowance to age pension.

The bill also continues the effect of savings provisions from a previous measure by replacing references to additional family payment according to the current family payment arrangements. It also corrects an error in the pension rate calculator so that, as is current practice, the income of a person's pension partner can be taken into account under the pensions income test.
As I indicated, in the view of the opposition, this bill is non‐controversial and, fundamentally, it is about correcting technical flaws.
I am sure the Minister for Social Security

(Senator Newman) would be aware—and Senator Tambling as the responsible parliamentary secretary—that the opposition did have some concerns about the beneficiaries of the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust finding out about the concession that is provided to them through this legislation. This is something that the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills also raised and the committee's concerns are able to be looked at by all honourable senators in its Alert Digest of 16 August this year.

I am pleased that subsequently the minister's office has confirmed that trust beneficiaries who have applied for a review of their payment have been paid the adjusted rate of payment in anticipation of this bill being passed. I also understand that, on the request of the opposition, the minister has written to the chair of the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust asking that beneficiaries of the trust be alerted to their rights to ask for a review of their payment and their entitlement to arrears, if any arrears do arise, from the date that they ask for a review. The opposition is satisfied in this case that the minister has done what she is able to do to inform people of the benefits that flow to them as a result of this legislation.

I do not intend to take up more time of the chamber speaking in support of the Social Security Legislation Bill (No. 1) except to say, as I think I mentioned in commencing my remarks on this particular matter, it is nice to see that the government at least got this one right on social security. Of course, other matters of social security legislation before us are a different thing altogether. But this bill is supported by the opposition and I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I thank the opposition for their generous support for these initiatives outlined in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. As Senator Faulkner indicated, the number of issues canvassed by the opposition have been addressed. I know that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, has at all times been keen to cooperate with interested senators in this regard. I am also pleased to acknowledge that a number of these initiatives were initially canvassed by the former government. It is a matter that the current government has been able to pick up and implement as a matter of course and of procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner referred to the fact that the bill provided four important aspects: the issue surrounding the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust; the mature age partner allowance; certain technical matters relating to savings provisions; and amendments relating to the pension rate calculator.

So it is important and, unlike Senator Faulkner, I would trust that the Senate would have particular regard to other social security initiatives that the government will take the opportunity to present to the parliament in the near future. I would not be as cynical as Senator Faulkner, who perhaps indicated that there were threats of a lack of support. I would hope that the arguments relating to social security issues to be canvassed and addressed in the parliament in the coming months will enjoy, as they should, full and wide support from all parties, members and senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
