SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation and the related amendments concern the sale of Commonwealth Funds Management and the possible sale, as I understand it, depending on the tender outcome, of Total Risk Management Pty Ltd. Commonwealth management has approximately 120 employees and TRM has approximately 20 employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to emphasise that what is being sold here is the management fund itself and not the assets of Commonwealth Funds Management that are managed by Commonwealth Funds Management. The funds that are under management—I understand it is $7.5 billion—continue to remain under the ownership of the trustees of the PSS, the CSS and a number of other superannuation fund trustees. I think it is very important to emphasise that.

In fact, the asset valuation of the company itself, Total Risk Management and Commonwealth Funds Management, is about $19 million and that is made up on paper of office fittings. I am not sure whether that includes a building. But it is important to emphasise that particular point. With the sale of Commonwealth Funds Management, and the possible sale of Total Risk Management, the company that successfully tenders to buy will take over the management of the fund's $7.5 billion.

It is important to emphasise that whichever company is successful in winning the contract it does not have that $7.5 billion locked in for any period at all. The trustees, who legally own the moneys, have the right, from the date of the sale, to move the moneys in whatever way suits them, from the successful tenderer to any other private sector funds manager that they see fit. That is in contrast to the sale of the funds management arm of the public sector in New South Wales. I will make another comment on that shortly.

In looking at this particular issue, it is important to understand that, in this country, superannuation moneys are owned by trustees on behalf of the members in the fund. They are owned by the trustees and they are managed by the trustees; and generally—overwhelmingly—trustees subcontract the management of the funds to a large number of private sector funds management companies. In this country, I understand, some 96 or 97 per cent of moneys are managed by private sector funds management companies. With the sale of CFM, a government owned funds manager, to a private sector company, it is not a case of the government funds manager in any sense being able to influence the private sector funds management moneys in this country. The overwhelming majority of moneys are managed by private funds management companies.

The Labor government created Commonwealth Funds Management in 1990 out of the old superannuation fund operations. Regrettably, the record of CFM—and this is a second major factor in our supporting the sale of CFM—could best be described as poor. It ranks 24th out of 28 in the pool of 28 other managed funds in this country. Looking at the average return of CFM in 1994, 1995 and 1996, its return fell below the market average of managed growth funds in each of those three years. Its average return was six per cent over those three years, compared with the market average of 7.3 per cent. Of course, a significant number of funds management companies did much better than 7.3 per cent. Looking at the Intech superannuation performance survey, CFM was ranked 32nd out of 37 superannuation funds in the 12 months to 31 March 1996. CFM's return of 7.2 per cent for that period stands in contrast to that for the first ranked company, ANZ, of 14.2 per cent. That is the second factor in our supporting the sale of CFM.

Thirdly, the union itself—the CPSU—which was originally opposed to the sale of CFM now holds a position of support for the sale of CFM. It does so for a range of reasons, not least of which are the transitional provisions for the continuity of wages, conditions of employment and—in respect of superannuation—entitlements of employees. It also believes that the carry‐over of redundancy provisions stands as a model in the event of any privatisation. For a variety of other reasons, including the lower general return that CFM has experienced over the past three years, the CPSU is not opposed to the sale of CFM.

The other important consideration in supporting the sale of CFM is that there is no possible risk to members' money under management. There is no risk, because the public sector superannuation funds for the vast majority of members are defined benefit funds. Whether an individual who leaves the public sector chooses to take a lump sum or an annuity, the government has guaranteed an outcome because it is a defined benefit fund. If the return of the moneys is not sufficient to meet the amount required for an individual who is leaving the public sector funds, the government has, because the fund is a defined benefit fund, an obligation to meet any particular shortfall. In fact, in this case, given the poorer general returns of CFM, in the longer term the government will save money, as long as whoever purchases CFM is able to obtain a better investment return than CFM has done over the last three years. The government will in fact save money because it is not required to top up whatever the shortfall may be on the budget.

PARA.BREAK: Another factor is that CFM is experiencing a critical problem in maintaining its profes sional expertise, its professional employees. Over the last few months, I, along with a number of other members of caucus, and my staff have met with CFM management and also with the CPSU. We have had discussions with the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey. For the reasons that I have outlined, we are prepared to support the sale of CFM. I know that the reasons I have outlined in support of the sale of CFM stand in stark contrast to those given for the proposed sale of Telstra. We do not believe that they fit into the same category. We do not believe that the sale of CFM even fits into the same category as the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. I do not intend to canvass the issues in respect of the Commonwealth Bank or Telstra, but we believe that they are distinctly different reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The case for CFM no longer remaining in public ownership is overwhelming, in our view. It is not just for the public good, and it is not just for the good of the budget: it is overwhelmingly in the best interests of the members of the various public sector superannuation funds that have their moneys managed by CFM. In consultation with the CPSU on this matter, the complaints that the CPSU has received about CFM have gone to the generally poor return of CFM, and not to the proposed sale of CFM. We accept that the arguments for the sale of CFM are overwhelming. We approach the issue of privatisation on a case by case basis. We do not have any particular ideological disposition to privatisation. As I say, we adopt—for very good reasons—a different approach to Telstra.

PARA.BREAK: The only other point, and I will conclude on it, is a word of warning to the government. In considering this matter, Labor also considered the matter of the administrative section that is responsible for the record‐keeping of public sector workers' superannuation entitlements. I do not know how many employees are involved in that area. They are part of the general Public Service. With the sale of CFM, in respect of this bill, there is no proposal to privatise the administrative section of the work force of the public sector that are involved in the record‐keeping and the processing, et cetera, of the superannua tion records. I would say for the record that, if we are ever presented with such a proposal, we will oppose it. We see the administrative record‐keeping of superannuation entitlements of public sector workers as a proper and legitimate public sector function that should continue in direct public sector ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment I will make is that the New South Wales government is privatising both its funds management arm and the administrative arm, which actually administers the public sector superannuation entitlements of New South Wales public servants. The New South Wales government is providing a guarantee that whoever is the successful tenderer for the funds management arm in New South Wales will receive those funds for, I believe, four years. That is not the case with the sale that we are considering today.

There is no guarantee that the funds will continue to be placed with whoever the successful tenderer is. The only way the successful tenderer can maintain those funds under management is by its better return. If it does not achieve a better return then I have no doubt that the trustees of these moneys will—as I would argue that they have an obligation to—remove those moneys and place them elsewhere to obtain the better return. For those reasons, we support the bill.
Amendments 1, 2 and 3 go to ensuring the continuity of entitlements of the employees of CFM with respect to long service leave. Obviously, we support that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this bill which allows the sale of Commonwealth Funds Management. I opposed the claim of urgency in respect of this bill a few days ago. The reason I did so goes to the heart of legislative process and the process of sale of public assets.

PARA.BREAK: The argument for urgency presented to the Senate was essentially that the employees and buyers of CFM might be disadvantaged and made less secure if the sale was not decided on immediately. I rejected this as an argument for urgency because, if it is accepted, all a government needs to do to create an exception to the cut‐off in the Senate is to an nounce and start the process of sale, and so create uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: But such an announcement—and, effectively, beginning the process of sale prior to approval of parliament—is an affront to the role of parliament and democratic process. In so anticipating and undermining the role of parliament, government acts without authority. For this reason, there is no urgency, can be no urgency.

Prior to a decision to sell a public asset, there should be no moves to sell it, and so no substantial insecurity. Where a government wants to sell an asset, the correct procedure is to go to parliament, get a decision, and only then announce a decision and initiate a process of sale. The process should be made clear to potential buyers. CFM is currently not on the market and may never be. Parliament has not yet decided.

The reality is that, in the push to privatise anything and everything the public own or do, government subverted this process with CFM. The CPSU is the union representing the workers whose money is in the Commonwealth fund as well as those who operate CFM. At this point, the process is so far advanced that the CPSU, which initially opposed the sale, believes that, if the sale is not finalised soon, it will have the potential for adverse impacts on its members. But they are clear that this is because the process was begun in spite of the absence of the authority of parliament.

As to the sale itself, for most people in the Public Service who are fund members the trustee system works reasonably well to give them a voice, and will continue to give them a voice. In many respects, things will not change. The main issue is that now there is a private sector fund owner that will want to make a profit. The option of the Commonwealth making a profit or deciding to transfer all profits to members will, effectively, disappear.

It also raises the issue of the compulsory nature of some superannuation schemes, including the Commonwealth superannuation fund. We are selling the right to profit from public sector workers who are required to join this fund. In effect, as we have noted before, while we do not concede urgency, we do consider this now to be a non‐controversial bill. We do not like the sale, and oppose it, but understand that it will pass and that, in this case, it is a good thing for it to pass quickly. The one thing I would like to ensure is that the process of sale is open and proper and can be scrutinised by the public and by parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition for their support of the CFM Sale Bill and note the comments of Senator Margetts. May I say, in relation to Senator Sherry, that I am pleased to hear the opposition say that it will approach privatisation on a case‐by‐case basis. I think that is appropriate. That is the way the government approaches privatisations. It just surprises me that the question of Telstra does not fit within the Australian Labor Party's framework for privatisation, given that we are disposing of only one‐third of it and that the Commonwealth will, of course, retain control of that particular entity.

SPEECH.PARA: I note Senator Margetts's comments. It was certainly the practice of the previous government, and I think it is the practice of most governments around the world, to announce their proposals and policy in relation to the sale of government assets and then to seek parliamentary approval of them. I think we are pursuing a normal practice in relation to this particular matter.

In relation to CFM itself, this sale is a natural progression from earlier decisions to establish CFM as a funds management company and to end its legislative monopoly. These decisions led to a fundamental change in CFM's role. For example, CFM is no longer the sole funds manager for the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme. CFM's legislative monopoly over the management of the CSS and PSS funds ended on 30 June 1995, under the previous government. CFM's role now extends beyond the management of the superannuation funds of Commonwealth public servants. It has a number of other clients in both the public and the private sectors for which it undertakes wholesale funds management.

I think it is also important for the government to note, for the Senate's benefit, that CFM's functions, from our point of view, are not part of the government's core activities. As the report of the National Commission of Audit indicated, the government business enterprises, whose objectives are to provide goods and services on a commercial basis, should be retained in public ownership only if there is a clear public interest case for doing so. That audit report considered that in a market based economy, which ours clearly is, controlled by a democratically elected government, there are only two primary reasons for government involvement in business: social equity, where the market system is incapable of delivering the social outcomes that the elected government has been given a mandate to achieve; and market failure, which is often associated with monopoly or undue influence through market power. Neither of these reasons is applicable to CFM. The government does not need to have its own funds manager.

The government's decision to sell CFM is, therefore, consistent with the changing role of CFM and the recommendations of the audit commission. The government also considers that the decision will be in the interests of the longer‐term future of CFM. In reaching its decision, the government consulted with the board of CFM, which has fully supported the initiative and which is being closely consulted during the sale process. The sale process is also being undertaken in close consultation with CFM's major clients, particularly the CSS and PSS boards, to enable them to look after the interests of their members. I therefore commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the appropriations bills today I want to look specifically at the impact of the first coalition budget on women and their families. It is a subject that I feel has not received much attention, especially in the media, and it is particularly relevant to work that has been going on now for many years. So I want to give a very brief history lesson on what has happened in previous years with budgetary planning to ensure that 54 per cent of the population is fully considered in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984 the then Labor government introduced Australia's first women's budget. In that budget it announced 20,000 extra child‐care places, new work opportunities for female apprentices, and the home and community care program to assist the elderly and the disabled. Every year since then there has been a specific women's budget which has detailed a range of initiatives, community services and entitlements to benefit women and their families.

These programs have focused on improving equality of opportunity for women and, at the same time, increasing access to health, education, training, employment and legal services. The social safety net has supported families through Medicare, various family allowance payments which have been indexed to maintain their value, the child support scheme and a comprehensive child‐care program offering different types of care and financial support to maintain the quality of child care and assist with the costs of care.

Many of these reforms have been studied by overseas governments researching appropriate models of social justice and gender equity. The Commonwealth secretariat responsible for making suggestions to Commonwealth countries has actually recommended the Australian women's budget process to Commonwealth nations as very well suited to implementing the United Nations Beijing action plan for women.

But what is the future of this process that has been built up over 12 years to highlight the need for gender policy analysis across government, not just in the social welfare programs but in areas such as Environment, Defence and Treasury? The benefit of the women's budget process has been to ensure that when we are planning at the elected level, the policy level and the implementation level the bureaucracy is familiar with gender policy issues. And what has happened just in the last eight months or so?

Already, the Office of Status of Women has been downgraded, with significant reductions in staff, therefore limiting its policy advice and coordination role in maintaining the national women's agenda. We heard in the estimates that the national women's agenda does not exist any more. There is no commitment to maintaining that process. Key initiatives such as the national women's health and family planning programs are set to be devolved to the states which will end the comprehensive and national planning approach to preventive medicine, and reproductive health and domestic violence.

BREAK.PARA: As Adele Horin observed, what is the point of having 26 coalition women in the Federal Parliament when they remain silent in regard to women's rights and the women's budget? I was very disappointed to find that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Newman), who is a minister and a person I admire very much for a range of initiatives she took, in opposition, in relation to women's issues and for a number of issues that she is currently working on, was yet unable to persuade her predominantly male colleagues that it was vital to maintain that women's budget process.

I understand the difficulty of this process because I have been there, done that. I know there is a tendency for certain male colleagues, across the political spectrum, to say, `Oh, women's budget. That is not very important. Why do we have to have a women's budget?' I have heard it on my side of politics. It does not surprise me that this has been a decision from the coalition.

I want to point out just why it is important to restore that women's budget next year. It is very sad that the Australian women's budget process has ceased when the United Nations, the Commonwealth Secretariat, Beijing, various countries around the world have homed in on that process and said, `Wow, if only we could have that process that identifies, across government, the key priorities every year for women and their families. It would make it much easier to ensure that policy is targeting those areas of discrimination that remain and those areas of priority that are so important for women and families.'

The Labor Caucus Status of Women Committee—without the resources of a department—has prepared the only document that exists on the coalition's budget. It is this document that we released just after the budget, called For all of us or just some of us? Impact on Women and their Families of Coalition Government Policy & the 1996 Budget. I am hoping that that work will not be in vain. I would just like to run through a number of the areas where I have significant concern about coalition policies.

I start with aged care. I wonder if the Office of the Status of Women was consulted when some of the decisions were made in relation to aged care: an up‐front fee of from $26,000 for non‐pensioners to be charged for entry to nursing homes; in addition, residents who are not full pensioners to be charged nursing home fees of up to $34 per day or $12,000 per year; from July next year, rent assistance paid to pensioners in nursing homes and aged hostels to be paid instead as higher direct subsidies to the service providers; nursing home and hostel sectors to be merged into a single residential aged care program; and—this concerns me most of all—responsibility for delivery of aged care services to be devolved to the states.

I am sure that some state governments have very effective policies. But aged care, like so many issues in this country, requires a fundamental responsibility of the federal government to set the standards and to maintain a very close role in ensuring that those standards are maintained. I do not believe that devolution to the states of responsibility in the area of aged care will produce the kind of quality or overall standard that Australian senior citizens should be able to expect. We will have a piecemeal approach, an ad‐hoc approach. If you are elderly in one state, that might be fine, you will have better quality. But in another state there will be a lesser priority.

The abolition of operational subsidies for publicly funded child‐care centres is a major concern to many families using child care. And, again—if I can not be totally partisan in commenting on this issue—I know that the Department of Finance tried to abolish this operational subsidy year after year. When I was minister I sat at the cabinet table and, although I should not talk about what happened at the cabinet table, I can tell the Senate that year after year there was a battle to maintain that operational subsidy. To the former government's credit, we were able to maintain that operational subsidy. It seems that in its first year the coalition has had the wool pulled over its eyes: that operational subsidy is not necessary—let it go.

Why is an operational subsidy so important? Again, it is a question of quality; it is a question of national standards; it is a question of ensuring that those children that are more expensive to cater for—babies under two—are cared for. Many of the private child‐care centres, no matter how good they may be, do not choose to care for children under two because of the additional costs. You can understand that from a business point of view. But, if you are running community‐based child care, you are concerned only with the quality and the provision of services to a diversity of categories.

Let us refer to children with special needs. Many community child‐care centres are better placed financially to cater for children with special needs than those private child‐care centres that have to look purely at the economics of running child‐care services. They tend to go for the older age group and the more standard pattern of child care. So there are just two areas, aged care and child care, where I feel that, had there been a more specific approach to women's budgeting, a couple of those decisions may not have proceeded. Let us move on. In this document, I cover community services, education, employment and training. Let us look at the impact of this budget on women. There have been major cutbacks, $1.3 billion over four years, to a number of employment training programs. There is going to be increased cost and wastage through the development of private training markets. There is the cessation of mentoring and support for young women in non‐traditional industries. There will be $6 million worth of savings in the years 1996‐97 and 1997‐98, cutting out altogether the following year. There is a reduction in staff. There is the closure of CES offices. There is the replacement apprenticeship program providing just a fraction of the funds and, to my knowledge, with no specific focus on women as apprentices.

What about the Family Court? Women are very dependent on the effective running of Family Court programs and family court offices. We have seen, particularly in my home state and I am sure in other states, the closure of regional offices with reductions in staff, reductions in hearings, reductions in counselling, an increase in general fees, and a fee of $40 per hour introduced for counselling services. Madam Acting Deputy President, if you are on a tight income—and many people are on tight incomes—and you have to decide whether or not you want to afford counselling, no‐one would deny that you probably should afford it as a priority in your budget, but it will not be surprising if some people choose not to pay that $40 an hour.

We move on to family tax. There was a family tax package, and elements of that family tax package were sold as being of great benefit to women. But the family tax cuts, I would argue, have been offset by increased out‐of‐pocket expenses. There are 1.1 million families with children earning between $30,000 and $65,000 a year who will, over the next four years, lose around $295 per family per year as a result of cuts totalling $1,300 million in vocational education and training, child‐care benefits, parenting allowance, Austudy and, of course, pharmaceutical benefits rebates.

We move on to health. Cuts to public hospital funding of around $1 billion over four years will impact on the quality of health services. The private health insurance rebate of $450 per annum is only available to families paying around $2,000 for cover, leaving them $1,500 per year worse off. The Commonwealth dental program will be scrapped by a cut of $399 million over four years. All these areas will impact severely on women and families.

I could go on to detail what will happen in housing and Medicare, but I want to take a few moments to look at the needs of special groups of women—women who were given a special focus in the days of women's budgeting—such as migrant women. There will be a two‐year waiting period for newly‐arrived migrants to apply for Austudy and the child care cash rebate. The work place English language programs will be abolished. There will be increases in fees for language tuition. There will be a reduction in numbers of the Department of Social Security migration liaison officers.

Another special group is women with disabilities. In Senator Newman's document, which was not a budget itself—it was a women's budget statement—there was no special recognition of women with disabilities. If I could say something positive for a change, it is true that there were good initiatives in regard to women as carers in the coalition's budget. That is one point that I will concede. I am sure you would argue, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that does impact on women with disabilities. But, as a category, there are so many women with disabilities. Under the framework of the women's budget that went out to all the community groups and to individuals, it was very reassuring for special categories of women to see that they rated a mention—there were specific initiatives for women with disabilities.

Similarly, what has been the impact on rural women? The abolition of the regional development program and national oversight of regional development through the division of regional development will impact severely on regional Australia with multi‐million dollar cuts to road funding, community based child care and services to pensioners. The closure of Medicare offices in some country areas and, again, the cuts in the job programs will particularly impact on women in regional areas.

I would like to say, particularly to people like the Treasurer, Peter Costello, and the Prime Minister, John Howard, it is all very well to say `cut back the public sector' and `no need for such an expanded public sector,' if you live in the leafy comfortable suburbs of North Sydney or Melbourne. I doubt whether Mr Costello, Mr Howard and their families have a need for public services, and that is fine. But many families in other suburbs of those major cities—and certainly the major regional and rural centres—have just started to benefit from a decentralisation of services to regional Australia. When you cut back the public sector in the cities, sure, it makes a difference. But when you cut back in regional Australia, the services simply disappear.

PARA.BREAK: Madam Deputy President, I would be very happy to make sure that every woman mem ber and any other member on the other side have a copy of this document. It does provide a serious analysis of where the coalition government has gone wrong, particularly in regard to the impact of its budget on women. I hope that Senator Newman and other women members of the government will take a serious look at this document in their own policy making fora and will consider the return of the women's budget next year. I think it would certainly benefit the coalition government—which is perhaps no comfort to me—but, more importantly, it would certainly benefit women and their families to see the return of the women's budget so that we have a much more serious analysis of the impact of government policy‐making on women and families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the debate on the Appropriation Bills, which give effect to the government's first budget, to say that these documents are documents of deceit. They give with one hand and they sneakily take away with the other. The changes reduce services and they hike charges. But the hikes in charges and the loss of services are very often difficult to detect because, for the most part, they do not take effect until after 1 July 1996 or, in some cases, until even later.

SPEECH.PARA: It really heaps scorn on the charter of budget honesty when you see that there is no real honesty in this budget and that in fact it is a document that deceives the community. This is a budget that breaks $17 billion worth of promises made by the coalition government during the election and subsequently. The basis of the budget is dishonest, as well. In its slash and burn cuts, it relies on a purported $10 billion deficit that the government says is the responsibility of the previous Labor government. This is certainly not the case.

If the government were honesty and if they were to have regard to the charter of budget honesty, there would be a concession that $3½ billion of that deficit is as a direct result of decisions made by this Senate, prior to the election. If they were being honest about this budget and about these appropriation bills, they would concede that a similar sum accumulated in this deficit is as a result of the declining economic growth brought about by the policies of this government. As you would well be aware, as economic growth reduces, not only does revenue decline but also outlays in terms of social security and social services go up.

Further, the intended effect of this budget is dishonest in that they say that, by reducing the deficit, they will bring about economic growth and, accordingly, jobs. But already the policies of this government have destroyed the hard won gains of 13 years of Labor. While keeping inflation low by putting in place mechanisms of wages restraint and by improving productivity and, at the same time, achieving an unmatched level of job growth, Labor maintained economic growth at approximately 3½ per cent. Already, this government has abandoned these gains and they have returned to the tired old formula. First, there are slash and burn cuts, with no regard to the consequences. This in turn brings about a decline in economic growth; and then—surprise, surprise!—as we have already seen, unemployment goes up.

In the last three months, we have seen increasing unemployment, and I sadly predict that that will exceed 10 per cent by the new year and that it will, at some time during next year, reach heights of 11 per cent. Unless this government changes its economic objectives—that is, its old economic objectives of low inflation, maintained by declining employment—then unemployment will continue to grow thereafter.

To find further examples of budget dishonesty, you really do not have to go very far, because you can take a brief peek at the budget speech delivered on the 20 August by Mr Costello, the Treasurer. We can go through some of the issues that he has highlighted as the positives in this budget but, when you look very closely, you see that he has not given you the downside: he has not given you the negatives that go with it.

The first item put forward is the government's family tax initiatives. They are a good thing and we on this side of the chamber agree with them. However, the Treasurer, when putting forward these tax initiatives for families, did not outline the negatives that are secretly contained in the budget. As I said, often they will not have an effect until after the end of this financial year or perhaps even longer than that.

There are cuts of $1.5 billion to the states overall. If people do not think that that is going to affect the standard of services that are provided to the community, and the charges that are levied for those services, they are not being honest with themselves. Certainly, it is going to mean that people in each state of Australia will be paying more, well in excess of the paltry amount that they will be receiving from the government's tax initiative. And that is before you take into account the cuts to child care, the reducing eligibility for child‐care assistance, the child‐care rebate and the cuts to operational subsidies which will mean that, in community based child‐care centres, each child will be paying approximately $25 more.

The next item set out in the budget, and heralded by the Treasurer, is the private health insurance subsidies. A lot of people took heart from this and thought that it would mean more money in their pockets but, as we have seen with approvals by this government of 5.1 per cent in health insurance premiums, the small amount of dollars from the subsidies have been eaten up well before they come into effect on 1 July next year.

Let us look at the next item heralded with enthusiasm by the Treasurer. In relation to older Australians he says that there will be a continuing twice yearly indexation of pensions and that they will make financial provision to maintain the age pension at or above 25 per cent. People might even think that this is a new initiative of this government but, in fact, it is something that we, as a Labor government, had been doing for quite some time. It is a good thing and this opposition supports it. However, the Treasurer failed to point out for older Australians the negative things that are contained in this budget.

He forgot to point out that, for pharmaceutical benefits, pensioners and concession card holders will have to pay an additional 50c on each occasion that they fill a prescription. He failed to point out that that increase in the pharmaceutical copayment would no longer be offset by the pensioner's pharmaceutical allowance, which is incorporated in their pension, that for the first time this government had chosen to break the nexus between pharmaceutical copayments and the pensioner's pharmaceutical allowance.

He also failed to point out that, even though the pension was being maintained, the government is intending allowing nursing homes to introduce fees. That entry fee is estimated—obviously the fee is a secret because no‐one, including the nursing homes, have been given any details of the fee—to be, on average, if you extrapolate the entry fees taken for hostels, at about $26,000.

When questioned about the fee and about the $26,000—this is one of the cruelest and rudest comments I have heard from this government—the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) said, `Even though it is $26,000, most people will not have to pay it because it only comes into effect after six months and most people die before that time.' He also failed to point out that the HACC services, which the frail and elderly in our community access, will have payments imposed on them as well so, all in all, older Australians are not better off; they are pretty poorly off as a result of this budget.

Another benefit promised by the Treasurer on 20 August was for regional Australia. He talked about increasing assistance to isolated students. The amount is quite small but it is something we should applaud, as an opposition concerned about regional Australia and about those people who are adversely affected by isolation. He failed to say anything about the increase in HECS payments. He failed to point out that eligibility for Austudy would be reduced—
