Minister, home owners and small businesses have welcomed the significant savings resulting from the latest reductions. But I understand and would imagine that the benefits go beyond small business people and home owners. Could you indicate to the Senate the positive effects that the Reserve Bank's decision would have on farmers in rural and regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, this was good news for all Australians—home owners, small business, as well as the rural community. There is no doubt about that. In fact, the variable mortgage rates are now 8.75 per cent, which is down from the 10.5 per cent when Labor was defeated in March of this year. Good news for Australians—and no doubt related, to some extent, to the hard but important decisions that we took in relation to the budget to rein in public expenditure.

ANSWER.PARA: It is pleasing to see that mortgage lenders such as FAI, Aussie Home Loans, ANZ and Westpac have announced that they will pass on to home owners the full 0.5 per cent drop. It is worth understanding that for average mortgages this means that these people are now $140‐plus per month better off. So, since Labor, home owners are now $140 a month better off. Good reason to have voted for the coalition, I would think.

Terry McCrann points out today that the average borrower with a $100,000 loan is now saving around $2,700 a year in interest payments. He said, `This is a permanent saving adding around $2.5 billion extra a year in borrowers' pockets.' That is a huge sum of money.

Senator Macdonald may be interested to know that, in real terms, these figures are now down to those that last existed about 22 years ago. The 13 years of Labor misery is behind us. We are now able to achieve home loan interest rates in figures that existed a long time ago. As I said, I have no doubt that our policies of low inflation and keeping public expenditure down, together with growth, have to some extent influenced the Reserve Bank to make this decision.

It is pleasing that the community tends to respond positively to these hard decisions that we have taken. Madam President, you might have noticed that the Reuters poll trend published today shows that growth in support for the government has been rising decisively since the budget. That is really quite interesting. The two-party preferred lead moved even more strongly from seven or eight points to 14 points, implying a strong swing to the government among minor party supporters.

Senator Ian Macdonald went on to specifically ask about the benefits that would flow to rural and regional communities. I said that it is also clearly good news for them. That has been applauded. The New South Wales Farmers Federation has said that the official rate cut would allow annual interest repayments on total farm debt of $18 billion to fall by about $90 million. That is clearly good news for farmers. If banks pass on the cuts in full, this will result in cost reductions of an estimated $90 million annually. That is why we say that they need to be passed on fully and quickly.

This reduction comes at a critical time for the farm sector. Many are now in the recovery phase after the drought. I remind the Senate of the extra assistance we have been giving those in drought. Be they in or out of drought, a lower interest rate gives them the opportunity to grow and put themselves in a stronger economic position to take full advantage of seasonal rains and to try to restore the important prosperity of that vital sector of our community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given that you have indicated in your answer to my first question that you are aware of the Commonwealth Public Service Guidelines on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants , I wonder whether you are also aware that those same guidelines state clearly:

QUESTION.PARA: Outside employment is to be performed wholly in the public servant's private time.

In view of this, can you give the Senate a cast‐iron, categorical assurance that Mr Moore-Wilton has performed the duties associated with his $50,000 a year job and those associated with his $30,000 a year job outside the hours required for his $215,000 a year job? In other words, has Mr Moore-Wilton complied with his own guidelines?

TALK.START.PARA: —The rules that I specifically looked at were the statutory provisions applying to Commonwealth public servants under both the Remuneration Tribunal Act and the Public Service Act, to clarify that aspect. As to the terms of compliance with his duty obligations, I am sure that that is properly monitored by the Prime Minister. From my own observations, I have some idea how hard Mr Moore-Wilton has been working in the best interests of the government and the Public Service.
—How are you sure?
—I have witnessed him working many hours of overtime. If that is an indication, I am sure that the taxpayer is getting full value for its expenditure in relation to his remuneration.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister whether Mr Moore-Wilton, as the Prime Minister's chief investigative officer, will now be tasked not only to revise the key elements of ministerial responsibility but also the Public Service guidelines in order to escape his embarrassment in flouting them. Hasn't the Prime Minister, with a wink and a nod to Mr Moore-Wilton, effectively con signed these Public Service guidelines to the same fate as the now defunct ministerial guidelines which Mr Moore-Wilton is himself responsible for reviewing?

—I do not accept that he has been flaunting the guidelines. I also do not accept the categorisation of chief investigative officer. As I have said, the Prime Minister is responsible for the employment of the secretary. I am sure that he is satisfied with his performance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, tomorrow you will be holding a meeting of federal, state and territory youth ministers. Could you outline the aims of the meeting and the government's commitment to young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for such a positive question. It makes a refreshing change from what comes from those opposite. The coalition has a very strong commitment to Australia's young people, clearly evidenced by the fact that the Prime Minister is prepared to put a minister in cabinet with responsibility for youth affairs and by our plans to assist young people which are outlined in our youth statement entitled Young people shaping the future . It is something I highly recommend to senators opposite. Tomorrow I will be hosting a meeting of state and territory youth affairs ministers. This is an important part of our commitment. The meeting will be an opportunity to work together cooperatively to help make young Australians a national priority.

ANSWER.PARA: We have some of the best educated and healthiest young people that this country has ever seen. We should be celebrating young people's achievements in all fields, such as education, employment, sport, culture and the arts. However, all too often, our young people are, sadly, perceived quite negatively. The media shares some responsibility for this. Young people are often stereotyped. A 1992 New South Wales study by the Australian Centre for Independent Journalism on how youth were represented in magazines and newspapers found that most coverage concerned their involvement in criminal activity.

Other problems include the very high rate of youth suicide. Statistics show that from 1994, 377 young men and 60 young women suicided before reaching their 25th birthday. The high rate of youth unemployment must also be very discouraging for young people and is one of this government's highest priorities. We are determined to raise the status of young people generally, to celebrate their success and to ensure that all young people have the opportunity to participate to the best of their abilities in society.

Our strategy is to increase opportunities through sustained economic growth, a reduced budget deficit, industrial relations reforms and help for small business to realise its potential to employ more young people, along with programs which are specifically targeted to assist young people. They include improving literacy and numeracy, provision of real, quality career paths through the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system and an increase in the number of government funded undergraduate places at Australian universities next year.

Tomorrow's meeting is an opportunity for youth ministers across the country to show leadership to send the right message to our young people that governments are determined to focus on their concerns. It is important to acknowledge that a large amount of work has already been done by the states, territories and the Commonwealth in this area. However, there are young people who live in circumstances that are far from ideal and youth ministers together must ensure that the most disadvantaged are assisted.

One of the issues I will be discussing with my state and territory colleagues is youth homelessness. Many reports have indicated that this is one of the subjects that we need to focus on. The Commonwealth is clearly showing the way in a range of programs that we are supporting, not the least of which is the JPET program and the homeless youth pilot program.

I would say more about this, but I see that the clock is ticking and I may not have time to conclude. We are in fact showing the way with the JPET program and the homeless youth pilot program. They are Commonwealth initiatives that we are supporting. I intend to explore the opportunities for the states—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can you inform the Senate how much time Mr Max Moore‐Wilton has spent, since taking up his position as Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, on duties associated with his $50,000 job with the Victorian Public Transport Corporation and his $30,000 job with Southern Hydro Pty Ltd? Can the minister also provide the Senate with the details of meetings Mr Moore‐Wilton has attended in relation to these jobs? Finally, will the minister give an assurance that the Commonwealth government has in no way subsidised—in terms of airfares, travel allowance or absence from official duties—Mr Moore‐Wilton's activities in relation to these jobs?

—You will not be surprised, Madam President, to learn that I do not have all of that detail at hand. I will refer it to the Prime Minister and see whether he wishes to provide any further information.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps you might consider answering this, Minister, or refer it to the Prime Minister, and give further consideration to the Guidelines on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants : can you confirm that the Southern Hydro board met on Monday, 9 September at 1.30 p.m. and on Friday, 1 November in the afternoon? Did Mr Moore‐Wilton attend those meetings? Can you also confirm that the board of the Victorian Public Transport Corporation meets on a weekday once a month? How many of these meetings has Mr Moore‐Wilton attended since he became Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet?
—Obviously, I do not know when these meetings occur. I will refer it to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABC: Televising of Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has the minister, since July this year, written to the ABC on at least 25 occasions about the telecast of the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras? Has the minister taken to writing to the ABC personally with each individual complaint he receives? Did the minister unsuccessfully complain to the Privacy Commissioner because the ABC had asked the Australian Graduate School of Management to examine all the letters written in 1994 to the ABC prior to the first telecast of the mardi gras? Did the AGSM conclude that the ABC had been subject to an organised letter writing campaign which was not representative of widespread community opinion? Is the minister assisting in such an organised campaign prior to the possible 1997 telecast based on his own ideological position? Does the minister still stand by his statement that he is not attempting to influence the ABC in its programming? Why are the 60 complaints he received about the mardi gras worthy of such extraordinary personal attention when he has chosen to ignore the 17,000 letters he has received about the ABC budget cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a lot of questions in there. There were certainly some about which I have absolutely no knowledge. Indeed, to suggest there has been some organised campaign in relation to the telecasting of the mardi gras is certainly beyond my knowledge and I certainly have not participated in any such campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: What I did do several years ago, as I am sure is well known, is that I requested the ABC to consider scheduling the telecast at a later timeslot. Indeed, as I recall, the ABC received very many letters to that effect. I have not at any time sought to renew that particular request or make any personal representations on the issue. What I did do, however, after I had received a lot of letters on this subject, was to write and inquire whether the ABC had any plans for either discontinuing the telecast or scheduling it at a later time. The suggestion that somehow this issue has had special attention is simply incorrect.

My standard practice—and I am sure it was that of my predecessor—has been to refer letters of complaint to the ABC. Many people would write direct to Brian Johns. If they write to me, I invariably send him a copy of the letter drawing the matter to his attention. I can give you a couple of examples. A number of the complaints that come to my department are raised by them with the ABC and are then able to be incorporated in answers that we give to people who write in.

There have been occasions and I have one example. The ABC wrote to me on 28 October saying that the ABC had received a large number of complaints about one episode of Backchat. The inclusion of the particular footage in question was clearly an error of judgment as there were no warnings given to viewers and an inadequate explanation of the context. That sort of response is not unusual. The head of ABC television directed an on‐air apology be broadcast in relation to the same episode of Backchat, or it may have been another one. There have been other examples or occasions where the ABC has been able to advise the department, and I have therefore advised those who have written to me, that the ABC has taken corrective action.

It is not unusual for any broadcaster to concede on reflection with the benefit of hindsight that some programs were either in poor taste or may indeed have been treated in other ways or warnings might have been given. There is nothing unusual about what has occurred on this occasion. Indeed, I think it is my duty to ensure that the ABC is fully aware of all of the complaints that are made against it. Otherwise, as far as it knows things are going along smoothly, when in fact there are a lot of people complaining directly and who may have taken the view that there is no point in complaining to the ABC any more. Indeed, to the extent that their complaints system does not always allow for a satisfactory reply to be given, it is not unusual for people to think that there is no point in complaining to the cause of the problem. Therefore, they write to others, including the minister.

BREAK.PARA: What I have done on each of those occasions is to ensure that the ABC is fully apprised of the problem. Where there are recurrent letters, as there have been in relation to the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, I took the view that it was time—some seven months down the track—to ask a general question about whether they had any intention of changing the programming or, indeed, the time of the programming. It seems to me that that is a little more pro‐active than simply pretending that each individual complaint is dealt with in isolation. When you have got enough complaints to form the basis for a general inquiry, then it seems to me that that is a prudent approach to take, and I did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. However, arising out of it he mentioned two things. First of all, he said he wrote and inquired of the ABC about complaints he received. Did he do that on every occasion on which he received a letter about the mardi gras, at least since July this year? Does he do that with every single letter of complaint that he gets about the ABC? Did he do that with every one of the 17,000 letters he received about budget cuts? Secondly, on the complaints system, where he said that he does not believe it is a particularly good one or words to that effect, does he not agree that the ABC's complaints system is in fact a lot better than the commercials'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that there may well be people who take the view that the ABC's complaints system is not adequate and therefore there is no point in them writing direct and they write to me. The practice that I believe has been adopted by the department and by me is to refer each letter to which I reply personally to the ABC. In other words, I personally write a letter to Brian Johns saying, `Enclosed please find a copy of a letter of complaint from Fred Smith.'

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot give you a categoric assurance that each and every complaint that has come into the department or to my office has been handled in that way, but that is my understanding of the practice. As far as the 17,000 complaints which you say were received in relation to budget cuts, I am sure you will not be surprised to hear that I have not managed to write to 17,000 people or indeed at all. I think the department may have replied to some of those. You will understand that, if we were to devote the work of officers to responding to what in many cases are routine letters, then we would not be able to attend as expeditiously as we do to the many important policy issues that you and others raise. If you would like to take your choice, if you would like us to respond in great detail to every single letter, then I am sure that we might be able to come to an accommodation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Vanstone representing the Attorney‐General. Can the minister confirm that an Australian Federal Police investigation has proven that the claim by the member for the Northern Territory, Mr Dondas, that he obtained confidential material from the electoral data in the Northern Territory prior to the recent federal election from `a source in the Australian Electoral Commission' was proven to be utterly false? Can the minister also confirm that the investigation found that a person or persons unknown in the Department of the Chief Minister in the Northern Territory provided the material to a Brisbane based firm, Feedback Services, which provides data related services to the Liberal Party of Australia, who then passed this material back to the Country Liberal Party in the territory for use by Mr Dondas? Because the Australian Federal Police have no jurisdiction to pursue what happened to the material once it was provided to the Northern Territory authorities, will the federal government release the AFP report and support calls for an independent inquiry into the misuse of Australian Electoral Commission data in the Northern Territory by the Northern Territory authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any knowledge of the matters that you raise. I remind you—and I am sure you are aware—that it is common practice by others, and I am not suggesting you, to raise assertions about police investigations and, the assertions having been raised, therefore claim that all the material should be released. That is not necessarily a most helpful task in law enforcement.
—It has been all over the news for the last 24 hours.

—But you are asking for material that apparently is not all over the news, otherwise you would not be asking me for something to be released. I am just indicating to you that I will refer your question to the Attorney and no doubt he will reply in due course.
—Madam President, my question—

—I raise a point of order. Madam President, I note that Senator Brown is not observing the accepted dress code. I seek your guidance on what the situation is and whether that rules his question out of order.

—Madam President, this matter was debated on one occasion when I came into this chamber attired in exactly the same way as Senator Brown is now—which is, Senator Brown, the acceptable form of dress for the Northern Territory's parliament and is why I had come in here similarly attired. I might add, the Israeli cabinet do not wear ties or coats. On that occasion I was advised that dress was a matter for the good sense of individual senators.
—I also would like to speak to this point of order.
—I would like to hear you.
—Thank you, Madam President. Uncomfortable as it might be, I would like to dob in my colleague Senator Gibbs, who is not wearing a jacket either.
—Madam President, I take the point that has just been made: if some rule is to apply, customary or otherwise, it must apply equally to all members of the Senate.

—The situation at the present time is that there is a custom that clothes will be worn in the Senate. It has also been the custom that gentlemen wear jackets. Senator Brown this morning gave notice of a motion that this custom be abandoned. I suggested to him that he should honour the custom until such time as the Senate changes it. He has chosen not to do so.
—Thank you, Madam President. My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs—

—Madam President, on a point of order: unless I misheard your ruling, you were saying, in effect, that Senator Brown was out of order and that he should comply with the ruling until such time as the Senate changes the rules. Am I incorrect in thinking that?
—I said that I had suggested to Senator Brown in a note that he ought to honour the custom, which he acknowledges, until such time as it is changed. He has chosen not to.
—He has chosen to ignore the custom of the Senate. That is clear, is it? Right.

—Thank you, Madam President. My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister would be aware that next Sunday, 10 November, is a national day of action in Australia on the anniversary of Ken Saro‐Wiwa's murder in Nigeria. The Minister would also be aware of the atrocious role of Shell in the regime of terror in Ogoniland, including its supply of weapons to the Nigerian police earlier this decade. Can the minister say what the value of the federal government's contracts with Shell is, including for petrol in Commonwealth cars? Will the federal government suspend dealing with Shell until it shows by its actions that it is a responsible corporate citizen globally and, in particular, is prepared to negotiate with the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People and use its influence with the Nigerian government to free Ogoni political prisoners, including the so‐called Ogoni Nineteen who, for almost 12 months, have been living day to day with the prospect of summary execution. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I think there are two parts to the question. The first is Senator Brown's attack on a transnational corporation, which reflects a prejudice that he holds in general in relation to commercial operations of this type. In condemning Shell, perhaps he could have looked at the other side of the ledger and recognised that Shell in Nigeria has implemented a $100 million environment assistance program in Ogoniland, as well as a $20 million per annum community assistance program for the Ogoni people.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from Senator Brown's using this question as an excuse to attack Shell, there is within the question an important issue, and this is the continuing unsatisfactory behaviour of the regime in Nigeria. We, as a government, condemn the systematic violation of human rights by that regime. We particularly condemned the execution of Ken Saro‐Wiwa and eight other activists last November, and joined in the decision to suspend Nigeria from the Commonwealth in response.

We believe that the suspension from the Commonwealth has helped to isolate and embarrass the Nigerian regime. We use this sad occasion of the anniversary of the death of Ken Saro‐Wiwa to reiterate our concerns and to refocus our energies in relation to the Nigerian regime, particularly the efforts to compel it to comply with the international community's standards of proper behaviour. We will continue to look for ways to achieve that goal.

We monitor the work of the Commonwealth Action Group on Nigeria. We are not a member of the group but we monitor its work. We notice that it is due to visit Nigeria again in the next few weeks. We have discussed the issue of sanctions and we will continue to do that as the Commonwealth seeks to develop a position on that particular matter.

The bottom line is that the performance of the regime remains unsatisfactory. It does not reach the human rights behavioural levels which we, as international citizens, are entitled to expect. We will continue to look for ways in which Australia can work constructively with others towards pressing the Nigerian regime to behave better towards its citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister, for that answer. You mentioned focusing efforts with this anniversary pending on Sunday. I ask: could you be more specific about that focus? In particular, will the government be making direct representations to the Nigerian representatives in this country and to the President of Nigeria for the release of political prisoners, particularly the Ogoni Nineteen? Will the government be approaching Shell to ensure that it never again involves itself in actions like the purchase of arms to equip the Nigerian police?

—Again, Senator Brown wants to return to an attack on Shell. I could go through the whole of Shell's corporate history in Nigeria and give you a balanced assessment if you wish, Senator Brown. But I doubt very much that that is what you would wish to get from this debate. I am sure that Mr Downer will continue to make the representations that you refer to towards the goal that you are seeking in relation to the release of political prisoners.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Minister, are you aware that the Minister for Finance continues to declare in his register of interests that he is both a director and shareholder in Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd? Are you further aware that this company was deregistered on 8 December 1992 due to the company failing to lodge annual returns for seven years, in direct breach of section 335(1A) of the Corporations Law? Furthermore, can the minister seek advice as to whether, at the time of deregistration, there were any outstanding loans to the directors of Lochreagh, of which Mr Fahey was one? If there were, can the minister seek advice on the tax implications of such an outstanding loan?

—In relation to the matters raised by Senator Forshaw, I am not aware of the facts which you have stated. I do not know whether those facts are correct or not. I will refer those matters to the Minister for Finance and see whether he has any response that he wishes to make.

—I have a supplementary question. I hear the minister's answer but, Minister, could you also inform us, on the basis that it is the position, whether it is appropriate for a senior Howard government minister, through such conduct, to so flagrantly breach the Corporations Law, or is it just another clerical oversight on the part of this bumbling and incompetent finance minister?

—I do not accept the basic assumption behind the supplementary question but, as far as bumbling is concerned, I think you should go no further than the people on your own side. When have we seen one sensible policy statement out of that lot over there since March? The answer is: not once. So, as far as bumbling is concerned, I would say to you: `Physician, heal thyself.'

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. This morning, the shadow Treasurer and acting opposition leader, Mr Evans, said that today's job figures `would wipe the smile off the Treasurer's face.' In light of today's employment figures indicating a record number of people in employment on a trend basis, in tandem with yesterday's official interest rate reduction and the excellent inflation figures, would the minister say whether the budget forecasts are on track—and if you are smiling about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —On the way over here, I did pass the Treasurer, and he was still smiling—and rightly so. He has brought down a very successful budget which has been very well received by the public and regarded as a very fair budget. We have had recent figures in relation to low inflation and moderate wage growth, and we have the figures out today in relation to employment growth. Of course, there are a large number of figures showing how interest rates are tumbling, which is a huge advantage to first home buyers and to people in small business.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the Treasurer is concerned, I am sure that he is well pleased with the information which has come out for the Australian economy in the last week, as indeed I believe are the Australian people. As far as the shadow treasurer is concerned, I suspect he is wiping egg off his face at this very moment. And so he should be. I noticed that not long ago, on 28 October, former Senator Evans, now Mr Evans, shadow treasurer and acting leader of the Labor Party—boy, how the Labor Party has really fallen—said that the government would need—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is going well.

—Listen to this. This your acting leader of the Labor Party; this is the person whom you put into that senior position. He said that we would need 17,000 jobs for October to meet the budget employment forecast. How did we go? We had 25,500 jobs in October. So we have more than met the high jump bar that Mr Evans put for us—and with ample room to spare. I am pleased to point out to this chamber that employment has now risen in six of the past seven months. Job vacancy data continues to point to continued growth over the period ahead.

ANSWER.PARA: There is more good news than the jobs data. Yesterday, I pointed out to this chamber that several financial institutions were moving quickly to pass on the benefit of the official interest rate cut. Many of the non-bank home loan lenders are now offering home mortgage rates of around eight per cent—the lowest rates offered on home loans in two decades. We are now also in sight of the lowest rates offered by banks on their standard home loans for some two decades. The September consumer price index showed that we have put ourselves in the low inflation groove—low interest rates, low inflation, good jobs data, an excellent budget. No wonder the government is enjoying very strong support in the polls.
Thank you for that question. I know of your continuing interest in the interest rate issue. I am pleased to say that the government is fully on track.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Hill. I refer to the Liberal Party's $895 a head one day fundraiser in Melbourne on 26 November. Are you aware that this seminar is designed to provide busi nesses and organisations with practical advice, assistance and training in how to deal best with the new government? What kind of information not currently available to the ordinary battler will be provided to those privileged few able to buy positions at this seminar? Do you think it is appropriate for the chair of a government body, Professor Allan Fels of the ACCC, to be asked to speak at a party fundraiser? Will the Commonwealth be compensated for all costs associated with his participation?
—I must concede that because of the row on the other side I missed the tail end of that question.

—I will repeat it. Do you think it is appropriate for the chair of a government body, Professor Allan Fels of the ACCC, to be asked to speak at a party fundraiser? Will the Commonwealth be compensated for all costs associated with his participation?

—I was reflecting on why the questions today do not relate to matters of important public interest. I guess it is because there is no question they could ask on interest rates today; there is no question they could ask on taxes because we are keeping our promises—family taxes are coming down; there is no question they could ask on inflation because inflation is coming down; and there is no question they could ask on industrial relations because there is an excellent industrial relations package before the Senate at this time. So we are on these frolics, these excursions, into matters of irrelevancy.
—Try to answer the question now.

—The first point I would make is that when we used to ask that sort of question the answer always was that those fundraisers are entirely legitimate and serve a useful public purpose. The first part of the answer is that the fundraiser is entirely legitimate and serves a useful public purpose.
—I never saw the head of a government authority there.

—It is an opposition question and if Professor Fels believes that it is an opportunity for him to impart information that will benefit those attending this function then I have no quarrel with that either.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What is your current view of the propriety of such fundraisers, given your trenchant and hypocritical criticisms in opposition of the Labor Party's use of such events? Can you inform the Senate what disclosure provisions apply to those attending and paying $895 to the Liberal Party?
—I have already told you. My view on reflection is that they are entirely legitimate. The disclosure provisions are set out in the appropriate regulations.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Vanstone. There has been some difficulty in following the figures in relation to schools funding. This is partly because the Senate education committee whose job it is to scrutinise these matters was not provided with copies of DEETYA's submission until late the night before the hearing last Friday. I have now had more time to consider these figures and I refer you to my expanded version of table 3 of the submission, a copy of which you now have. Does the government now expect enrolments in government schools to drop by 23,524 and enrolments in private schools to increase by 94,551 by the year 2000? Will the minister confirm that, even though the number of students lost to government schools is just 23,000, the enrolment benchmark adjustment will be calculated on the basis of more than 73,000 new private school students and that this means a deduction from government schools of $305 million? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that question. There has been something of an extraordinary campaign of disinformation being waged by the Labor Party—
—Led by you.
—Order! Senators on my left should cease interjecting.

—and some lobbies on the government's budget decisions as they affect funding for schools. The fundamental facts are that, on the estimates in the budget, government school funding increases absolutely and per capita over the next four years. This is the case even though the budget estimates are based on an assumption of a fall of 23,524 in government school enrolments between 1996 and the year 2000. There is an increase in specific purpose payments for government schools when financial assistance grants are taken into account.
—Oh! Suddenly we have got FAGs taken into account.
—Senator Carr!

—An estimated additional $2.3 billion in Commonwealth moneys will flow to government schools to the year 2000 over 1996. Funding per government school pupil will rise, taking these assumptions into account, to 17.9 per cent compared with non-government per capita increases of 14.9 per cent. These increases will absolutely overwhelm any impact of the adjustment to government school funding which will arise from the loss of pupils. In other words, to focus on the enrolment benchmark adjustment is to focus on a very small part of the funding. Overall, funding is going up and there is good news for schools. Any suggestion that government schools are losing resources is simply untrue.
—You are the education minister. You would think you would know more about it.
—Senator Carr, you will cease interjecting.

—In the Labor Party's fear and loathing campaign that Senator Carr cannot keep himself away from the shadow minister for education has claimed that decisions of the last Premiers Conference will mean a loss to government schools of some $300 million. It is time that he put himself in touch with reality again. On the best information available to us, state and territory funding, through their own budgets for education, show increases in funding to government schools. Like the Commonwealth, the states and the territories have taken the view that school funding is a top priority.
—Just like Victoria, eh?
—Order! Senator Carr, you have been interjecting constantly. There is an opportunity after question time for you to take part in a debate.

—Those who are tramping around Australia telling lies should stop and think about what is likely to be the consequence of their actions. They are telling parents that government schools are likely to decline because their funds are declining. They are telling parents that government schools are going to be residualised and that they will be damaged beyond repair. These remarks they keep making are all false and damaging for government schools, for the students in them and for enrolments in them.

ANSWER.PARA: The Labor Party and a number of their fellow travellers are in a complete state of confusion. They say they want to protect government schooling, but all they do is go and talk it down. As I understand it, they now want to amend our legislation in the Senate in a way which will actually have the effect of doubling the incentive for states to move students out of government schools and into non-government schools. With friends like those opposite, what government schools would need enemies?
This government is deeply committed to quality government schools, choice for parents, and schools in non-government and government areas that meet the needs of students.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is clear from your answer that we still both believe that we are right in our interpretation of these figures. Given that the proper place to determine the matter would be the Senate education committee, will you request the coalition majority on this committee to schedule a further hearing so that we can get to the bottom of the matter? This is something the chair has so far refused to do.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, in relation to your request, if you have got some trouble understanding this, I will make sure that the departmental officials and Dr Kemp or someone from his office—one of his senior advisers—spend as much time as you want with you because this is a policy change, I acknowledge that, and, unlike senators opposite, you are in fact showing some interest in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: You do invite me by your question to remind Senator Carr, lest he express such surprise at putting together specific purpose payments and FAGs, that in November last year he quoted the Australian Education Union figures, which did just that—quoted them positively—and used them as an explanation for why the previous government was giving more money to schools. He has added them together himself. That is another example of the sort of fickle approach we have from senators opposite, who will say anything and do anything to get a headline. You really are a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is it true that, as reported in the 21 October edition of the Australia‐ Israel Review , the Queensland division of the Liberal Party has claimed the $55,000 matching funding subsidy available from the Australian Electoral Commission for the votes obtained by the member for Oxley in the 2 March election? Has the Australian Electoral Commission or the Liberal Party received any correspondence from the member for Oxley or her solicitors disputing the Liberal Party's claim?
—I thank the senator for his question. He has raised a number of issues, and I will refer those issues to the Minister for Administrative Services and see if we can give him a response.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, in view of the non‐answer.
—How can you have a supplementary if there is no answer?

—There is. If it is the case that there was correspondence, will you be able to advise the Senate of the basis on which the Liberal Party's claim was made and whether the Australian Electoral Commission has made a determination on this issue?
—Of course we will seek to advise the Senate on any information we have that can help you in providing an answer to that question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Can the minister advise of any measures he intends to take to protect the important environmental values of Shoalwater Bay, particularly in relation to its dugong population?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can. Shoalwater Bay contains perhaps the most important population of dugong remaining in the southern Great Barrier Reef. Many senators will be aware of the substantial decline in dugong numbers in the southern Great Barrier Reef area—a decline of between 50 and 80 per cent since 1986-87. By 1994 the dugong population had plummeted to an estimated 1,700 animals in this area. I understand that in over 1,200 kilometres of coast, only 1,700 animals remain. Of those, Shoalwater Bay is home to approximately 400 dugongs—therefore a significant proportion of the remaining dugongs in the southern Great Barrier Reef. Dugongs occur in the waters of over 40 countries, but all except Australia are developing nations. That gives us a special responsibility for dugong protection. The cause of the decline in dugong numbers in the southern Great Barrier Reef may be attributed to a combination of the following: gill netting, habitat loss and disruption, shark meshing and indigenous hunting. Clearly the time has come for radical action to address the decline in dugong numbers.

ANSWER.PARA: As a first step in addressing the decline in numbers, I am announcing this week that I have approved for public release a draft management plan for the conservation of dugong in Shoalwater Bay. The management plan will ensure that Shoalwater Bay remains a sanctuary for these beautiful and graceful mammals. The plan will effectively ban all gill netting in Shoalwater Bay. I have determined that current restrictions on the use of nets in Shoalwater Bay do not go far enough. There was evidence that the use of nets in the bay was continuing to contribute to the unsustainable mortality of dugong.

Accordingly, I have taken decisive action to increase the level of protection for dugongs by, as I said, banning all gill nets in the bay. Dugongs, therefore, in this remote and scenic area will be protected.

The plan has been developed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in consultation with interest groups, such as commercial fishers, conservation groups and Aboriginal groups. I am pleased also to note that the local Aboriginal people are contributing to the protection of dugongs in Shoalwater Bay by voluntarily forgoing traditional hunting.

GBRMPA will soon release the draft management plan and invite public submissions on it before it is finalised and comes into force. The protection of dugong in the bay will further enhance the exceptional environmental significance of the area.

The development of this management plan for the conservation of dugong in Shoalwater Bay demonstrates this government's commitment to the protection of the dugong. It is, however, an initiative which will need to be supported by other measures in the Great Barrier Reef area. For this reason, the government has this year committed over $630,000 to dugong conservation.

In addition, I recently addressed a meeting of the dugong review group, including representatives from the key parties with an interest in dugong conservation, and I urged all parties to identify and implement emergency measures necessary to further prevent the decline of dugong in the southern Great Barrier Reef. I am expecting Commonwealth and Queensland ministers to be able to consider a package of emergency measures produced by this stakeholder group at the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council meeting to be held later in November. I believe that the dugong review group will identify a series of measures which will lead to better coastal planning, use of less threatening fishing practices and further dugong sanctuaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to Public Service Commission guidelines on official conduct of Commonwealth public servants.

Chapter 15 of this particular official code of conduct says that public servants are able to perform work outside the public service, provided this does not create the perception that they have placed themselves in conflict with their official duties, is not likely to affect their efficiency in the performance of their official duties, is performed wholly in their private time, and does not interfere with the performance of their official duties. He is the same person who has been given the responsibility by the Prime Minister of looking into the issue of conflict of interest with Mr Howard's own ministers. I assume Mr Moore‐Wilton has been given this responsibility because it takes one to know one. This is the same man who should be a self-appointed expert in the matter of conflict of interest because, categorically, he is in breach of the Public Service Commission's Guidelines on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants.

A strong leader, a strong Prime Minister, would have said to Mr Max Moore-Wilton, `It's not on. You've got to set an example. You can't hold down a second job. You can't hold down a third job. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, Senator Vanstone, I seek leave to have a statement which is an answer to a question asked of Senator Vanstone on 6 November 1996 by Senator McKiernan incorporated in the Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senator Amanda Vanstone—On 6 November 1996 Senator McKiernan asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

`Minister, was Justice Michael Kirby of the High Court correct when he said that studies showed Australia was already, by world standards, a low spending country in the field of legal assistance. Was he correct when he said that Australia spends $13 per person per year on legal assistance as compared with New Zealand spending $16, Canada $18, the Netherlands $22 and the United Kingdom $65. Was he correct when he said that the withdrawal of this type of funding would cause attacks on the legal system.'
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is impossible to comment meaningfully on the comparison between Australian spending on legal assistance and that of other countries without knowing how the figures quoted by Justice Kirby are made up.

I am advised that the Australian figure of $13 per person per year spent on legal assistance is not correct. If the resources available to Legal Aid Commissions, Community Legal Centres and Aboriginal Legal Services are taken into account it is evident that at least $17 per head is spent on legal aid each year. This figure does not include some additional resources made available by State and Territory Governments to Community Legal Centres and other organisations or the value of pro bono work undertaken by the legal profession. In addition, there are payments made by both the Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments to community organisations for mediation and similar non court dispute resolution services. Including these payments will increase the per capita expenditure.

The Commonwealth will continue to fund legal aid for people in need who require legal assistance for matters arising under Commonwealth law. No reduction in overall legal aid funding will occur if the States and Territories recognise and honour their responsibilities to provide legal assistance for matters which arise under their laws—particularly criminal matters.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the statement by the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) on the National Health and Medical Research Council's 60th anniversary and move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

In September 1936, the Governor General made an Order in Council which established the National Health and Medical Research Council to assume the role of advising the Commonwealth, the States and the community on health matters and the allocation of funds for medical research. This year, the National Health and Medical Research Council is celebrating sixty years of providing Australian governments with expert advice across the great range of issues that fall under the Health Portfolio.
At the first formal meeting of the NHMRC held in Hobart in February 1937, the then Commonwealth Minister for Health, Billy Hughes said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australia, priding herself on being a nation, ought not to be satisfied to follow, to imitate, to duplicate. She must blaze a track for herself, seek to lead rather than follow: and this calls for the services of specialists of high repute to train, inspire, and guide research along right lines.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time Australia was struggling with diseases such as poliomyelitis—a struggle which was to continue until the vaccine was introduced in 1955.

Whilst we may no longer worry about the spread of polio the challenges we still face in population health are great. Today skin cancer in Australia is still the highest per head in the world; HIV/AIDS, after 15 years of being with us, still has no cure; and, although reduced, we are still working out why our young continue to die of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

I would like to pay tribute to the dedication and, to a significant extent voluntary, contributions of all members of the Council, its many committees and the wider community of health and medical professionals who have assisted the Council with its work over these sixty years.

When the Government announced its Health Throughout Life program it drew attention to its broad priorities for investment in health and medical research and a culture of evidence based practice in health care. The National Health and Medical Research Council has supported these priorities, as can be illustrated by the 1997 Research Grants.
The 1996 Budget provided significant funding increases for health and medical research through a number of initiatives, not only for the National Health and Medical Research Council.

Australia contributes about 2 per cent of the world health and medical research effort, well above what might be expected from our population base. This level represents an investment in health and medical research across all disciplines by government, private bodies and the business sector.
It means that Australia has a role in the international research scene as a significant player. It punches above its weight.

The National Health and Medical Research Council funds about 22 per cent of Australia's health and medical research activity. This research represents the very best of Australian health and medical research with funding being awarded only to those who meet extremely stringent standards.

It therefore gives me the greatest pleasure to announce today that I have approved health and medical research awards worth $159.8 million, to be made by the National Health and Medical Research Council in 1997.

These awards, which include research project grants, large program grants, block grants to institutes and a range of career and training awards are a demonstration of the Government's commitment to maintaining Australia's highly regarded health and medical research base.

The funding of $159.8 million covers research which is continuing from previous years to the value of $96.6 million; new and renewed research awards totalling $54.7 million; and funding allocated for special research projects.

Australia has a worldwide reputation for the quality of its health and medical research—demonstrated in the last few weeks with the announcement of the award of the Nobel prize for medicine to Professor Peter Doherty and Dr Rolf Zinkernagel, for work they did 20 years ago at the John Curtin School of Medical Research when both were young post-doctoral researchers investigating cells which form part of our body's immune system.

Not least as part of Australian research efforts funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council, strokes and heart attacks have been reduced by half over the past 25 years—saving 54,000 lives from strokes alone; cot deaths reduced by nearly half in two years; kidney failure prevented in thousands of Australians; cost and illness associated with stomach and duodenal ulcers reduced by the discovery of a bacterial cause and a short course of treatment.

We must recognise that research does not produce overnight results, funding of research is a long‐term investment to gain improvements in health. It is important that the support of basic research such as that conducted by Doherty and Zinkernagel is maintained, at the same time as targeting research funding to areas of health concern requiring more immediate attention.

A number of significant links have been forged with other countries and other research funding bodies. The National Health and Medical Research Council has established Memorandums of Understanding on research cooperation with Germany and Switzerland. It has been involved in cooperative workshops with Japanese researchers. It has an arrangement for exchange training fellowships with its equivalent organisation in France and shared funding arrangements with the Menzies Foundation for a training fellowship to be held in the United Kingdom.
These are important partnership activities. Also important for Australian health and medical research is the investment of overseas funding bodies in Australian research.

I am also delighted to announce that the Wellcome Trust of the United Kingdom has advised me that next year, in recognition of the strength of Australian science and the impetus given by the increased funding for health and medical research in this year's Budget, it will commit funding for the support of Australian medical research at approximately two and a half times its current level. This increase will bring the Wellcome Trust contribution to Australian medical research to about $10 million per annum.

The Wellcome funding will be provided for various purposes. A significant portion will be to enable researchers to purchase major items of equipment, a very valuable contribution to the research effort.

Other funding will be for a range of fellowship and training awards especially for collaborative biomedical research work in the Asia Pacific region. Australian researchers will also have access to Wellcome Trust grants in the area of population and reproductive health studies.

Among the new research grants to be awarded by the National Health and Medical Research Council in 1997 is one to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, an outstanding example of Australia's contribution to the international medical research scene, which will receive renewed funding for five years for its wide range of research programs which cover aspects of diabetes, cancer and malaria. The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute will receive over $8 million per annum as a block grant towards its investigations of the complex cellular and genetic mechanisms of the body.

Other areas of research to receive considerable new funding in 1997 include research into musculo-skeletal diseases. This includes $1 million for new studies relevant to arthritic diseases. A number of projects will be funded, including a study at the University of New South Wales which will assess the most appropriate and cost effective treatments for common arthritic conditions.

Research into asthmatic disease will also receive considerable funding. Over $1 million will be awarded for new research projects investigating aspects of asthmatic disease, including the links between various allergens and the development of asthma, preventive strategies and appropriate medication.
Research projects and training awards in the area of HIV/AIDS, will amount to $4.7 million in 1997.

The problem of youth suicide will also receive attention. Studies will be funded into adolescent depression, deliberate self harm and substance abuse. One of the projects will include a collaboration with the Victorian Department of Education to provide suicide prevention health education programs in Victorian schools. Another will be investigating the long term effectiveness of psychological intervention in preventing the development of depression in adolescents.

I wanted to use this time in the House to reinforce the commitment the Government has made to the National Health and Medical Research Council. For all diseases for which we find a cure there will always be new challenges ahead. As a society, we are making real progress in both fighting disease and promoting better health. Life expectancy for a male has increased from 59 years in 1920-22 to 75 years in 1994. For a female, life expectancy has gone from 63 years in 1920-22 to 81 years today.
As Billy Hughes said when he first addressed the National Health and Medical Research Council:

PARA.EMPHASIS: To this Council of War against Disease I come to bid its members welcome. . . hope that their wisdom, experience and skill will evolve such plans as will result in further triumphs over disease and conduce mightily to the health and happiness of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Sixty years on, the message hasn't changed. I congratulate the NHMRC on reaching its Sixtieth Anniversary, and look forward to working with it in the years to come.
Debate (on motion by Senator Conroy) adjourned.
