DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (WAITING PERIOD) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
This bill amends part 2 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. Part 2 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act provides for the Austudy scheme.

The bill introduces a two year (104 week) waiting period for access to Austudy benefits which will, as a general rule, apply to migrants (including New Zealand citizens) who arrive in Australia on or after 1 January 1997.

The two year waiting period will not apply to migrants who settled in Australia before 1 January 1997. However, the existing six month Austudy waiting period for New Zealand citizens will continue to apply to those who arrive before 1 January 1997.

Migrants and New Zealand citizens who have visited Australia before 1 January 1997 as a tourist or in some other temporary capacity and subsequently return to settle on or after 1 January 1997 will be subject to the waiting period.
Madam President, a safety net exemption from the waiting period will be available to:
Refugee and humanitarian migrants and their immediate family members;
Former holders of visa subclasses 820 (spouses or fiances of Australian citizens) and 826 (interdependent relationships);
Holders of visa subclasses 832 and 833 (innocent illegals—unlawfuls who are over 18 but entered Australia and became unlawful while they were children); and

People who would otherwise be subject to the waiting period but who experience after arrival in Australia a change in circumstances, when they are aged 21 years or less, such that they no longer have access to a parental home and financial support.

Madam President, the bill ensures that migrants make provision for their own and their children's education during their first two years as Australian residents. This reflects community expectations that new migrants make a reasonable contribution towards certain educational costs upon their arrival in Australia.

A similar bill currently being considered by the parliament will introduce a two year waiting period for receipt of most Department of Social Security payments by migrants who arrived in Australia on or after 1 April 1996.

For migrants subject to the two year waiting period, it will commence on the day the migrant entered Australia or the day they became a permanent resident, whichever is the later. For migrants subject to the two year waiting period who are New Zealand citizens, the waiting period will commence on the day they permanently settled in Australia.
The two year waiting period does not include periods of absence from Australia.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

BREAK.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

This bill will give legislative effect to a 1996 Government budget decision to discontinue the payment of the untargetted operational subsidy to community based long day care centres from 1 July 1997.

This bill will also give legislative effect to a 1996 Budget decision to apply a reduced rate of entitlement to the Childcare Cash Rebate for families on higher incomes, while retaining the current rate for families on lower incomes. This change will take effect from 1 April 1997.
The bill will also introduce amendments aimed at clarifying eligibility issues and compliance requirements consistent with the intentions of the Commonwealth Childcare Cash Rebate scheme.

Madam President, currently operational subsidy is paid under Section 11 of the Child Care Act 1972 for child care places provided by community based services, but not for places provided by the private sector. 70 per cent of all centres are privately operated centres.

The repeal of Section 11 from the Child Care Act addresses the inequities in Government funding between families using private long day care centres and community centres. The removal of operational subsidy will place community based long day care centres and private long day care centres on an equal footing. It will also encourage greater competition and efficiency.

Operational subsidy will continue to be made available for Family Day Care Schemes, Occasional Care, Outside School Hours Care, Multifunctional Children's Services and Multifunctional Aboriginal Children's Services. These services are crucial to meeting the diverse child care needs of Australian families.

Assistance will be provided to help community based long day care centres losing operational subsidy to restructure their business and to ensure families in severely disadvantaged areas do not lose access to child care. Over a two year period, $8.3 million will be provided to enable community centres to purchase financial and/or management advice to improve operating practices and adjust to the loss of operational subsidy.

The withdrawal of operation subsidies for community based services will not affect the quality of care as this will be maintained for all centre based long day care services through the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System.

Madam President, there is presently no link between a family's income and their level of entitlement to the Childcare Cash Rebate. While access to the Childcare Cash Rebate will be retained for all families regardless of income level, it is equitable to apply a lower level of entitlement for those families who need assistance less.

Families with a taxable income in the current year lower than the family income cut offs for Part A of the Family Tax Initiative will have their benefit maintained at 30 per cent of their claimable child care costs, while families with a taxable income in the current year greater than these cut offs will be entitled to a reduced rate of benefit of 20 per cent of their claimable child care costs.
This reform to the Childcare Cash Rebate ensures that Government assistance is targeted to those most in need, while still recognising child care as a legitimate work related expense.
Further amendments to the Childcare Cash Rebate scheme implemented by this bill will improve the administration and accessibility of the Childcare Cash Rebate scheme.

Madam President, the Government wishes to ensure that the Childcare Cash Rebate is available to those who are genuinely in need of assistance. The Government is equally concerned that those who do not have a legitimate need are held accountable for any payments to which they are not entitled.
To that end, further refinements to the operation of the Childcare Cash Rebate scheme will ensure that:
foster parents and persons with long term informal parenting responsibilities are eligible for the Childcare Cash Rebate;
the Rebate is payable for two sets of child care fees for the one period of care in certain circumstances;
the Health Insurance Commission has the power to suspend claims where a problem with a registration or claim has been identified;
the Rebate cannot be paid for care provided by a registered carer to children of that registered carer's partner;
carers must notify the Health Insurance Commission if their circumstances have changed, affecting their eligibility to be registered.

To further clarify the legislation, the definition of child care will be revised and consequential amendments will bring the Childcare Rebate Act into line with recent amendments to the Family Law Act 1975.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the bill as a whole. The question is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Schedule 5, item 19, page 28 (lines 29 to 31), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the subsections.
Repeal the subsection, substitute:

(1D) The Commission must decide as quickly as it can whether to make an interim award if the Commission considers that such an award may be necessary to protect, for an interim period, the wages and conditions of employment of the employees whom the award would cover.
Repeal the subsections.

This amendment relates to the repeal of the provisions introduced by the previous government to fast‐track transfers from state to federal jurisdiction. Subsections 111(1A), (1B), (1C), (1F), (1G), (1H) and (4) will still be repealed, but subsection 111 (1D) will be retained in part and subsection 111(1E) will be retained.

PARA.BREAK: The new subsection 111(1D), which retains the current paragraph 111(1D)(a), and subsection 111(1E) require the commission to decide as quickly as it can whether to make an interim award if it considers it necessary to protect, for an interim period, the wages and conditions of employment of the employees whom the award would cover. Provision is also made in amendment No. 30 to the effect that the repeal of subsection 111(1A) is not to apply to any proceedings before the commis sion that commenced before the commencement of the repeal.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 21 is one of a series of amendments which reflect the government's policy that employers and employees should have the right to choose the jurisdiction that they wish to enter, while recognising the need to ensure that the public interest is taken into account. Related amendments are amendment No. 22, which amends proposed section 111AAA and amendment No. 28, which amends section 152.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor opposes this amendment and the original provisions in the bill. The reason why we oppose this is that, with one very weak exception, the bill repeals the provisions which enable employees under state awards to gain quick coverage under federal awards. We will seek to delete this repeal.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we do this is that the fast‐track provisions have allowed employees in Victoria and Western Australia to gain quick access to the federal jurisdiction where their wages and conditions have been threatened by changes in the respective state systems. These provisions may also be important in future in states such as Queensland, given the mooted changes to industrial relations law there, and perhaps at some time in the future in South Australia and New South Wales.

I would like to draw the committee's attention, and that of Senator Murray in particular, to the last few lines of page 331 of the report of the Senate Economics References Committee where, in a supplementary report by the Australian Democrats relating to chapter 3, there appears this sentence:
Therefore, I endorse the Majority report's recommendation that the onus, process and criteria used to determine public interest not be altered in the way proposed by the bill.

Regrettably, today we note that the Democrats are not following their own recommendation in the committee report. One other reference that I would like to make is to the Democrats' pre‐election policy, which states:
. . . continued support for the right of workers to transfer from one state jurisdiction to the protection of federal awards under legal provisions approved by the Democrats in 1992.

We should emphasise here that the current provisions which we are discussing enjoyed Democrat support in 1992. Regrettably, the Democrat‐government deal repeals very substantially the provisions that they supported in 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I will not be supporting Democrat‐government amendment No. 21 and that I will be supporting the ALP's amendment on this issue.

—I have a question for the parliamentary secretary: in the context of section 111 of the act and the repeal, I noted in your comments that it will not apply to proceedings currently lodged or before the AIRC and working through the system. Can the parliamentary secretary or his advisers advise whether that comment applies to matters that have left the commission and gone on appeal on a point of law to the High Court and are part heard before the High Court.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is very hard to answer the question if you do not know the specific facts of the case. It would depend on what point it is before the High Court. That is the best advice I have. That is a very good question.
—We would like a very good answer!
—We would like to give you a more detailed response but—
—Are you seeking more facts? I can give you them now. Or do you want to resolve it another way?
—Yes, we will accept more facts; we are here to be helpful.

—The matter concerns a number of applications lodged in Western Australia, involving previously affected state award workers, which have made their way through the system and the AIRC under a section 111 application over the last three years. Then it went on appeal from the single commissioner to the full bench and a federal interim award was issued by the commission and upheld by the full bench in the middle of last year. Since then, applications have been lodged by employer interests in the High Court which have not yet been argued before, or determined by, that court. So I suppose the salient point is that the issues on merit have been determined by a full bench of the AIRC; there is an application in the High Court, in regard to the issue of the interim award, which has not yet been set down for formal hearing. That is my understanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop may help me to answer that by providing some information. Is it the section 111(1A) matter that is one of the issues before the High Court?
—The issue before the High Court is the same one that has been determined in respect of the Ambulance Employees Association of Victoria. That has been joined to that matter.

—Senator Bishop, as far as I can help you, my advice is that if the 111(1A) issue had been determined by the commission, it would have passed the threshold. If that was an issue before the High Court—and you have not been clear about that and I am assuming that the 111(1A) is part of something that the High Court has been asked to rule on or is in the process of ruling on—then it would not have passed that threshold.
—I do not have a copy of the act in front of me. Would you just remind me of the difference between the 111(1A) and the 111(1G) provisions of the act?

—I will reiterate that to give such an answer is a little hard under these circumstances although we will be as helpful as we can. This would have been a good question to have had some notice of but we will be helpful. We need to know if the (1A) issue is the one before the High Court. I think Senator Bishop is desperately trying to find that bit of information for us.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop, to make it easier, if you want to leave the chamber—I am not encouraging you to do so—we will certainly make one of our officers immediately available to you to look over that part of the act with you, if that suits you.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be quite adequate, Senator Campbell.
—We will get a few votes through while you are out of the way!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the government‐Democrat amendment No. 21. Senator Sherry, because you are a Tasmanian, you might not know the local politics. I should remind you that you cannot have it both ways because, over in Western Australia, the Liberal minister in the state government, Graham Kierath, is extremely cross with the Democrats for the amendments we have managed to win on behalf of Western Australian employees.

SPEECH.PARA: These important provisions were inserted in the act in 1992 to deal with the industrial situation created by Jeff Kennett's industrial reforms in Victoria that year. The Democrats supported the establishment of the fast‐track mechanism at that stage. This week, the AIRC—as we are advised—will proceed to make an interim award under these provisions for Victorian state public servants, the last set of award employees to exit the Victorian system for the federal system. Those provisions have now served their purpose. However, we do retain in the transitional arrangements a provision to allow all outstanding matters to be under the fast‐track mechanism.

The provisions of 111(1B), (1C) and (1G) relate to the matters that the AIRC had to take into account in relation to state employment agreements. They are superseded as these matters are to be dealt with under proposed sections 152 and 111(AAA).

Importantly, we have persuaded the government to retain proposed section 111(1D), after some very heavy discussion, I might add. Proposed section 111(1D) in its amended form will require the commission to act as quickly as it can to make an interim award if the commission considers such an award might be necessary to protect, for an interim period, the wages and conditions of employees whom the award will cover.

While the making of an interim award is still subject to the commission being required under 111(1G)(ii) to determine whether to refrain from dealing with a dispute because it has been dealt with by a state industrial authority, the clear statement of legislative intention of the desirability of affording appropriate protection for workers under 111(1D), combined with the objects of this part in 88A and 88B and in proposed section 3, provide a clear impetus for the quick establishment of such awards.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Campbell's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes item 19. I do not intend to speak any further. We have covered the matter in debate already.
—You are opposing item 19. The bill will be divided in respect of item 19 of schedule 5. The question is that item 19 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Schedule 5, item 20, page 29 (lines 3 to 24), omit section 111AAA, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 111AAA Commission to cease dealing with industrial dispute in certain circumstances

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Commission is satisfied that a State award or State employment agreement governs the wages and conditions of employment of particular employees whose wages and conditions of employment are the subject of an industrial dispute, the Commission must cease dealing with the industrial dispute in relation to those employees, unless the Commission is satisfied that ceasing would not be in the public interest.
(2) In determining the public interest for the purposes of subsection (1), the Commission must give primary consideration to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the views of the employees referred to in subsection (1); and
(b) the views of the employer or employers of those employees.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The Commission must inform itself as quickly as it can about the views referred to in subsection (2), and may inform itself in such manner as it thinks fit.
(4) In this section:

PARA.TAB: cease dealing , in relation to an industrial dispute, means:
(a) to dismiss the whole or a part of a matter to which the industrial dispute relates; or
(b) to refrain from further hearing or from determining the industrial dispute or part of the industrial dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment replaces proposed section 111AAA with a new section with the same title. The new section applies to industrial disputes in relation to employees whose wages and conditions are governed by a state award or state employment agreement.

The proposed section was previously limited to employees whose wages and conditions are governed by a state award. The commission is required to cease dealing with such a dispute unless it considers that to cease dealing with the dispute would not be in the public interest. The effect of this provision is that a federal award will only replace a state award or state employment agreement where the public interest would be served by federal award coverage.

The new section also omits proposed subsection (2)(c), which specified as one of the matters to which the commission has to give primary consideration in determining public interest the history of the regulation of the employment relationship in question. Omission of subsection (2)(c) means that the matters to which the commission must give primary consideration in determining the public interest are the views of the relevant employees and of their employers. Where employees and their employers are in agreement as to the jurisdiction within which they wish to operate, they should, as a general rule, be permitted to operate within the jurisdiction of their agreed choice. Where they do not agree, the commission will have regard to the broader public interest considerations, having apprised itself of the views of the employers and employees concerned.

BREAK.PARA: New subsection (3) requires the commission to inform itself as quickly as it can about the views of the employees and the employers concerned, and provides that it may determine those views in such a manner as it thinks fit. Proposed section 111AAA, together with amendments to section 152 proposed by amendment 28, and the repeal of the fast‐tracking provisions referred to earlier, reflect the government's policy that employers and employees should be free to enter the jurisdiction of their choice.

New section 111AAA is designed to ensure that federal award coverage will only displace coverage by a state award or state employment agreement where federal coverage will serve the public interest. Consistent with the principle of freedom of choice, primary consideration will be given to the views of the employers and employees concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are opposing the government-Democrat amendment 22. From the outset, I would like to note that this actually makes worse the original bill that we were considering. I do not know how the Democrats can claim a victory by moving backwards. But I suppose only they can do that.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of amendment 35, the bill inserts a new provision which requires the commission to cease dealing with industrial dispute concerning employees—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Sherry, we are dealing with government-Democrat amendment 22.

—That is right. I am speaking at this stage in respect of the opposition amendment 35 to save some time. What I intend to do—and I understand we have two further amendments 1 and 2 on sheet 224—is seek leave for 111AAA to be reconsidered. That is the advice we have had.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking in opposition to government-Democrat amendment 22, the bill inserts a new provision which requires the commission to cease dealing with an industrial dispute concerning employees who are subject to a state award and state employment agreement, unless the public interest is against the commission ceasing dealing. In opposing this, we seek its deletion. The reason we do this is that it effectively precludes state award employees from seeking access to the federal jurisdiction.

If employees wish to seek federal coverage and can satisfy the requirements, they should not be deprived of the opportunity. So much for the choice that the government and the Democrats have been boasting about in respect of this matter. It is a limitation of choice; it effectively precludes it. The original bill only precluded the Commonwealth from acting where an employee was on a state award. Now, the provision also applies to employees on a state employment agreement. If an employee goes on to a state enterprise agreement, it will become almost impossible for the employee, if they want to, to get back on to a federal award. Hence my reference to this particular amendment moving the bill backwards.

In concluding my remarks, I would like to draw the attention of the chamber to a speech Senator Kernot gave to the Victorian conference of the Australian Education Union on 15 June 1996. When outlining her concerns about a range of issues relating to the original bill she said on page 10 that its powers to grant federal awards to workers under state awards or agreements are substantially reduced.

I would like to draw attention to the pre‐election commitment of the Democrats', which I have already referred to in relation to 111AAA, to continue to support the right of workers to transfer from state jurisdictions to the protection of federal awards under legal provisions approved by the Democrats in 1992. For Senator Murray to claim that these provisions are no longer necessary is frankly exhibiting a gross ignorance of industrial law and a continuing need for workers under state awards or employment agreements to be able to fast track to federal awards if they so desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Sherry that once again his ground is undercut by just how angry Minister Kierath is about these amendments. Proposed new section 111AAA dealt with under government‐Democrat amendment No. 22 is now substantially different from section 111AAA contained in the original bill. Firstly, it will apply to state employment agreements other than those that meet the requirements of section 152. Secondly, in determining the public interest, the commission is required to give primary consideration to the views of employers and employees, but not to the history of the regulation of the employment relationship as originally envisaged by the government. Thirdly, a new subsection (3) will make it very clear that this provision is not to be used as a time delaying device, with the commission required to inform itself as quickly as it can and in such a manner as it thinks fit.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed new section has the effect that a federal award will only displace a state award or state employment agreement where the public interest would be served by federal award coverage. It is the commission which determines that public interest. The intent of this is further provided in the explanatory memorandum. It will operate simply to ensure that the AIRC, before displacing a state award or agreement, asks the people affected what they think about that.

As the explanatory memorandum makes clear, where the employees and the employers both clearly want to stay in the state jurisdiction—and I remind you that we emphasis that they should be able to jointly and freely agree to do that—then unless there is some other public interest consideration they should be able to do so. They should not be forced in one direction or another by either a union or an employer.

Where the employers and employees have a differing view, even where a few employees have a different view, the AIRC should determine the matter on normal public interest grounds. I do not believe that it is particularly terrible to ask the AIRC to ask these people affected what they think.

It is important to read proposed new section 111AAA(3) carefully in determining how these provisions will work. How the AIRC informs itself is up to it not the parties. It is our intention that this be done in the simplest and quickest way possible, consistent with the public interest. I would envisage that if a union presents evidence of a workplace resolution in favour of the award being made and evidence of employers rejecting a log for a federal award, then they have satisfied the wording of that section. It is not open to an employer to insist on dragging these proceedings out to prove what would already be evident by that simple information process. From that point it would then fall to the public interest considerations as to whether an award should be made.

I want to talk about state employment agreements and the operation of proposed new section 111AAA. I do not believe that this section can be used to deny employees who want federal award coverage from escaping a substandard state employment agreement. This is because such a decision would be clearly contrary to the public interest. Section 90 of the act makes it clear that in determining the public interest, the commission must have regard to the objects of the act and, in particular, the objects of this part.

New object 88A is very important. It sets as the key object of this part that wages and conditions of employment are protected by a system of enforceable awards established and maintained by the commission. Object 3(d) also places a heavy onus on the commission to ensure that enterprise bargaining moves on to the foundation of minimum standards through any effective award safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions of employment. If a state employment agreement is below the standard of a federal award, there is a compelling public interest case for the commission to proceed to extend that award to circumvent that agreement.

The term `state employment agreement' is defined in a new addition to section 4(1) and has four elements. One element is that the agreement prevails over an inconsistent state award system. That implies a state award system is underpinning the state agreement stream—a condition which is present in five of the six states in this country. The inclusion of this fourth criterion—`What is a state employment agreement?'—is consistent with object 3(d) of this act which states that the employment agreements will be based on a foundation of minimum standards and that there must be an effective award safety net.

Thus it would be consistent with a public interest to argue that an employment agreement which did not meet each of the four criteria in section 4(1), having regard to the objects, could not fall within proposed new section 111AAA. Given the protections within proposed new section 111AAA, as amended, the Democrats believe that this provision is limited to the effect described above and it is entirely appropriate for the Senate to support it as a protection for employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do the transitional provisions cover this? If they do not cover this, what is the position of a union that has been in litigation with a state government for years and has spent many dollars to get decisions from the High Court and other places? I do not necessarily want an answer at this stage, but I would like an answer at some stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing I can say about Mr Kierath in Western Australia is, `Methinks he protesteth too loud.' I do not necessarily take Mr Kierath as any judge of good or bad in industrial relations. I think it is better for us to look at the issues ourselves, to see what it is we are voting on, to judge whether or not it is going to be taking workers forwards or backwards. In our opinion, both the proposed section in the bill and the amendment will still be taking workers backwards.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put this on the record for my esteemed colleague Senator Barney Cooney. But seriously, it is quite outrageous that a group of employees—represented by their union or not—who have begun a process and, in many cases, who would have spent literally tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of dollars on the process, will have wasted their money once this bill is proclaimed as an act, because there are no transitional provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Schedule 5, page 30 (after line 21), after item 26, insert:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 120A Orders of Commission on exceptional matters

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Each exceptional matters order must relate only to a single matter.

PARA.TAB: Note 1: An exceptional matters order is an order made by the Commission on a matter that is allowed to be included in an industrial dispute because of subsection 89A(6).
Note 2: Exceptional matters orders are published under section 143, in the same way as other orders of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Commission must not make an exceptional matters order unless the Commission is satisfied that making the order is in the public interest, and consistent with the objects of this Act.

(3) The Commission must not make an exceptional matters order that would apply to more than a single business unless the Commission is satisfied that such an order is an appropriate manner of settling the matter in dispute.
(4) An exceptional matters order must be made by a Full Bench, unless the order relates to a single business (within the meaning of Part VIB).
(5) An exceptional matters order ceases to be in force 2 years after it is made, and cannot be extended.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 120B Commission to report on junior rates of pay

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Before 22 June 1999, a Full Bench must prepare a report for the Minister on the feasibility of replacing junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives.
(2) The report must include assessments of:

PARA.TAB: (a) whether it is desirable to replace junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives; and
(b) the consequences for youth employment of abolishing junior rates; and
(c) the utility of junior rates:

TAB.TAB: (i) for different types of employment, and
(ii) for different industries; and
(iii) in the school-to-work transition.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The Minister must cause a copy of the report to be tabled in each House of the Parliament as soon as practicable after the Minister receives it.
(4) In this section, junior rates means junior rates of pay.

This amendment proposes a new item which would insert two new sections relating to exceptional matters orders and a proposed review of junior rates of pay. New section 120A relates to the orders which the commission can make in connection with an exceptional matter. This amendment relates to new subsection 89A(6) which permits exceptional matters to be included in an industrial dispute for the purposes of subsection 89A(1). I explained the concept of exceptional matters earlier in moving amendment 19.

The commission must not make an exceptional matters order unless it is satisfied that making the order is in the public interest and consistent with the objects of the act. The commission must not make an exceptional matters order that would apply to more than a single business unless it is satisfied that such an order is an appropriate manner of settling the matter in dispute. For example, if the order sought were to apply across an industry the commission, in determining whether such an order would be appropriate, would need to have regard to whether the matter might be more effectively and practicably addressed through an order or orders applying at the workplace or enterprise level or through agreements at the workplace or enterprise level.

An exceptional matters order must be made by a full bench unless the order relates to a single business. An exceptional matters order ceases to be enforced two years after it is made and cannot be extended. The purpose of limiting the life of an exceptional matters order is to encourage the parties to reach agreement on the matter concerned. However, where agreement cannot be reached, a new exceptional matters order may be made in relation to the same matter provided that the requirements of subsection 89A(6) and section 120A are satisfied. Exceptional matters orders do not form part of the benchmark for the no disadvantage test which is provided for in schedule 13.

New section 120B requires a full bench of the commission to prepare a report for the minister on the feasibility of replacing junior rates with non‐discriminatory alternatives. The section sets out the matters to be addressed in the report. The report is to be prepared before 22 June 1999 and tabled in both houses of parliament as soon as practicable after the minister receives it.

This amendment relates to government and Democrat amendments 27 and 30, which exempt junior rates of pay from the anti‐age discrimination provisions of the legislation for a further three years from 22 June 1997. The proposed reporting requirement will ensure that the parliament will have the opportunity to consider the feasibility of replacing junior wages well in advance of the expiration of the across‐the‐board exemption and that the parliament will be assisted in its deliberations by a report which is required by section 120B to address all key issues relevant to youth wages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against this provision. We have decided against calling this the Murray amendment on this occasion. We decided to call it the topless amendment. That is in response to the media release that Senator Murray put out yesterday, which makes reference to this provision and its alleged protection of in particular people in the hospitality industry, and some people in the entertainment industry, who may be coerced into working topless.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray makes the point in this release that the provisions of government‐Democrat amendment 23 would make it impossible to see a union failing in an application to the commission to maintain these provisions because their appeal would clearly be harsh and unjust if the order was not made. Senator Murray went on and said it was clear that Labor spokesperson Bob McMullan had not read or did not understand the protection for workers that the Democrats have negotiated.

The negotiation in this case and the provisions provide that an order can only be made for two years and then cannot be renewed. In respect of the alleged protection that the Democrats have boasted about in their news release No. 96/740, the reality is that women can be protected from coercion, but for only two years.

This press release of Senator Murray does highlight the lack of understanding of the protections that the Democrats believe they have been able to introduce into this legislation. It is deeply regrettable. Unfortunately, there are some employers in the hospitality industry and some other industries who coerce topless waiters—usually female, I would have to say; very rarely do we see any male topless bar attendants or waiters in the industry. The Democrats seem to believe that this provision will provide a union facility to protect employees but, unfortunately, it does so for only two years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, you have just made my point for me. I have great admiration for your abilities—and I say that without any sarcasm—but I am afraid that you are wrong on this provision. Those orders can be renewed and shortly I will tell you exactly how. I rise to support government/Democrat amendment No. 23. This amendment seeks to insert two new provisions, one dealing with exceptional matters orders and the other with junior rates. I have already spoken about the exceptional matters orders and when they are granted. This provision contains a number of requirements on the making of the order as opposed to the circumstances when the commission can deal with an exceptional matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Subclause 120A(2) requires that the order be in the public interest and consistent with the object of the act. Of particular relevance to such orders will be object H which makes it clear that arbitration is available where appropriate. Object D(1) says that bargaining should be based on the foundation of minimum standards. Object A stresses the importance of a fair and flexible labour market. Object I is in relation to working family balances and object J is on discrimination.

Subclauses 120A(3) and 120A(4) add a requirement that where an order is to extend beyond a single business it must be approved by a full bench as an appropriate manner of settling the dispute. The explanatory memorandum gives the example of a consideration of the appropriateness as to whether that matter might be more effectively and practicably addressed through an order or orders applying at the workplace level. Similarly, it might more effectively and practically be dealt with at an industry level. In the hospitality industry, the current award requirement that a waiter cannot be required to work topless without their consent is a clear example of a provision that should be retained to prevent harsh and unjust outcomes across the industry.

To require hundreds and hundreds of workplace orders, each to defend human dignity in the hospitality industry, clearly would not be appropriate. Subclause 120A(5) says that the order can apply for only two years. This is to encourage the parties to try to reach agreement. The explanatory memorandum again makes it quite clear that if agreement cannot be reached or is reached in only a number of workplaces covered by the order, the union is entitled to reapply for the same order for a further two years, as long as the conditions continue to be met—in other words, it is a recurring agreement.

Subclause 120B flows on from the repeal of section 90AB in relation to junior rates. It requires the AIRC to inquire into the feasibility of replacing junior rates with non‐discriminatory alternatives and to report back to parliament within two years. The report must include assessment of the desirability of replacing junior rates with non‐discriminatory alternatives; it must include the consequences for youth employment; and it must include the utility of junior rates for different types of employment, different industries and the school to work program.

BREAK.PARA: In moving this amendment, the Democrats again commit themselves to the abolition of age discrimination against young workers. We believe that it is abhorrent that a 16‐year‐old is paid 40 per cent less than a 21‐year‐old, working side by side with them and doing the same work, just because they are young. I do not propose to repeat my comments of yesterday's debate—one or two of them in a loud voice—and will confine my comment to the process we have put in place.

As I said yesterday, the joint working party established under the commission to look at junior rates has failed to come up with an alternative which would deliver genuine wage equity for young people. We would prefer a real solution that takes a little longer to a sham solution that still leaves young people being paid less than adults doing the same work. The truth is that junior rate provisions in awards have never been reviewed. The restructuring of adult wage rates under the structural efficiency process basically passed this group of workers by.

Indeed, there is great commonality between the ratios of different age based rates to adult rates across different industries, suggesting this is based not on work value or competency assessment but on prejudice. Placing the onus on the commission to report on those matters effectively elevates the issue to the level of a major test case. It has a number of advantages. First, it requires the parties, particularly the employers, to put up or shut up on their claims that abolishing junior rates will cost jobs. I have never been persuaded by these arguments but they do deserve close scrutiny before we embark on a social experiment with the livelihoods of 220,000 young workers.

Second, it will allow youth and community groups excluded from the working party process to put proposals to the AIRC. Third, it will allow the canvassing of all the alternatives in the development of appropriate principles to move reform forward. Fourth, it will play an educative role in hopefully turning around the prejudices against the value of young workers which appear to be held by many employers and also a number of unions. Fifth, it will come up with a solution which is practical and fair and which will then flow through to the state commissions.

That last point, as I emphasised yesterday, is important to us. The model we see for the case, the personal carers leave case, commenced as the result of a similar Democrat amendment to the 1993 reform legislation. I say `as a result' because section 170KAA provided an early trigger for commencing the case at a time when the ACTU, in this case, was dragging its feet. Within two years of that amendment the AIRC had concluded a major test case which has been adopted by all state commissions and has now been implemented. That is the process we are committed to. We believe it is a solution orientated process, not one dictated by slogans.

It should be pointed out that, while the commission is required to report back to the parliament on the result of its hearings and deliberations, that is not the end of the matter. Proposed new section 143(1E) makes it clear that any principles determined by that full bench will be capable of implementation. Further, the award simplification process in item 43(7) and item 47 will require the commission to have regard to any such principles on junior rates when reviewing awards over the next 18 months.

Section 120B combined with 143(1E) will allow the commission a further year's grace through to the year 2000 to implement its decision. I believe personally that three years is far too long and that the commission should aim to complete this process in much less time. Indeed, the 18‐month transitional period for award simplification, in our view, would be the appropriate time to also update awards to include new wage systems for junior rates and we urge the AIRC to take note of those remarks. In that way, in 18 months we would have modern, simple awards that totally eliminate discrimination consistently with items 43(7) and 47 of the transitional arrangements.

By setting a time line on the completion of the report, this amendment increases the importance and the stature of the process we are asking the commission to engage in. The timing of the case is up to the commission, but certainly we would hope that the resolution of these issues is earlier rather than later. It would be our expectation—and that is why we have entered into this amendment—that the commission will invite submissions from unions, employers, governments, interested community groups, interested persons and, in particular, youth groups and youth organisations. Indeed, we would encourage the commission to adopt a proactive approach to informing itself on these issues, making a decision in principle and reporting its assessment to parliament. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do rise briefly but I have to say very strongly to the Senate that the proposed protections that the Democrats have negotiated with the government do not mean a great deal. It does not mean a great deal if the commission is going to carry out an investigation and report to the minister which the minister will not necessarily have to act on. It is a much more effective protection—particularly for women who may be coerced into working topless—if the commission has the power to either deal with the matter as a test case or to deal with the matter and prescribe it and maintain it in awards forever.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Murray referred to and one of his justifications for this outrageous sell‐out of women workers in Australia is his example about youth wages and the alleged protections. We reminded Senator Murray and the Democrats yesterday that, again, a report from the commission to the minister does not mean a great deal when the commission cannot ensure very clear protection by undertaking a test case and ensuring there are specific provisions in awards forever.

It is with regret that I say that the Australian Democrats, when this bill is proclaimed and if we have instances of topless bar attendants and waiters and coercion, will have to bear the responsibility on this particular issue.
