TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Schedule 5, item 27, page 30 (line 22) to page 31 (line 6), omit the item, substitute:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 127AA Awards and orders dealing with rights of entry

PARA.TAB: (1) Nothing in section 89A of this Act prevents the Commission from including a provision in an award or from making an order that requires or authorises an officer or employee of an organisation:

TAB.TAB: (a) to enter premises:
(i) occupied by an employer who is bound by the award or order; or
(ii) in which work to which the award or order applies is being carried on; and
(b) to inspect or view any work, material, machinery, appliance, article, document or other thing on such premises; and
(c) to interview an employee on such premises.

PARA.TAB: (2) If the Commission is of the opinion that a person has abused the rights provided by subsection (1) the Commission may vary the award or order accordingly.
(3) A person exercising the rights provided by subsection (1) must not:

TAB.TAB: (a) harass an employer or employee; or
(b) hinder or obstruct an employee in carrying out a duty of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important amendment for the trade union movement in this country. The guts of the government and, regretfully, the Democrat approach in respect of the right of entry is to make it very difficult indeed for the trade union movement, in a practical sense, to continue to organise. I will read it out because it is important to remind the Senate of the importance of the particular provisions. We require that:

PARA.TAB: (1) Nothing in section 89A of this Act prevents the Commission from including a provision in an award or from making an order that requires or authorises an officer or employee of an organisation:

TAB.TAB: (a) to enter premises:
(i) occupied by an employer who is bound by the award or order; or
(ii) in which work to which the award or order applies is being carried on; and
(b) to inspect or view any work, material, machinery, appliance, article, document or other thing on such premises; and
(c) to interview an employee on such premises.

PARA.TAB: (2) If the Commission is of the opinion that a person has abused the rights provided by subsection (1) the Commission may vary the award or order accordingly.
(3) A person exercising the rights provided by subsection (1) must not:

TAB.TAB: (a) harass an employer or employee; or
(b) hinder or obstruct an employee in carrying out a duty of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that this provision is the minimum necessary for a union and its officials and representatives to be able to organise, to speak to employees and to be able to recruit employees in a reasonable manner. I say `in a reasonable manner' because the commission can ensure—and it should be the commission that does this—that there is no harassing of an employer or employee and no hindering or obstructing of an employee in carrying out a duty of employment.

This is absolutely crucial for effective union organisation. This is a balanced, very important and essential amendment. It is much better for the commission to determine union right of entry provisions than for parliament to legislate these—it is much better to do it that way. The commission is able to make more flexible provisions and take into account the circumstances of particular industries or the actions of particular employers or union officials.

In conclusion and from my own experience, taking the hospitality industry as an example, it is very difficult to go and talk to an employee when they are serving alcohol or serving at tables, but it is not unreasonable to be able to enter the premises and talk to an employee when they are in the rest room or on their meal break or their morning or afternoon tea‐break.

I believe that the commission has acted in the past with respect to each industry in a very reasonable manner. Again, I say that it is very unfortunate that the Australian Democrats, by cooperating and agreeing with the government in this area, are going to make it difficult for unions to organise. The officials that I have talked to, both full‐time and part‐time people in the union movement, have all expressed to me their grave concern at the government‐Democrat approach in this area.

I think this exposes the hidden ideological agenda of the government—the Liberals and the National Party—which is to make it very difficult if not impossible for unions to organise effectively. With the current provisions and awards as administered by the commission or as inserted by the commission—often by consent but sometimes by arbitration—despite the number of times in a year, which must be in the millions, that an official would visit workplaces around Australia interviewing employees, very rarely does the commission actually get a complaint or a dispute in this area. Why the change, Senator Murray? Why the change in this area? I do say quite sincerely that it is very regrettable that you have gone along with this change. There is no evidence that there needs to be a change to the right of entry provisions in awards. On the vast majority of occasions when right of entry has been exercised by officials it has been done in a highly responsible way. And, if an employer believes that it has not been exercised in a responsible way, then the employer or the employer organisation can seek a variance of the particular right of entry provision in the award through the commission. I personally do not know of any such applications. There may have been some—I am not denying that—but they are certainly very rare and thin on the ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 127AA renders unenforceable any award provision or orders dealing with a union's right of entry. It makes workers in dangerous industries more vulnerable to unsafe work practices and complicates and lengthens the dispute resolution process.

SPEECH.PARA: One example of where this right of entry clause will be removed from an award occurs in the building industry. Clause 43 of the national building and construction industry award provides for an automatic right of entry for accredited officials for, amongst other things, `checking safety conditions and regulations'. The Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union have described to me how this would affect their important role in inspecting workplaces to check on safety matters.

Safety is obviously of prime concern in an industry such as the construction industry. Around Australia each year, hundreds of workers die in occupational accidents. Most of these could be avoided with proper safety precautions. In 1993‐94, 60 construction workers were killed—more than one a week. The government claims that this bill will improve the efficiency of Australian industry: how efficient is it to have construction workers dying on unsafe building sites? How will these new right of entry provisions improve the safety of workers in the building industry?

Let me give you an example from your own state, Senator Campbell. On September 6 this year, a young CFMEU organiser named Mark Allen went to a demolition site in Western Australia. He and the other union organiser with him saw several bonfires burning on concrete floors causing topping to explode. They saw workers up on the roof dismantling potentially deadly corrugated asbestos roofing.

Mark called the workers down from the roof to discuss his safety concerns with them. However, the demolition company boss threatened to call the police if the union men did not leave. Mark called Worksafe and requested that a safety inspector be sent to the site. He then climbed up to talk to the workers again. He was concerned about their safety and wanted to convince them to come down. As he approached the men, a section of ceiling collapsed beneath him. He fell 12 metres and died from his injuries.

Will not the prevention of right of entry provisions into awards in dangerous industries such as the construction industry make it more difficult for union organisers to visit potentially dangerous workplaces? Will not employers be even less concerned with worker safety, knowing that the union must give 24 hours notice of an intention to visit, thereby giving the employer a chance to clean up a site at the last minute, having paid little attention to occupational health and safety before that point? Will not this inevitably lead to higher rates of industrial accidents and even deaths?

Section 89A(2)(p) provides that dispute settling procedures are allowable award matters to which the commission may apply its dispute settling powers. Can the parliamentary secretary explain how proper dispute resolution procedures can be followed without right of entry provisions? For example, the metal industry award contains a provision for discussion to occur with employees, shop stewards, management and union officials. Right of entry for union officials is thus both `incidental' and `necessary' for the effective operation of the dispute resolution process as set out in the award. However, this bill does not allow right of entry provisions in the award. How do you explain this contradiction?

What would be the benefit of removing the right of entry provisions from the award in an example such as this? A dispute occurs in company X regarding an employee's refusal to work with an allegedly unsafe machine whose guard is faulty. This happens all the time in industry. The shop steward institutes avoidance of dispute procedures, and the union organiser arrives immediately to assist in settling the dispute. The official is denied automatic right of entry under these proposals. The employer states that there is no award provision and no 24 hours notice pursuant to section 285D(2). Will not the dispute escalate due to having dispute settling award provisions that include the presence of union officials but not award provisions allowing right of entry?

What about having right of entry provisions that are enforceable by the commission in the act but not in the award? What about the lack of right of entry provisions, forcing the dispute into the longer process of AIRC resolution rather than settling the dispute quickly and effectively in the workplace? What is the point of extending and complicating the dispute resolution process in this way? Why will you not leave right of entry provisions in awards as they are in order to protect the industrial health and safety of workers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to what Senator Childs has just said, because I believe that it is a very important issue. I remind honourable senators that last night we went through a section which made industrial action for worker health and safety not allowable. We made it not allowable. It now becomes even more important that there be right of access for unions in this case to be able to maintain some ability to do spot checks on those important issues. All that we were left with after last night was schedule 14(2), which mentions whether the action was based on a reasonable concern by the employee. There is no ability at the moment to legally take any industrial action, including withdrawal from dangerous equipment. Last night, that section was voted against.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only can workers not down tools but they are also, as far as we know under the definition, not allowed to work with a particular piece of equipment. As far as we know, under that definition, that is also industrial action. There is also no right of entry for the union official to be able to assist in those cases. So you are making it not legal to take industrial action and barring unions from going in to be able to assist in those instances. Who will take legal responsibility for the deaths that are likely to occur as a result of this double jeopardy? It is leaving workers totally to their own devices.

Section 14(2) does exactly that. It refers to an employee on their own. They can be forced to go into another area to work. They cannot even take any industrial action other than not work on the equipment or whatever that is likely to be faulty. There is not necessarily a big choice in many of those cases. I strongly support ALP amendment No. 7. I really want to know why there has been this double jeopardy in relation to worker health and safety issues in terms of the ability to take reasonable action and settle issues that occur in the work force without, for instance, having to give 24 hours notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise in support of opposition amendment No. 7. I acknowledge the comments of Senator Childs and Senator Margetts and add my own. In my former capacity as a union official in the building and construction industry, I have had no less than about 10 years experience of how important it is to be able to have the right of entry to a workplace. It is important for all the reasons that have been said. It is important because workers do not have the capacity, in the majority of cases, to be able to call in a union official without the employer intimidating or victimising that worker in some way. To rely, as this government and the Australian Democrats want to, on a mechanism which means that an employee has to formally request the presence of a union official compromises the variability of those employees to seek representation in a fair and meaningful way. This amendment puts back in place an effective mechanism to allow union officials to enter workplaces.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard about the need to be able to enter a workplace on an issue of occupational health and safety. There is nothing more important than a union official being able to walk into a workplace and raise with the employer and the workers issues relating to breaches of health and safety standards. It is a fundamental role. It is a role that, despite all the enabling legislation that has been introduced in this country, is still there. With health and safety representatives, regulations, inspectorates and so forth, that problem has not gone away. The number of deaths and injuries still occurring in Australia shows that the problem has not been solved.

The government and the Democrats, by taking the position they have with respect to right of entry, are effectively denying working people another form of redress when it comes to an unsafe workplace. There is a need for it, particularly in a transient industry. As I said, I come from the construction industry. You do not have a defined workplace in the way you do in a fixed establishment. You have a workplace that changes from day to day, from week to week. It is a workplace that is progressing all the time because you are constructing something. If you need to go through a bureaucratic process to get access to that site, whether it is to try to enforce award conditions or health and safety, it defeats the purpose. It provides an out for employers who are not doing the right thing.

I think Senator Campbell and Senator Murray know that we are talking about cases where employers do not do the right thing. Let us face it, some employers adhere to safety standards. I have to say, though, my experience in building and construction is that the majority do not. The majority do not adhere to the occupational health and safety standards, and there is always some degree of risk on the job.

The other issue about the building and construction industry is one of job security. There is not a lot. It is a transient industry. To hang on to your job in the building industry requires a lot more than just doing what you are paid to do. It is very easy in the construction industry to be targeted by your employer and moved along. It is easy because jobs come and go. The average tenure of employment for a labourer, for example, a non‐tradesperson in the building industry, is about six to eight months of the year, and that is on the positive side.

BREAK.PARA: I would like you to explain to me how a complaint made by building workers, given the transient nature of the industry, is not going to in some way disadvantage them and disadvantage their job security. Why would an employer, if he could suffer no retribution under any of this legislation—and the way it is shaping up, they won't—hang on to an employee who caused them to expend money on something like occupational health and safety? You might say that does not happen, but I am explaining to you the reality of it. There is very little job security for building workers, particularly, and other industries are in exactly the same position. So if those workers make formal complaints, invite a union official onto the job, they are exposing themselves to a disadvantage with their employer. That is the reality.

We are trying to avoid that situation by inserting this clause back into the legislation. The government and the Democrats are not only denying working people access to fair and reasonable representation by union officials, but also they are setting up employees so that it is very hard for them to make a complaint. That is, of course, working on the assumption that they actually know what their rights are in the workplace. As Senator Margetts said in her contribution, so much has been removed from the allowable matters, including trade union training and occupational health and safety, that it is very difficult for those employees to have any access, firstly, to what their rights are in the first place, and, secondly, to have someone come in and educate them and, thirdly, to have a union official arrive on‐site in such a way that the employer will not be able to victimise any of the employees who lodged the complaint in the first place.

I ask Senator Murray if he could respond to that on the basis of the victimisation that will occur in transient industries where there is very little job security, and how those people will be protected if they do make a complaint. The reality is that if employers move someone along because they have made a complaint about safety or something else, when they sack them, they do not say, `I'm sacking you because you've made a complaint about health and safety or your award conditions.' They sack them because, `The job is finished and it's time for you to move on.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to right of entry, I have seen on many occasions over a long period how very difficult it is for workers to deal with issues at their workplace, even if it comes down to how they are paid. One of the fundamental problems I have with what is proposed, and which I would like to put to Senator Murray, relates to this question of 24 hours notice. It is like sending a signal to the employer that there is a problem—you are identifying what the problem is, you give the employer a period of time to call together his or her work force and place enormous pressure on the workers at any work site, whether it be in the building industry, the timber industry, the retail sector or, indeed, in the public sector, such as health services, education or otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: It happens now. That is why workers, quite often, probably more often than not, ring up their union or a representative—and that includes workers who are not even in a union—and say that there is a problem at a work site. Quite often they will not give their names because of the fear they have for the security of their job. I know it is no good appealing to the government because that has been a lost cause from the start.

I certainly appeal to the Democrats, even though they have done a deal with the government, to rethink this aspect. As I said the other night, I hope they will have the courage of their convictions to support amendments to this act in the future when it is proven that some of these issues on which they have come together with the government are so bad and are having such an impact on workers.

The Democrats have proposed for the registrar to issue a permit for right of entry, and the permit can be for a period of three years. This seems somewhat illogical given the current process where the secretary to an organisation can issue to an officer of an organisation a permit for the purposes of right of entry. Other aspects include what can be inspected when they go onto a work site with the exclusion of AWAs. I know that has been dealt with in other areas. If you look at a work site that has an enterprise agreement primarily made up of AWAs, I am stuffed if I know how union officials are going to check on wages and get a complete understanding of the terms and conditions of employment of an employee given that AWAs are supposed to be secret documents.

I now turn to things that have been removed from allowable matters, such as occupational health and safety. We have a real problem with workers compensation costs in every state, and state governments have embarked upon a campaign to try to encourage workers to be more aware of occupational health and safety matters. I do not care who it is, but anyone who is honest in this process will know that in most industries, if not all, in some pockets of employment there are problems with regard to the standard of occupational health and safety. That is under the existing arrangements.

You cannot tell me that it is going to get better if the existing mechanisms for keeping some of these people up to the mark are weakened. In the case of occupational health and safety, if there is a problem you now have to give 24 hours notice before you can go onto a site. This is a ridiculous situation. I think the evidence ought to have been fairly clear to Senator Murray during the inquiry when the number of people, particularly young people, gave evidence to the committee of the difficulties they confronted when they raised issues with their employer regarding contractual arrangements of employment. In the case of Western Australia, I can recall at least three people who gave evidence that, when they refused to take certain terms and conditions on board or have those included in the workplace agreement, they suffered the consequences.

Where a union suspects breaches of conditions of employment or occupational health and safety, it can take immediate action. That is the way it should be. I can imagine ringing up an old company like North Broken Hill, which I used to have a lot of dealings with regarding employment matters, and giving them 24 hours notice of a problem that they had. I have to say that they did try to take that course of action because I thought in the award covering them they did not have an appropriate right of entry clause. So they used to try to require at least a period of notice. The next step will be that you will have to identify the reason why you are going on site.

I do not think it will take too long before employers will exploit this. I would be interested to hear Senator Murray's explanation why employers will not exploit it and how workers can be provided with genuine protection in terms of the conditions in which they work. If he cannot explain, then I believe he does not understand the difficulties which workers are confronted with. I do not say that in any derogatory sense, because I think you have to have experienced a lot of these things first hand.

I can recall a young bloke who worked for Toys `R' Us in Queensland who came before the committee. I draw to your attention what he said and the view that he expressed. He suffered victimisation simply because he involved the union. He sought from the union information. Union officials did not come on site. He did not want them to come on site because he was too scared about that.

They are the sorts of things that you are now proposing to put into an act to exclude a right of genuine protection for workers. They will not be allowed to ring up at night and ask their union to come the next day or in some instances, in the case of shift workers, that night. That is a real problem. I think the Democrats should think long and hard about that. As I said before, there is not much point in asking the government to change their mind. I know their position. We would not have right of entry at all if it were up to them. What we have in terms of the Democrats' arrangement with the government is not much better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubting the sincerity of the remarks made so far. I would like to begin my remarks by agreeing that the original bill was unacceptable to the Australian Democrats in this area and we therefore expressed our opposition to it. Consequently, we have won amendments from the govern ment for which union leaders have told us they are extremely grateful. Opposition senators should not give the impression that there is lack of support for the amendments we have won. Obviously, there are other provisions which are desirable but we need to deal with two separate issues here.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is that occupational health and safety has always been a state matter, dealt with under state law. That has been the recourse for issues that need resolving. The award system has assisted unions and the act to interact with the state governments in this area. Obviously, the current system has many problems because, as previous speakers have outlined, things are happening now that people are not happy with.

Under the amended bill there is no restriction on union officials under proposed section 285(5C) from going into any workplace and discussing with any employer an occupational health and safety matter and then, as they are entitled to do at the moment, having it resolved under the existing law. Further, there is nothing in this proposed legislation which would preclude employers and employees agreeing, in a certified agreement or any other industrial instrument, to an expanded right of entry regime.

With selected industries, the circumstances attaching to arbitration on a dispute over working conditions can be harsh and unjust. There are appropriate mechanisms as well. We have negotiated with the government for what we consider to be a much more balanced and extensive right of entry regime, and that is contained in schedule 15. I will speak at length on those provisions when we come to that schedule. However, I should say right now that one of the fundamental differences is really a shift in the kind of regime under which right of entry will reside.

This is a statutory scheme to replace the award based scheme. It follows the same direction that the New South Wales Labor government has followed in its legislation. In that legislation they have opted for a statutory rather than an award based right of entry regime. There is a great deal of commonality between the proposed federal scheme and the New South Wales scheme, although they are not identical. I will make more remarks on that area when we come to schedule 15.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I need to respond to, even though Senator Murray has cleared up the position on a number of matters.
—Not really.

—Perhaps not to Senator Murphy's satisfaction. I think that Senator Lundy was under a misapprehension in relation to a number of matters. She talked about having to go through a complicated bureaucratic process every time a union official wanted to enter a site. She might not be aware of the intention of the bill as amended to ensure that a permit is not required for each entry; permits will be issued for three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, an employee does not need to make a request. The union can make application for a permit without a request coming from an employee. That is something Senator Lundy seemed to be unaware of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do there have to be union members present or can they go into a workplace where there are potential union members?

—That is quite clear. We have not hidden from the fact that there would have to be a union member on site. But Senator Lundy was talking about intimidation of a union member for having requested a visit. Under amendment 160—which, as Senator Murray so eloquently said, was supported by the Australian Democrats—the member does not have to make a request. The union can make the request, seek the permit and go onto the site. Again, Senator Lundy might have thought that was not the case and so, unintentionally, misled the debate in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy also made comments about workers knowing their rights. I thought her comments unusual for someone who voted against the Office of the Employment Advocate, which office was designed to ensure that workers, if they so chose, had the right to avail themselves of information from trade unions. I am sure that active trade unions, with people like Senator Lundy working for them—as she did in a previous occupation—will go around and ensure that people know about those rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, like they do in Western Australia.

—As Senator Bishop will tell you, there are some very good people in unions like the shop and allied industries union, or whatever it is called, a number of whom have visited me recently in my office.
—Will the Office of the Employment Advocate make visits to sites, informing workers of their rights?

—They are going to do all sorts of things, Senator Lundy. We have dealt with that amendment, and I think we have dealt with that schedule. I do not think it is in anyone's interest or the Senate's interest to actually go backwards.
—You raised it, though; we didn't.
—I found it a little interesting that a senator who voted against the Office of the Employment Advocate should be saying that workers will not know their rights. Well, they have been put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, Senator Margetts still appears to misunderstand the provisions that we voted on yesterday. She probably chooses not to understand that the provisions in 89A do not address industrial action; they relate to the scope of industrial disputes. As Senator Alston stated in that particular section of the debate yesterday, industrial action is not prohibited where it relates to imminent danger. The government‐Democrat amendments do not preclude right of entry. The amendments do not require an invitation for a right of entry.

TALK.START.PARA: —All you can do to back that up is 14(2), and I have just told you why that's a nonsense.

—I have explained the position. The law, as amended—if it gets through the Senate at some stage—will stand. I am telling you that the position you put is wrong. You either refuse to accept the black‐and‐white amendments before you, you refuse to understand them, or you seek to mislead people on them. So there are three choices. I know you are a very genuine person. I know that you would not actively seek to mislead people, so you clearly misunderstand it. I think that covers the issues that were raised in the last four or five contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It was actually Senator Alston who pointed out section 14(2) as being the remedy. I am just pointing out the same section. Read it yourself and then say whether or not that is in fact a remedy when it adds, at the end of the definition of industrial action, `if the action was based on a reasonable concern by the employee about an imminent risk to his or her health or safety.'

SPEECH.PARA: It does not give any ability for workers on a site to take industrial action in support of somebody who is being asked to work on something that is dangerous. That is the reality. It is isolating it to a number of one, and that is all that Senator Alston said is the remedy. If there is another one, let me know, then you can say whether I have misled the committee or not. I am happy to be advised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to conclude in respect of this matter—and we will be dividing on it. I think it was Senator Woodley who, yesterday, berated me for at times raising my voice. He came down here to listen to our argument, and then decided not to support us. I do not know whether Senator Woodley is listening at the present time—or any other Democrat senators for that matter—other than—
—Or any other senator, for that matter.

—Some may, some may not. Perhaps Democrat senators other than Senator Murray are listening. If they had listened to this debate, they would have been convinced, on balance, of the merit of our argument.

BREAK.PARA: I want to again draw the attention of honourable senators to the report of the Senate Economics References Committee. I will quote Senator Murray who, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, said this in respect of the right of entry clause:

The Democrats support in general terms the analysis and conclusions by the Majority report in relation to the exclusion of `right of entry' clauses from awards. There was very little evidence to the committee that the current regulation of the right of entry to workplaces by award clause was in any way inadequate. However, very strong arguments were presented by unions, workers and industrial lawyers to the committee that the impact of the Government's proposed changes would be to unnecessarily restrict the access of union officials to workplaces for the purposes of talking to members and prospective members.

I would also draw this to Senator Murray's attention: I attended about half the hearings and I read the employer submissions. I specifically refer here, Senator Murray, to the employer submissions. I can recall a great number of issues raised by employers in respect of the bill—and you might correct me if I am wrong—but I cannot recall one employer submission criticising the current provisions in the act as to the right of entry. I cannot recall one.

I can recall a lot of other criticisms that we may or may not agree with, but this is one area where there was considerable criticism of the government's proposals and there was not any support from employer submissions. Senator Murray, you have said that you forced the government to compromise. All you have done in this area is turn what is, in our eyes, a manifestly, grossly, horrible provision into a woefully inadequate provision.

Senator Murray, in the glory of your media coverage just over a week ago you launched the agreement that you entered into with the government—the document that we have been working from and for which you have voted time and time again. You cannot shirk from your responsibility by arguing that you made such a dreadfully, woefully bad provision. You have drawn it back a bit but you have still left us with what is a very bad provision indeed in respect of right of entry.

Again, I can only appeal to the Australian Democrats—if they have listened to the argument and the debate that is being presented. I do not believe there is any evidence, any good reason, why the current provisions in the act should not stand as they are. They should not be changed in any way. The matter should be left to the commission. The Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) also referred to this right of entry issue in her speech to the Australian Education Union Victoria conference.

I cannot find the particular provision. Frankly, I am not sure that that is going to make a lot of difference, but I know it is referred to in this speech somewhere. All I can do, again, is appeal to the Australian Democrats not to support the government in this area of right of entry.

This amendment does not just go to the issue of health and safety; it goes to fundamentally being able to recruit union members. Senator Murray has touched on the fact that health and safety is a very important issue, but this goes fundamentally to being able to recruit and sign up people to a union and discuss things with them. These restrictions are horrible. As I have said on a number of occasions in this debate, the position that the Australian Democrats have adopted on this issue is very disappointing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall chapter and verse, but I know that employers have complained to the Australian Democrats—they might have done so during the hearings—about unions entering workplaces where they have no members, for the express purpose of harassing employers and going through their books. The Australian Democrats have consistently agreed with the government that unions should not have a right to go into a workplace for the express purpose of looking at the books when they have no members in that workplace. We agree with the unions that they should—and we have achieved this—be able to go into any workplace for the purpose of recruitment. You still have all the rights of entry for recruitment, but you cannot harass employers when you want to look at their books and have not got members in that workplace.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: Item 27, as amended, agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Campbell) proposed:
(25) Schedule 5, item 29, page 31 (lines 16 to 22), omit subsection (1B), substitute:
(1B) The Commission must, if it considers it appropriate, ensure that a decision or determination covered by subsection (1):

PARA.TAB: (a) does not include matters of detail or process that are more appropriately dealt with by agreement at the workplace or enterprise level; and
(b) does not prescribe work practices or procedures that restrict or hinder the efficient performance of work; and
(c) does not contain provisions that have the effect of restricting or hindering productivity, having regard to fairness to employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in opposition to the government proposal and in support of our amendment No. 44, whilst accepting the commission should ensure awards do not prescribe work practices that restrict or hinder the efficient performance of work, we add that the commission must also ensure that such awards do not prescribe work practices that adversely affect the interests of employees, particularly their health and safety.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not dispute that the commission should ensure that awards are suited to the efficient performance of work, but the existing act also expressly states that the commission must also ensure that awards take into account the interests of employees. The fact that the bill removes this requirement is highly symbolic, showing that the bill is weighted in favour of the interests of employers and against the interests of employees. In the matters of employee health and safety, this is particularly important. I move:
(44) At the end of subsection (1B), add:

PARA.TAB: ; and (d) does not prescribe work practices or procedures that adversely affect the interests of employees, and, in particular, their health and safety.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Sherry's) negatived.
Amendment (Senator Campbell's) agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (8) Schedule 5, item 29, page 32 (after line 19), after subsection (1D), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1E) Paragraph (1D)(a) does not apply to a decision or determination made by the Commission after 22 June 1997, except where the Commission decides, on a case by case basis, that the paragraph should apply for a further two years because:

TAB.TAB: (a) there are special circumstances; and
(b) the parties intend to replace, and are making progress in replacing, junior rates with rates based on skill.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to refer here to the Senate Economics References Committee report at page 353. This matter is in respect of youth wages, which we debated at some length yesterday. We will not be dealing with the matter in the same length now because, regrettably, the Australian Democrats did not vote with us to end the discrimination with respect to youth wages. I would just like to read the recommendation from the Australian Democrats:

It is recommended that age based discrimination in relation to wages cease as from 1 July 1997 as set out in the current Act. However, the parties may be able to approach the AIRC on an award or agreement basis to seek an extension of up to two years at a time provided they can demonstrate special circumstances and that they intend and are making progress in replacing age-based wages with wages based on skill.

I do not intend to repeat the arguments that we debated yesterday. The Democrats got it wrong yesterday; they have got it consistently wrong. I am pleased to see another two Australian Democrats here now. They regrettably were not in the chamber to hear the debate on right of entry, Senator Woodley.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am listening.

—We have just debated right of entry, and it has gone. You challenged us yesterday to provide you with compelling evidence. We believe that any reasonable person, on balance, should have supported our previous amendment. But that has gone, and the Democrats will have to live with it. We have an opportunity here to deal with youth wages again. I do not believe it is necessary to repeat the arguments that we went through yesterday, except to highlight once again the contradiction of the Australian Democrats on this particular provision.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move government amendments No. 26 and 27 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Schedule 5, item 29, page 31 (after line 28), after paragraph (1C)(a), insert:
(aa) where appropriate, contains provisions enabling the employment of regular part-time employees; and

This government amendment inserts a new paragraph 143(1C)(aa) to improve access to part‐time work. The provision will require the commission, where appropriate, to ensure the decision or determination contains provisions enabling the employment of regular part‐time employees, as defined in subsection 4(1) and as provided for in new section 89A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to explain why I opposed amendments 26 and 27 being moved together. I would support 26 but I would not support 27. Therefore, it would be better to deal with them separately. Amendment 26 does improve the situation in regard to employment of regular part‐time employees. But amendment 27 extends the current exemption from anti‐discrimination claims in respect of junior rates of pay by three years. You can see why it was necessary for me to refuse leave at that stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Margetts, we can support amendment 26, but we cannot support amendment 27.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27) Schedule 5, item 29, page 32 (after line 19), after subsection (1D), insert:

The bill repeals reference to an award including provisions relating to superannuation benefits. We want to delete this repeal. We believe superannuation must be retained as subject matter for awards. Award provision is used to require superannuation contributions from employers in relation to employees, even though their income is less than the superannuation guarantee act threshold. There was some debate about this yesterday and I will conclude my comments there.

The bill repeals the requirement for the commission to review awards every three years. We delete this repeal. Why? The award simplification process provided in the bill by section 89A and the transitional provisions—we will be referencing later to amendment 56—is far too severe as it ensures that many employees will lose existing award entitlements. The section 150A review process, although not perfect, has achieved award simplification and should be permitted to continue. There has been some extensive discussion of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Schedule 5, after item 34, page 33 (after line 2), insert:
Repeal the section, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 150B Protection of employees' entitlements in circumstances of employer insolvency

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Each award in force (other than an agreement made under Part VIB or Part VIC of this Act) must be reviewed by the Commission for the purposes of this section.

(2) If, after reviewing an award for the purposes of this section, the Commission considers that the award fails to provide an optimal level of protection for employees affected by the award and employed by insolvent companies, in respect of the following entitlements:

PARA.TAB: (a) wages;
(b) accumulated annual leave entitlements;
(c) termination payments;
(d) long service leave entitlements;
(e) superannuation entitlements;

SPEECH.PARA: the Commission must, in order to remedy the deficiency, vary the award after giving any party to the award who has a genuine interest in the matter an opportunity to be heard.
(3) A Full Bench of the Commission may establish principles about varying awards under this section.

(4) For the purposes of this section, optimal level of protection means the provision of such award‐based protection so as to ensure that the category of employment‐related entitlements described in subsection (2) can not be lost by an employee in circumstances of their employer's subsequent insolvency.

In amendment No. 21 we incorporate a provision which protects employees' wages, accumulated annual leave entitlements, termination payments, long service leave entitlements and superannuation entitlements in the event that an employer becomes insolvent. Currently, employees are often very low on the list of creditors—and they can suffer greatly if prevented from being paid the entitlements they are due. This amendment attempts to rectify the situation. Provisions of the new section 150B give the Australian Industrial Relations Commission a discretion to deal with applications for award based protection of accrued award and legislatively based entitlements in circumstances where the employer becomes insolvent.

It is only fair that a caring society ensures that those who can least afford to lose their lawful entitlements are the ones most effectively protected by the law. In recent years we have seen the advancement of employees' priority in bankruptcy cases ahead of the tax office. However, employees lag behind secured creditors. Countries such as France and Spain have legislated to protect workers' rights in these circumstances and the previous ALP government indicated its intention to address the issue in accord mark 8. In the absence of a legislative response, the Greens believe that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission should conduct a test case into this matter and the commission should be given guidance to ensure that an optimum level of protection is available for employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's view is that this is not the right way to fix up the problem. The fact is that employees come above most other unsecured creditors upon employer insolvency. SPEECH.PARA: (28) Schedule 5, item 35, page 33 (after line 25), after subsection (3), insert:
(4) In subsection (3), award does not include an award made under subsection 170MX(3).

(5) Subsections (2) and (3) do not apply to a State employment agreement unless the agreement is one that was approved by a State industrial authority under a State Act that required the authority, before approving the agreement, to be satisfied:

PARA.TAB: (a) that the employees covered by the agreement are not disadvantaged in comparison to their entitlements under the relevant award; and
(b) that the agreement was genuinely made, or that the agreement was not made under duress or that the agreement was made without coercion; and

(c) that the agreement covers all the employees whom it would be reasonable for the agreement to cover, having regard to matters (if any) specified in the State Act (such as the nature of the work performed under the agreement and the relationship between the employees in the part of the business covered by the agreement and the remainder of the employees in the business).

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important provision. It covers the circumstances in which a state agreement can override a federal award. We have said that a state agreement can override a federal award only where it meets the basic requirements for a federal certified agreement or Australian workplace agreement—that is, the agreement has been approved by a state industrial authority as one that does not disadvantage employees in comparison with their entitlements under their award; the agreement was genuinely made; and the agreement covers all workers whom it will be reasonable to cover having regard to matters such as the nature of the work performed and the relationship of the employees covered to the rest of the business. At present only three states meet this requirement: New South Wales, South Australia and Queensland. I note that the Queensland government has announced plans to rewrite its industrial laws and it remains to be seen whether the new Queensland laws will meet the requirement.

This provision recognises the role that the federal jurisdiction has increasingly played over the last four years of providing a fair and reasonable safety net protection for employees seeking to flee any unfair and unbalanced legislation such as that in the conservative state governments of Western Australia and Victoria. Already virtually all Victorian workers and most Western Australian workers have moved to the federal jurisdiction to avoid harsh and unfair anti‐worker industrial legislation.

The originally drafted section 152 would have allowed employers to undermine John Howard's `No workers will be worse off' pledge by simply undermining federal standards by moving to substandard state agreements. The modification we have made will ensure that John Howard's promise is able to be kept. But at the same time it will ensure that employees and employers can choose the appropriate jurisdiction for the regulation of their employment arrangements whether it be state or federal.

This section will set the standard for the state industrial relations system. The message it sends is this: either states like Tasmania and Western Australia bring their industrial systems up to standard or risk losing the rest of their workers as Victoria has done. Already the Western Australian minister, Graham Kierath, is reviewing his legislation to bring it up to the federal benchmark. The Tasmanian parliament has set up a committee to review its state industrial legislation, which I think will follow suit. The Queensland government, in rewriting its legislation, knows that this is now the benchmark. As such, this is an enormously important provision capable of extending the no disadvantage test beyond federal awards to state awards simply by being here. I therefore commend it to the committee.

Amended section 152 will also make it clear that arbitrated awards under section 170MX, that is, awards made due to a failed bargaining period, will override state agreements. This is because federal certified agreements override state agreements and, as 170MX awards are akin to certified agreements, their treatment should be similar.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

But it then becomes extremely difficult for the employee to move back on to a federal award coverage. So from then on they will always be on an individual contract and we believe that that is unreasonable and unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions to Senator Campbell and Senator Murray. I refer to subclause (5) in the second line where it says, `unless the agreement is one that was approved by a state industrial authority'. What is the meaning of the words, `was approved by a state industrial authority'?

SPEECH.PARA: There seem to be two possible interpretations: one where the agreement is simply filed in a registry and it has the force of law according to the relevant act of parliament. Is simply the filing of the agreement without any consideration at all by the workplace agreements commission sufficient? Or do the words `was approved' require some consideration of the merit of the agreement and whether the agreement is consistent with the law as is traditionally done by an arbitral authority?

Secondly, in the third paragraph it says that the `agreement covers all the employees whom it would be reasonable for the agreement to cover'. What does that mean? For example, presuming an agreement which was registered or sought to be approved by a state industrial authority was binding on only half the employees, that is, half refused to be bound by the agreement and wished to remain under the federal award or the pre‐existing state award or agreement, would it mean that the state employment agreement would not be registered because half the employees or a percentage of the employees refused to have anything to do with the new agreement? Could I have advice on both of those issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, typically your question has both quality and content. I must remark that the federal awards are the relevant and overriding awards. But, in view of the nature of your questions, we should defer to some professional advice. As you know, I sit here without an adviser.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question that you raise is that mere filing would not be satisfactory. The answer to the second question is that the state law must have a provision which precludes the unfair exclusion of employees from agreements.

—Under paragraph (5)(b) of amendment 28, it says `that the agreement was genuinely made, or that the agreement was not made under duress or that the agreement was made without coercion'. TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

Norman Moore in Western Australia got the `no ticket, no start' signs removed off campuses around Western Australia, which was a decision I was very proud of. TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

SPEECH.PARA: Many submissions to the committee highlighted the need to retain paid rates awards. The Women's Industrial Relations Lobby, for example, said in their statement of concerns that they were particularly concerned about:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposed to this amendment. The government proposes to repeal legislative provisions relating to paid rates awards subject to providing access to arbitration in special and isolated cases where the parties are unable to reach an agreement. I refer honourable senators to government amendments 105 and 107 to schedule 9 in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale for removing paid rates awards is that their continuation is inconsistent with the new agreement‐oriented environment where awards provide a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions. The government amendments to the award simplification arrangements will protect employees' overall entitlements to pay when award rates of pay are being converted to be expressed minima.

Where awards, such as paid rates awards, are being varied so that rates of pay are expressed as minima, the commission must include provisions to ensure that the overall entitlements to pay provided in the awards are not reduced by variation. The only circumstances in which such provisions are not to be included are where the commission considers it would be in the public interest not to include them. I refer honourable senators to government amendment 30 in that regard.

The government's position is that the need for different types of awards has disappeared and the general continuation of them would be inequitable. At the same time, the government's amendments to the legislation reinforce our clearly stated position that the transition to minimum rates awards is not a threat to the terms and conditions of employment of workers customarily covered by paid rates awards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose the retention of part 6C. That is not because we are opposed to the retention of paid rates awards. Rather, it is because we believe that this amended bill actually provides for paid rates awards in a much more effective way. Paid rates awards are necessary where there is an imbalance in bargaining power. This occurs in the government sector because the government has massive legal, political and financial power to bring to bear against its unions. But it also occurs in industries like oil and transport because their unions have the ability to bring a company to its knees with wildcat strikes. Hence the need for paid rates awards.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill has been amended by the Democrats to provide for paid rates awards under 170(MX) where the parties cannot reach agreement on a certified agreement. There is a much broader right to arbitration for failed bargaining than exists under the current act. That is a massive benefit to paid rates employees. It says that you do not have to agree to a substandard bargain; you can take the option of putting your concerns before the commission. Proposed section 170(MY) makes it clear that this award is not restricted to being a paid rates award. Item 44 of the transitionals makes it clear that award simplification does not apply to those awards.

There are serious problems with the wording of the unamended part 6C which, it seems, the ALP and the Greens might have closed their eyes to. Since the Bell Bay case, it has been quite clear that most awards that we know of as paid rates awards do not fit the definitions in this part. Indeed, if the part were to be retained, it would have to be substantially amended. The retention of the part in its current flawed state will create more legal problems in the future than are fixed. In all the circumstances, I believe that the solution the Democrats have negotiated with the government will retain access to paid rates arrangements and award increases instead of leading to failed bargaining, and that is when it is needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

This bill represents a significant milestone for the Australian wool industry. It is the culmination of extensive consultation and co‐operation within the industry and clearly demonstrates the industry can come together on issues of critical importance to its future. It reflects a willingness of the industry to work together that I hope will remain a feature of the industry for many years to come.

This government has worked alongside the industry during a very difficult period to help reach the consensus approach to the package of measures reflected in this bill. It is a mark of the level of co‐operation and the recognition of the need for a consensus which brought the industry and government together to resolve this issue.
This bill represents the final stage in the disposal of the wool stockpile which was created during the last years of the reserve price scheme.

The stockpile and the associated debt are both now at a level which is less than half that which had built up in the early 1990s. To a very large extent this is a tribute to the fixed release schedule which has operated since 1994. This government supported the implementation of the fixed release schedule on the basis that it presented a sound mechanism for disposing the stockpile and removing the detrimental effect it was having on the entire wool market. Only through the success of this arrangement has the industry been given the opportunity to review and recommend change to the disposal schedule to enable Wool International, as the stockpile manager, to exercise greater commercial flexibility and responsiveness in the interests of the wool market overall.
The bill provides for a package of measures which will see the stockpile finally cleared by 31 December 2000.

The package broadens considerably the range within which Wool International is required to sell stockpile wool each quarter. The quarterly minimum disposal requirement is reduced from its current level of 182,000 bales per quarter first to 135,000 bales per quarter from 1 January 1997 to 30 June 1997 then reducing to 90,000 bales per quarter from 1 July 1997. The quarterly maximum disposal requirement is increased from 192,000 bales per quarter to 350,000 bales per quarter from 1 January 1997.
The intention of broadening the disposal range is to provide Wool International with considerably greater commercial flexibility to sell more in a rising market and sell less in a softer market.
The expectation is that this will ease the pressure on the fresh wool market at more critical periods in the wool market cycle.
However, the Wool International board will need to balance the exercise of this greater commercial flexibility against three other, new elements.

First, as a means of ensuring a steady retirement of the debt, a target date of 31 December 1998 has been set for the final repayment of the debt. Once this has been achieved, the government's debt guarantee arrangements will also end. This under lines the government's view that it needs to continue to withdraw from the industry to allow the industry to determine its own future direction.

Second, Wool International is to be required to have sold and delivered the last bale in the stockpile by an end date of 31 December 2000. This is included to ensure that the overhang effects of the stockpile on the wool market can be removed at the earliest possible time taking account of the many other factors in the market. It is also included to ensure that Wool International, and the government's involvement in this statutory authority, can be wound up within a reasonable timeframe.

Of course, there may well be an opportunity for Wool International to clear the debt and the stockpile well in advance of these legislated dates and this would be entirely consistent with the government's objectives of an early withdrawal from direct involvement in issues that are clearly matters for the industry and the market place.

Finally, Wool International's objects have been changed in two ways in order to add a new factor which the Wool International board must take into account in determining the rate of stockpile's disposal at any particular time in the future. The requirement for Wool International `to foster the "long-term" profitability and efficiency of the Australian wool industry' has been amended to remove the phrase "long-term". This reflects the increasing need, as the stockpile runs down, of Wool International to foster the short, medium and long term profitability of the industry to the greatest extent possible.

In addition, Wool International is to be required, in providing for the disposal and management of the wool stockpile, and in addition to enhancing the ultimate value of the stockpile, to take account of the effect of the disposal of stockpile wool on the Australian wool market.

This requirement is repeated in Wool International's functions so as to ensure there is no doubt as to its importance in the disposal program. As a result, I expect Wool International to review its sales program and, in reaching the decisions it makes on a day‐by‐day basis on the level of sales, to be continuously addressing the issue of the impact of those sales on the wool market.

As I said at the outset, this package is the culmination of a very intense and widespread consultative process. It is a clear signal that the Australian wool industry is prepared to set its own course and to determine its own destiny without relying on government for support.
It is a sign of the industry's increasing maturity as it forges ahead.
I commend the bill to honourable Senators.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.
