TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak to the report entitled Causes of Death: Australia , which was tabled yesterday and which I am sure we all would have preferred to have ignored. I guess most of us want to avoid facing and discussing the issue of death, but we will be forced to discuss it in more detail when we debate the euthanasia bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This report, which was produced by the Bureau of Statistics, highlights an issue of major concern to me and it is probably one of the issues that encouraged me to come into politics. It is important that the Senate take note—and I draw this to the attention of honourable senators—of the information in this document, which I think many of us could have easily overlooked, especially given its title.

The summary of findings in the report indicated that 125,124 deaths occurred in Australia last year, which was a decrease of 1.2 per cent on the number of deaths which occurred in 1994. The area of increase which concerns me and which, as I said, has concerned me for a long time, is that where dementia is associated with death, especially in older people.

Dementia affects about two per cent of those in the population aged between 65 and 70 and about 20 per cent of those aged over 80. So the older we get, the more likely we are to have dementia. Deaths from dementia account for about three per cent of all deaths of those in the population aged 65 and over, but ranks as the fourth leading cause of death for those in that age range.

There are no reliable data to monitor the prevalence or incidence of death from dementia. The only information comes from death registration statistics. There is a complication in that, because a person may have dementia yet die of some other disease, like pneumonia. It is really a judgment of the doctor as to whether it is dementia that is indicated or whether it is pneumonia or some other illness. Some of the deaths may be associated with dementia, but the actual death could be from a fall or a from a house burning down or something else. So the dementia could be hidden. The other factor that could contribute is that, with the increase in understanding and better psychogeriatric education of medical graduates, more people are likely to diagnose dementia, which is then more likely to appear on the death register. So there are some confounding variables in determining the number of people who die from dementia.

Taking all that into account, anybody in the field would recognise that there has been an increase in the number of deaths from dementia. One of the factors contributing to that has been an increase in the number of older people. Regardless of the concerns that I have expressed about interpreting the statistics, dementia deaths among persons aged 65 and over increased from 582 in 1982 to 3,312 in 1995. During this time, the elderly population has increased by 48 per cent.

We are seeing a disproportionate increase in the number of older people. The population as a whole is increasing at a much slower rate than the population of those aged 65 and over. The number of people aged 85 and over is increasing at an accelerated rate. If anybody wants to get a feeling for this, all you have to look at is what was once called—when I was a student in economics—a population pyramid. By the year 2030, that population pyramid will in fact be a population rectangle. The projected figures for 2030 and 2050 show that the number of older people will far exceed the number of younger people.

This problem will not go away unless we find out the causes of dementia and some way of curing it. Without that breakthrough in medicine this is going to be an increasing problem in the Australian community, particularly as we see an increase in the aging population. It is highlighted by the figures that are expressed in this document, which states:
The projected increase in the elderly population is 58% between 1989 and 2011 and 173% between 1989 and 2031.

That shows the rapid increase in the number of people in that age group. The prevalence of dementia among persons aged 65 or more is estimated to rise by 93 per cent between 1989 and 2011 and by 234 per cent between 1989 and 2031. So by the time some of the young people working in our offices today are 75, there will have been an enormous increase in those figures. Maybe we can sit down and say, `That is in 30 years time.' If you look at the figures, as I have been whilst preparing for a paper I am giving on ageing, and at the need for an increase in nursing homes, in the next 30 years there will be a need to double the capital of nursing homes and hostels.

In the 10 years that I have been in parliament I have seen how little can happen. Unless we as a parliament really start thinking about this very seriously and treating it as a serious issue, we are going to leave a legacy for the next generation—many of us here in this chamber now—of people who will require residential care, which will not be available. It will place an enormous burden on the next generation.

We have to overcome a legacy that has been left by Labor. The Labor Party really neglected the issue of dementia. Time after time I stood in this chamber and asked the Labor government to fund dementia specific facilities. I do not know where the breakdown was, but the policy was driven by some sort of ideology that people with dementia ought to be integrated into nursing homes because they had rights and they should not be segregated. That demonstrated to me an absolute lack of understanding of the behavioural problems that are associated with extreme dementia.

Some people have mild dementia, and they can be managed quite well in a facility for older people. But there are many people whose behaviour is such that it is totally unacceptable in situations of accommodation with people who are frail but not suffering from dementia. There are those people who, because of their disease, wander into other people's rooms; they interfere with their person and with their personal belongings. In one nursing home I went to a woman who was there because she had profound Parkinsonian syndrome had a metal gate across the entrance to her room because two people with profound dementia were going in and beating her over the head with rolled up newspapers. My view was that she had rights. She should not have been locked in her room, with her visitors having to unlock a gate to get in to see her.

If you see a dementia specific facility which is run properly—where people suffering from dementia are able to be catered for with proper activities, where the degree of stimulation is kept low and where staff are trained to deal with some of their psychotic and abnormal behaviour—then you will appreciate that a modicum of order can be maintained. That cannot happen with the comings and goings in a normal nursing home.

This afternoon I was disturbed to hear Senator Neal again put around the furphy that people will have to pay $26,000 to get into a nursing home. She knows that is wrong; she knows that is just continuing to put about a myth. She also said that we were not doing things for people in nursing homes. One of the things the coalition has done is to put in place a funding arrangement that takes account of the fact that a person has dementia, and that was never done by the Labor government. The message that we have had in the Australian Bureau of Statistics report yesterday is a very salutary one. It means that all of us should address this issue urgently. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about recent events in Queensland. This is an extremely sad period in Queensland politics. In recent years, the people of Queensland have enjoyed basking in the glow of a government that was corruption free and seen to be so. Mr Borbidge and Mr Cooper have stolen this from them. They have done it solely in pursuit of their own political ambition. They are robbing Queenslanders of their right to government that is perceived to be corruption free.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the nature of Queensland political history in recent years, I am amazed that the attempt to discredit the CJC has been so blatant and arrogant. The current Queensland coalition government has displayed an appalling sense of propriety in relation to the CJC and the whole process of political and legal reform. The events of the last week have had indicated that, according to the likes of Mr Borbidge and Mr Cooper, the Fitzgerald inquiry may well have occurred in vain.

This is an extremely frightening situation to contemplate for many Queenslanders. Years of political corruption and poor public administration have taken a very severe toll on the people of Queensland. During those dark years, living in Queensland was not beautiful one day, perfect the next. Queenslanders became the butt of many jokes because they appeared to other Australians to be oblivious to the corruption, anti-democratic practices and lack of concern for Westminster traditions—characteristics of the then coalition and National Party governments.

BREAK.PARA: From the late 1960s right through to the late 1980s, people who dared to make public political comment that highlighted the deficiencies of the then Bjelke-Petersen government risked being the subject of special branch surveillance. People who ran the gauntlet of political protest during that time had their homes bugged or raided, were arrested and/or gaoled or were subject to public vilification.

Many of these people who suffered political oppression under the National Party government left Queensland, never to return. They moved to places where they could express their political opinions without fear of ruining their lives and their futures. It was not all that long ago that all this occurred. Living in Queensland was not okay then. It was dark, oppressive and occasionally dangerous. Queensland—beautiful one day, corrupt the next.

Madam President, once again, dark forces govern the state of Queensland. The Borbidge administration has been caught out trying to influence the outcome of the Carruthers inquiry. The Borbidge government has been breathtaking in its attempts to drag Queensland back to the future. The most spectacular example of this was the famous memorandum of understanding that the Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, along with the police minister, Russell Cooper, signed to get rid of the Police Commissioner and six of the senior members of the Queensland Police Service.

This farce commenced on 8 January of this year when a Queensland Police Union wish list was sent to Russell Cooper, who then took the list to a National Party policy committee. The now infamous MOU was created on 10 January, and by 15 January had been signed by Russell Cooper, Rob Borbidge and Gary Wilkinson. On 1 March, former Supreme Court Judge Kenneth Carruthers was appointed by the CJC to investigate allegations of electoral bribery involving the police union memorandum of understanding.

At this stage, it appeared that the new coalition government was to honour their election promise to the Queensland people that it was not going to repeat the mistakes of the past. They have reneged on this promise. When counsel assisting the Carruthers inquiry, Cedric Hampson QC, said that a recommendation of criminal charges against Russell Cooper and others was possible, the Queensland government swung into action.

By 11 October, the state government had launched an inquiry into the CJC and amended the Criminal Justice Act to compel CJC staff and commissioners to give evidence to the Connolly-Ryan inquiry. This then led to the resignation of Mr Carruthers, who had refused to be subject to this inquiry. The establishment of an inquiry that is clearly in conflict with the Carruthers inquiry can only be described as an attempt to pervert the course of justice in the state of Queensland. What we have here is an attempt not only to invalidate the Carruthers inquiry but also to effectively squash the effectiveness of the CJC.

This whole debacle just gets worse. At the weekend we heard revelations of another deal to prolong the strike during the lead-up to the Mundingburra by-election to ensure a Liberal victory. We have also heard reports that Mr Cooper wanted to sack the Director-General of Corrective Services, Keith Hamburger, in exchange for prison officer support. Mr Hamburger is also on Mr Borbidge's secret hit list as a person to be sacked.

Also on this secret hit list are some former Commonwealth public servants who applied for jobs in the Queensland Public Service—people like the former Director‐General of the Department of Employment, Education and Vocational Training and Industrial Relations, Bob Marshman, who is condemned in the secret hit list as an active Labor supporter. Mr Marshman worked for governments of all political persuasion in Canberra. He has never been a member of any political party and was highly critical of directors‐general who showed any party preference, because he believed it compromised their ability to offer objective advice to their minister.

This government is turning back the clock to the days of cronyism in high places. It will not be long before we have a corrupt police force once again because they are trying to carve up the CJC—the body appointed to ensure that there is no corruption perpetrated by politicians within the Queensland Public Service.

The other election rort they tried was the Concerned Citizens of Mundingburra Campaign—a law and order television campaign. It turned out that every member of this so‐called citizens group was a paid‐up member of the National Party—all except the poor dupe who authorised the advertisements. National Party bank accounts were used to channel funding for the TV advertising campaign, which starred none other than Russell Cooper, and were organised by Matthew Heery, who was known as Cooper's `eyes and ears'. Mr Heery has since been charged following consideration of evidence by the Carruthers inquiry.

The list of secret deals goes on and on: a police union secret memorandum; a similar deal with the Queensland Democratic Firefighters Association, an organisation established by Bruce Wilkinson, brother of Gary Wilkinson, of the Queensland Police Union. Bruce Wilkinson in no way speaks on behalf of the majority of firefighters in Queensland. He belonged to a committee that was campaigning against the Labor government in the Mundingburra by‐election. There was the prison officers deal and secret deals with the Veto Eastern Tollway Organisation and the recreational fishing group, Sunfish. It makes you wonder how many other squalid little secret deals are festering away under the surface ready to be exposed. No wonder the coalition government wants to nobble the CJC.

What the current behaviour of the Queensland government is all about is protecting Mr Cooper and Mr Borbidge from the risk of criminal charges to which their unprincipled and unconscionable behaviour has exposed them. In their desperation to take government at any price they have thrown the idea of political ethics in the bin. Now, they are hell‐bent on smashing any institution or inquiry that is ever likely to call them to account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Gibbs on her speech on this issue and I wish to speak on the same subject. I probably will diverge slightly from what she said, but basically I agree with the description she has given of the situation in Queensland and with that history. Any of us who lived during those years can endorse everything she said.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about the future and effectiveness of the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland. I have spoken in the Senate quite a number of times about concerns I have had with the CJC and especially its treatment of whistleblowers. I do still retain those concerns. However, I have always tried to make it clear that those concerns do not in any way reduce my commitment, or that of the Australian Democrats, to the role of the CJC in identifying and preventing official misconduct or other improper actions of governments or their employees.

I am very concerned that the latest round of political turmoil surrounding the CJC will fatally wound the critical role for which the CJC was established. I would have thought that no‐one could forget the traumas of the Fitzgerald inquiry and the effect it had on the perceptions which Queenslanders had of politics and of the police service and the damage those perceptions do to the consensus which is necessary before any police service and any government can really be effective. The CJC was the central plank of the Fitzgerald report's attempt to remedy the faults which the inquiry uncovered.

I believe the Democrats can assess the current Queensland situation with some impartiality. It is not very long ago that the former Labor government in Queensland was engaged in its own battle with the CJC. The message that the Democrats would like to send to all parties in Queensland—and that includes the Democrats too and the CJC—is that we should all calm down, take a cold shower and focus on the real job, which is to serve the public in a competent and incorrupt way. The whole concern exercising the minds of many people in Queensland at the moment is: are we going back to a previous era?

I would also say, however, that the CJC itself does have to share some of the blame for the current shambles in Queensland. Political point scoring seems to have taken precedence over serious attempts to address the issue. One of the problems with the CJC has been its increasing involvement in criminal investigations and political debate. I believe that the CJC should leave criminal investigations to the police and the re‐establishment of an upper house in Queensland would avoid the need for the CJC to be involved in politics. Having said that, however, the real task of the CJC remains to be done. That is to prevent, investigate and prosecute corruption and official misconduct.

The Democrats do not claim necessarily that the Borbidge government's judicial review is just a cynical perversion of the political process, but we are certainly concerned with the interference in the Carruthers inquiry which it seems has brought that to an abrupt end. I trust that the work done by Mr Carruthers will not be lost, but that those reports will be produced. As Senator Gibbs has said, and I agree with her, the interference in the Mundingburra by‐election was a scandal.

Whatever the motives of Mr Borbidge may be there are legitimate concerns with the operation of the CJC and with the sorts of roles it should be performing. The central message—and I and the rest of the Democrats would like to underline this—that we would like to convey to all Queenslanders is: let us not forget how many people fought and how hard they fought to achieve the Fitzgerald reforms and to ensure that that report was written into the conscience of Queensland.

Let us not forget how important that original role of the CJC was and still is and ensure that it is not lost amid the current battles between Labor, the coalition and the CJC. That original role is still fundamental. More importantly, and finally, let us remember that we are all here to serve the public, not just to wrestle for power. Let us approach these important issues in a considered manner, understanding that it is absolutely critical for the political process in Queensland that the CJC continue and that it does the job that we believe it has been called to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to speak about the issue of immigration. I do not want to refer to the views of Mrs Hanson on this subject but, indeed, to the views of Senator Bolkus, in particular in relation to his views about immigration in South Australia. There was an article in the Adelaide Advertiser on 4 November headed `Call for bigger migrant share'. It refers to the federal opposition and says:

SPEECH.PARA: It has called on the Howard Government to examine ways in which SA can reverse the shrinking of its population.
Senator Bolkus is then quoted as saying that SA was `a dying state' which was in danger of becoming `Australia's retirement village'. He said:
The number of migrants we receive is just too low for an ageing population like ours.
We need to regenerate our population base as a matter of urgency.
He also said:

This state is in very serious danger of becoming a home for the ageing. There was a time when young people headed to SA . . . now the children of the people who moved here in the `70s are having to move away.

I must say that I read that with shock and horror—that a South Australian senator could speak so disparagingly of his own state. It is an extraordinary attack on the quality and the people of his own state of South Australia. When I read that I thought, `Let us look at the facts,' because it is always very wise when Labor senators say things to just check the facts, and Senator Bolkus had said all these remarkable things about the dying state of South Australia which Senator Bolkus, of course, represents.

The ABS statistics that I had pulled out are based on the population growth rates for the last 10 years and projections forward as well as median age statistics for the last 10 years and projections forward—and they make very interesting reading. In fact, the population of South Australia, despite what we read from Senator Bolkus, has grown every year for the last 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —In proportion to the rest of Australia?

—Every year, the population has increased. From 1985 to 1995 the population grew by a total of 7½ per cent or about 102,000 people, which as you would all know is about the size of a city like Townsville. So in the last 10 years South Australia has added to its population a city the size of Townsville—over 100,000 people. That, obviously, is quite contrary to the view put by Senator Bolkus that the state is shrinking.

SPEECH.PARA: The population of South Australia is projected by the ABS to continue to grow well into the next century, at least until the year 2036; and the projected population increase over that period of 40 years—which is within our lifetime, Senator Conroy, I trust—will be 12 per cent or about 170,000. So over the next 40 years it is projected by the ABS that we will add to the population of South Australia a city the size of Hobart. Yet we have a senator for South Australia, Senator Bolkus, telling us the place is shrinking and dying. It is obviously not dying; the population is going to grow for at least another 40 years and then it will probably stabilise at around nearly 1.7 million. I would have to say to Senator Bolkus, who obviously does not spend a lot of time in South Australia, that we are talking about the driest state in the driest continent—

TALK.START.PARA: —You wish! You leave the Premier alone.

—A state which, it would not be known to Senator Conroy, is totally dependent on the Murray River, a river system which other states are doing their best to pollute and a river system which clearly is in a lot of trouble. That is one of the reasons we want to sell one‐third of Telstra, in order that we can find the money to clean up the Murray River so that the state of South Australia can get clean water.

SPEECH.PARA: It would have to be said that it is doubtful that South Australia in its current situation and its total dependence on the Murray River for the most important thing that any population needs—water—can sustain a population much bigger than that projected for the year 2036. But Senator Bolkus also went on to say, as I quoted before, that SA is in serious danger of becoming Australia's retirement village. Presumably he means we are all getting decrepit.

He might be speaking about the Labor Party in South Australia; it is very decrepit, I can tell you. But, again, let us go to the facts. The median age in South Australia in 1995 was 35.1 years of age. I am very close to that median age but let us look at the median age in Australia as a whole. That was 33.7. So this ageing decrepit state has a median age of only a bit over one year more than the national average. I see Senator Conroy pointing to himself. He is presumably the median age of South Australia. Congratulations, Senator!

The future projections for South Australia, based on ABS figures, show that: for example, in 2006 the median age will be 38.5 compared with 36.6 for the nation as a whole; in 2026 the median age will be 42.8 for South Australia and 40.6 for the nation as a whole; and in 2046, which is the extent of their projections, the median age in South Australia will be 45 and 42.5 for the nation as a whole.

So even way out into the year 2046, another 50 years from now, the median age in South Australia will only be 2½ years greater than the median age for the population as a whole. Yet we have Senator Bolkus disparaging his state of South Australia, of which you and I, Madam President, are very proud, saying it is a retirement village, we are all dying and it is the nursing home for Australia. Obviously his assertions are utterly ridiculous and without foundation, as are many of his assertions in this place.

The ageing of the population, as those figures demonstrate, is a national phenomenon. It is not something peculiar to the state of South Australia. I am sure Victoria and other states are experiencing the same ageing of their populations. Presumably Senator Bolkus is saying that we have to do something dramatic to halt this increase in the median age. However, it would require a massive change in the demography of not only Australia but also South Australia to change that in any significant way, certainly to halt it.

There would have to be a massive increase in the birthrate of South Australians, which I am doing my best to help, and an incredibly huge influx of very young migrants to make any difference to the gradual increase in the median age. A huge increase in the birthrate or in the number of young migrants is not realistic and probably not sensible in South Australia, or indeed sustainable. As I have often said, what this country really needs and what Senator Bolkus should turn his mind to is a population policy. Senator Bolkus would do himself a lot of good by paying attention to what his own national president, Barry Jones, has said on this subject many times and to the very good report which Mr Jones brought out a couple of years ago, which our government will be responding to in due course.

We really all should approach immigration, the appropriate growth rates for our various states and the median age of the nation from the point of view of the appropriate population for the country. How many migrants we have should be seen in that context. I am personally of the view that a stabilisation of our population at around the 23 million mark, which is projected to occur in around 2036, would be a very sensible outcome.
I conclude by quoting a very interesting letter I saw in the Age today from Dr Phillip Law, AC, CBE, where he said:
Pauline Hanson has poisoned the immigration debate.—
and I think we would all agree with that—
It should be about a sustainable society, not about the ethnic composition of that society.
Immigration needs to be reduced (whether comprising British, Italian, Greece, Turkish, African, Indian or East Asian immigrants) to a level that this country can absorb without deleterious effects.

A recent symposium of the Australian Academy of Science on Australia's population examined economic, demographic, environmental, agricultural, urban, defence and social aspects of population increase and concluded that an ultimate population of around 23 million should be the objective.
We have a remarkably high "quality of life" in Australia. It is the result of great space and a small population. Don't let us destroy it.

We should all heed those words. We should all examine this question of the population and immigration sensibly on the basis of environmental, economic and social factors. We should approach it in a much more constructive fashion than Senator Bolkus in relation to his home state of South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the adjournment tonight about Canberra. An interesting theme has emerged in the adjournment debate tonight where a number of speakers have said there seems to be a correlation between the coalition government and policies that take them back into the past. That is exactly what I want to talk about tonight with respect to Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously this government is anti‐public sector. We have seen the job cuts that have impacted here on the public sector and flowed through to job cuts in the private sector. BREAK.PARA: This government seems to think that Canberra deserves some rough handling and that somehow that will score them points out in the rest of Australia. But, as usual, this government ignores the people factor in their economic equations. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Satellite Launch Facility: Gunn Point, Northern Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 25 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the proposed satellite launch facility at Gunn Point in the Northern Territory:

(1) Is the Commonwealth Government currently involved in the negotiations regarding the establishment of a satellite launch facility at Gunn Point in the Northern Territory; if not, why not; if the Commonwealth is involved, please detail the nature of the negotiations.

(2) Can all memos, departmental advice or letters from Ministers, advisers or departmental officers, internal or between State and Federal Governments, regarding any relevant matters or negotiations regarding this facility be tabled.
(3) What clearances from the Commonwealth Government will be necessary for this project to proceed.
(4) Are there any planned or potential defence applications for the facility.
(5) Are there any present or future issues of national security regarding the proposed facility.
(6) Does the Federal Government have, or will it have, any financial or administrative commitments or responsibilities in relation to this facility.
(7) In the event that this venture fails commercially in the future, what would be the Commonwealth Government's involvement and financial liability.
(8) How does the Commonwealth Government propose to monitor the operations of the facility, particularly in terms of environmental protection and health and safety procedures.
(9) In the event of an accident at, or as a result of, the facilities' activities, what does the Government anticipate its involvement or liability would be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The satellite launching facility at Gunn Point in the Northern Territory is being proposed by Space Transportation Systems (STS) Ltd, with United Communications Public Company Ltd (Thailand) as its major partner. The Commonwealth Government is not involved in any commercial negotiations regarding the project but is involved in the facilitation and regulatory process.
The proponents are currently completing a detailed feasibility study including an environmental impact assessment.

The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has granted the project `Major Projects Facilitation (MPF) Status'. The MPF service provides STS with support from the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism (DIST) in identifying the project approvals required, and coordinating the activities of the various approval agencies so that decisions can be made within commercial timeframes. The Minister has conveyed this support to some parties involved in commercial negotiations with STS, to indicate that the Government is working with STS to ensure the necessary approvals are sought and processes complied with, in a timetable acceptable to a commercial venture.
(2) Due to the commercial nature of the project, much of the information currently held by the Commonwealth is `commercial‐in‐confidence' and therefore cannot be tabled.
(3) Commonwealth Government approvals which are required for the Gunn Point project to proceed are:

PARA.TAB: Foreign Investment through the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975;
environment approvals, as required by the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974;
satellite launch licenses—this legislation is currently being developed and is anticipated to be introduced to Parliament in the Autumn 1997 sittings.

ANSWER.PARA: (4) There are no planned or potential defence applications for the facility beyond what would be the case with a commercial seaport or airport. If the Commonwealth Department of Defence is interested in being a customer for launch services, it is up to it, as it would be with any potential commercial or government customer, to negotiate an arrangement with the service provider.

(5) There are no present or anticipated future issues of national security regarding the proposed facility any more than there would be in the context of a commercial seaport or airport. Launch licensing, which will be required for commercial launches, will take into account national security considerations. This will include the right to veto payloads which may infringe Australian defence interests, Australian law, or international agreements.

(6) As outlined in the answer to questions (1) and (3) above, the Commonwealth's role in the project is both facilitative and regulatory. It has no financial interest in the facility. The project may be eligible for existing generic industry development grants and concessions (eg., tariff concessions), but at this stage none have been applied for.
Ongoing administrative responsibilities of the Commonwealth will be the licensing and monitoring of the satellite launching facilities.

The Commonwealth Government's Investment Promotion and Facilitation Program contributed $50,000 to a pre‐feasibility study for the project in 1995. Funding was also provided by the Queensland and Northern Territory Governments.
(7) As a wholly commercial venture, there would be no Commonwealth Government liability in the event of project failure.

(8) In areas where the Commonwealth has an interest, the operation of the facility will be monitored through legislation providing a regulatory framework for space activities in and from Australia. This legislation will cover environmental protection and health and safety issues that are not already in other Commonwealth legislation.

(9) The space activities legislation will cover issues of Commonwealth involvement and liability (resulting from obligations to UN Space Treaties) in the event of an accident or as a result of a launch facility's activities. Private operators will be required to purchase liability insurance for their activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staff, other than staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, were employed in or attached to the office(s) of the Minister and each of his or her Parliamentary Secretaries as at Tuesday, 8th October 1996.
(2) What were the total salary costs of such staff.
(3) What was the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of such staff.
(4) What were the titles, roles and duties of such staff and what public service (or equivalent) classifications did they carry.
(5) Under what programs were they employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two such staff are employed in the Prime Minister's Office, and one each in the offices of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet).

(2)‐(3) The salaries of the four positions, including ministerial allowances, together with expenditure on travel totalled $108,929 to 8 October 1996. This figure makes up the bulk of the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of the staff.

To obtain information on other overheads associated with the employment of these staff, such as superannuation and property operating expenses, would involve considerable research, and I am not prepared to authorise the time and resources entailed in collecting the information.

(4) The staff are all titled Departmental Liaison Officers, with the following classifications: Acting Senior Officer Grade B and Administrative Service Officer Class 5 (Prime Minister's Office); Senior Officer Grade C (Office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) and Administrative Officer Class 6 (Office of the Parliamentary Secretary, Cabinet).

Their role and duties in each case are to act as a main point of contact between the Prime Minister's or Parliamentary Secretary's Office and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. They provide advice and support in the following areas: correspondence, parliamentary matters, administrative matters, overseas travel, and representational duties by or on behalf of the Prime Minister.
(5) The positions are funded under the Corporate Services (Support Services) program, Prime Minister and Cabinet portfolio.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hydro-electric Scheme, Mamberamo River, Irian Jaya

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact, as reported in the West Australian on 19 September 1996, that Indonesian Research and Technology Minister, B.J. Habibie, offered Australia the opportunity to work on projects in eastern Indonesia including a hydro‐electric scheme for the Mamberamo River in Irian Jaya; if so, what other projects were mentioned.
(2) What information does the Australian Government have about the proposed hydro‐electric scheme for the Mamberamo River.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dr Habibie raised in our meeting on 17 September 1996 Indonesia's plans to construct a hydro‐electric dam in the Mamberamo region. Dr Habibie said he saw a role for Australia in the project in relation to irrigation from the dam and proposed that Australia and Indonesia collaborate to develop irrigation in Irian Jaya. Dr Habibie also mentioned his plan for the development of Eastern Indonesia, but did not mention any other specific projects.

(2) The science and technology portfolio has had primary carriage of cooperation with the Indonesian government on development of the Mamberamo region under the Collaboration on Science and Technology Australia‐Indonesia (COSTAI) arrangement. The following was provided by the minister for science and technology, the Hon Peter McGauran, MP, regarding information which his department and portfolio agencies have about the Mamberamo River project:

The Mamberamo River project is a major development proposal, initiated by Indonesia's Research and Technology Minister Dr B J Habibie. The concept includes development of the region's agricultural and mineral resources, the damming of the Mamberamo River and the development of a 15000 Megawatt hydro‐electric power plant to attract a wide range of industrial activity.

During 1993‐1995 the CSIRO, in collaboration with the Indonesian Agency for the Assessment and Application of Technology, was involved in a preliminary study of sustainable development of the Mamberamo region. The study addressed the development of methodology, the use of remote sensing technologies and the compilation of a multi‐layered data‐base of the region.

The report of the Phase 1 study recommended a comprehensive and integrated approach to the development of the region, including the conservation of biodiversity and proposed a Phase 2 study which would produce an environmental and resources management plan, covering nature conservation, agriculture, forestry, industrial and other development and social issues.
The proposed Phase 2 study has not progressed because funding (estimated at US $5 million) has not been obtained.

The Australian Geological Survey Organisation has not been actively involved in the development of the project to date. However AGSO has had preliminary discussions with Indonesian officials regarding a possible geoscientific contribution to a database of the region.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Social Security: Office Fitout

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 30 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the circumstances surrounding the fit-out and refurbishment of Senator Newman's office; specifically, is the Minister aware: (a) how inefficient the fit-out people were; (b) that clear instructions were ignored and that work had to be redone; (c) that a meeting table could not produce a flat surface to work on; and (d) that the lighting installed was excessive and that those working on her office were not getting professional supervision.
(2) Were those working on the refit and refurbishment of Senator Newman's office required to address her as Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Administrative Services has advised that there were difficulties experienced in the fitout of the office due mainly to a breakdown in the supervision of the work at a critical time.
